headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Kyle, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Yum! Brands Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I'd now like to turn the call over to
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Kyle, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Yum! Brands Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I'd now like to turn the call over to Mr. Steve Schmidt, Vice President of Investor Relations and Corporate Strategy. Sir, you may begin your conference.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kyle. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. On our call today are Greg Creed CEO; and Pat Grismer, CFO. Also on today's call is Larry Gathop, Yum!'s Treasurer, who'll be participating in the Q&A. Following remarks from Greg and Pat
componenttext:
Thanks, Kyle. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. On our call today are Greg Creed CEO; and Pat Grismer, CFO. Also on today's call is Larry Gathop, Yum!'s Treasurer, who'll be participating in the Q&A. Following remarks from Greg and Pat, we will take your questions.
I want to thank all of you who joined us in Texas for ou investor conference in December. I'd like to remind everyone that the presentations from this conference are available on our website.
Before we get started, I would like to remind you that this conference call includes forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements are subject to future events and uncertainties that could cause our actual results to differ materially from these statements.
All forward-looking statements should be considered in conjunction with the cautionary statements in our earnings release and the risk factors included in our filings with the SEC. In addition, please refer to the Investors section of the Yum! Brands website at yum.com to find disclosures and reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures that may be used on today's call.
We are broadcasting this conference call via our website. This call is also being recorded and will be available for playback. Please be advised that if you ask a question, it will be included in both our live conference and in any future use of the recording.
Finally, we would like to make you aware of the following upcoming Yum! investor event. Our first quarter 2016 earnings will be released Wednesday, April 20. And with that, I'd like to turn the call over to Mr. Greg Creed.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased you could join us today as we share with you the opportunities ahead for Yum! as well as a review of our results. Before we get started, I want to underscore what I presented at our Investor Day
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased you could join us today as we share with you the opportunities ahead for Yum! as well as a review of our results. 
Before we get started, I want to underscore what I presented at our Investor Day in December. 2016 will be a transformational year for Yum! as we complete the spinoff of our China Division, ultimately creating 2 powerful independent, focused growth companies. The fundamental goal of Yum! however, is unchanged. We are 100% dedicated to building and strengthening KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell all around the world as strong brands are critical to delivering sustained growth and creating shareholder value over the long term. I'm pleased with the momentum we generated across the majority of Yum! in the fourth quarter. 
KFC China, for example, grew same-store sales 6% in the last quarter of 2015. This was a sequential improvement from the third quarter and in line with our expectations. Outside of China, each of our brand divisions grew same-store sales on a 1- and 2-year basis. Our U.S. results in the fourth quarter were particularly strong for all 3 brands as KFC posted its sixth consecutive quarter of same-store sales growth, Taco Bell continued to outperform the category and Pizza Hut grew same-store sales 2%. On a 2-year basis, our fourth quarter comps in the U.S. were the best of the year with Pizza Hut at plus 2, KFC at plus 8 and Taco Bell at plus 10. This success has complemented our international results in the quarter where KFC posted 2% same-store sales growth with solid results in both emerging and developed markets and Pizza Hut grew same-store sales 3% in emerging markets.
Fourth quarter EPS grew 11% with full year EPS growth of 3% in 2015 despite a 7% decline in the first half and a 6 percentage points of foreign currency headwinds. For the full year, our brand divisions collectively grew operating profit 8% in constant currency, which is in line with our ongoing growth model target. This was led by 12% operating profit growth at Taco Bell, a remarkable result given the significant investments we made in the fourth quarter to position the brand for continued momentum and category leadership for years to come. Operating profit grew 8% in constant currency in China with impressive cost management partially offsetting weaker than originally expected sales [indiscernible] 
We opened more than 2,300 new units globally in 2015. And as I look forward, I expect 2016 to be a year of improved performance, building on the fourth quarter's momentum. This year, we expect nearly 2400 new restaurants, which means we're opening over 6 restaurants a day, laying the groundwork for future growth. With all of this in mind, we are reiterating the guidance we gave you in December. Given the results we've seen year-to-date and the plans we laid out for each of the brands, we are confident in our ability to deliver 10% operating profit growth in constant currency in 2016.
Now I'd like to discuss what gives me confidence in the future for each of our businesses. After that, Pat will walk you through the financials. So first, China. As I mentioned, KFC, which represents about 75% of the division's operating profit, grew same-store sales 6% in the fourth quarter, continuing the sequential improvement we saw throughout the year. System sales grew 9% in the quarter as we added 114 [ph] net new units, surpassing the 5,000 unit mark. I'm thrilled the China team is applying global best practices, fresh thinking and new insights to revitalize the brand and achieve traction with consumers. test results have proven that global sales-driving techniques are encouraging, and the implementation of these programs shall drive transactions and benefit the division later this year.
One example is which has proven successful globally, and we expect to be similarly well-received in China. I can assure you that we are taking the right steps to grow the business, and the momentum we are seeing makes me confident we will.
Pizza Hut Casual Dining in China, which represents about 25% of China's operating profit, has proven more challenging. System sales in constant currency grew 4% in the fourth quarter as we added 151 net new units, but same-store sales declined 8%. The macroeconomic environment and volatile stock market have impacted the casual dining segment, and we know we had to generate more exciting value to counter this headwind. We'll be more focused on value going forward with workday lunch specials and value pieces as well as other initiatives to drive traffic. We have our work cut out for us at this year and we'll be moderating our development pace a bit this year. Nevertheless, the China team has a number of strategies and that we expect to improve results. We know substantial runway for new units in same-store sales growth for China's leading western casual dining brand.
Before I move on to the other divisions, I want to give you a quick update on January sales in China. We're encouraged by what we're seeing in KFC, but Pizza Hut sales remain soft. It's difficult to gauge exactly where the first quarter will finish, especially given the earlier timing of Chinese New Year. But at this point, we expect same-store sales growth to be up low single digits for the division, which sets us up well for the balance of the year. We expect solid KFC sales going forward. And even with the potential of negative results of Pizza Hut Casual Dining in the first half, we are reconfirming our full year guidance for the China Division to generate same-store sales growth of 2% to 3%, operating profit growth of 10% in constant currency and to open 600 new restaurants.
Now turning to our 3 brand divisions. KFC is our franchise emerging powerhouse. Franchisees [indiscernible] 85% [ph] about 705 new international restaurants in 2015. Total system sales grew 11% in emerging markets for the year with particular strength in Russia and Central and Eastern Europe. In fact, Russia has generated system sales growth of at least 40% in each of the last 4 years. I'm also encouraged that our recent performance in developed markets such as Australia, Japan and the United States. These results reinforce my confidence in the brand's ability to drive sales going forward. We don't only have an ability to generate meaningful growth in mature markets where we have a long-established presence, we also have tremendous potential in emerging markets where we have a significant lead over the competition. So we are taking our global brand identity and unifying that with local cultural insights to expand and grow our business all around the world. We are 100% focused on our real authentic and freshly prepared food and merging that with value and innovation to drive results. The international front we've enjoyed success with lunch and dinner box meals, and we're delighted by in the United States are finding their way into the system. For example, we just introduced national in the U.S. This is a sparkly version of our crispy chicken inspired by one of NASCAR's most famous dishes. The new unit pipeline remains impressive. In KFC's top 12 emerging markets, excluding China, we only have 1 restaurant per million people. Today with an aggregate population of 3 billion people in these markets, think of the potential.
Across the world, we have plans in place to grow sales and to build on the division's consistent operating growth performance. I am confident KFC will continue to excel and reward shareholders for years to come.
At Pizza Hut U.S. we are starting to turn the corner with our focused emphasis on making it easier to get a better pizza. This runs the gamut from improved operations and insight-driven food innovation, digital enhancements and consistent value. While we recognize it was a lot more work to do, we're now generating consistent transaction and same-store sales growth in the United States. Equally significant and as you heard in December, we reached an important agreement with our U.S. franchise. Starting in January, we begun an overhaul of our assets replacing and upgrading in-store technology. From a marketing calendar perspective, we are focused on a balanced approach. This begins with premium-priced innovation least recent launch of pizza to protect and improve unit level economics. You may also seen the launch of our $5 flavor menu the most compelling value menu in the pizza business. In conjunction with our ongoing $6.99 any pairs deal, it will provide customers with great value on an ongoing basis. We are encouraged by the start of the year of pizza in the United States, and we believe we have the right strategy going forward. Our international business at Pizza Hut is led by strength in emerging markets but offset by weakness in some of our developed markets. We believe you can apply best practices from the U.S. business to drive growth in these developing markets going forward.
Finally, Taco Bell delivered a fantastic 2015, surpassing 9 billion in system sales, and we expect solid year end 2016 as well. Taco Bell is on the cutting edge of QSR. And as the industry gold standard for social engagement on the product development, brand positioning and advertising. We have several new exciting product launching this year, including 1 we'll announce during the Superbowl. So be sure to watch the first half to see the national introduction. Our innovation focus extends beyond just food. We are encouraged by early results of our delivery program and are developing expansion plans for additional cities. The addition of our loyalty program in November also in our mobile app and will increase brand affinity as it rewards social behavior. Furthermore, we are focused on our core value messaging to drive actions. We continue to build on our breakfast daypart where sales were growing at twice the rate of our business as a whole. In fact, we grew best breakfast transactions 6% in the fourth quarter. Given the brand's strong economics and broad franchise appeal, we continue to accelerate new year openings both domestically and internationally with a record number of U.S. openings in 2015 and expect to build upon this in 2016. I'm particularly excited that we're starting to traction expanding the brand internationally. We know this process will take time, but we're making real progress here. Our growth plans both domestically and internationally will lay the groundwork for higher operating profit growth in the years to come. With all this progress, you can see I'm very excited about what's happening other company. We are undertaking the biggest strategic move in the history of Yum! with our spin of the China business. We are confident that this will create 2 large, optimally structured, independent companies with unique investment profiles. Yum! China will target 15% ongoing EPS growth, and it's focused solely on Mainland China and will pay the new Yum! a 3% license fee. New Yum! will be a high margin global franchise company targeting 15% shareholder return. Recapitalization plans are underway and will be completed in the first half of this year. We see substantial value in our share at current prices as we have repurchased 23 million shares from the announcement of the separation through last night. I want to assure you that while the spin-off transaction is critically important, we're not going to let that distract us from the business in China or anywhere else. All 3 of our brands have significant opportunities for growth as they progress along the journey to brand excellence. We expect to achieve 10% constant currency growth in operating profit this year as a company and are setting up 2 separate companies that will lead the restaurant industry going forward.
Yum! is in a unique position. We have 3 iconic brands and are making them even stronger. As you've heard me say before, my goal is to build 3 global iconic brands that people trust and champion. We are well on our way to achieving this, led by our brand positioning, courageous leadership and committed team members and franchisees. Needless to say there's a lot to be excited about at Yum!, and I could not be more pleased to lead this company into its next phase. Finally, as you all know, this is Pat's last earnings call with Yum!, and I'd like to take this opportunity to thank him for his leadership, his hard work and unwavering drive to raise the bar of Yum!. He will be missed across the organization. As you may have seen in our 8-K filing, we've appointed our current Corporate Controller, Dave Russell, as interim CFO. And I look forward to working with him while we complete our search for a permanent CFO
And with that, it gives me great pleasure to hand the call over to Pat.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Greg, and good morning, everyone. In my remarks today, I'll cover 3 areas: our fourth quarter results, our outlook for 2016 and an update on the separation of our China business. I too am pleased with the overall sales momentum that we demonstr
componenttext:
Thank you, Greg, and good morning, everyone. In my remarks today, I'll cover 3 areas: our fourth quarter results, our outlook for 2016 and an update on the separation of our China business. I too am pleased with the overall sales momentum that we demonstrated in the fourth quarter where EPS excluding special items grew 11%. Reported EPS growth was considerably higher as last year's fourth quarter included a noncash special charge related to the impairment of our Little Sheep concept in China. Excluding special items and the impact of foreign exchange, operating profit grew a healthy 17% in the fourth quarter led by system sales growth of 6% and restaurant margin improvement of over 3 percentage points. 
I'll now take you through our results by division, starting with our China business. For the division overall, same-store sales grew 2% in the fourth quarter. As we preannounced, KFC grew same-store sales 6%, which was sequentially better than Q3 as we expected. We're encouraged by the positive momentum in our KFC China business, particularly as it sustained into the new year. Same-store sales at Pizza Hut Casual Dining, however, have remained sluggish and declined 8% in the fourth quarter. As Greg said, the China team is addressing this matter with urgency, and we will update you on our progress throughout the year. Restaurant margin management continues to be a bright spot in China's performance. For the fourth quarter, China restaurant margins improved more than 4 percentage points versus prior year to 11.4%, helped by sales leverage at KFC and productivity improvements across the division, more than offsetting sales leverage at Pizza Hut. As a reminder, our fourth quarter is a seasonally low sales period for the China Division, so the absolute restaurant margin tends to be lower at the time of year. Full year restaurant margin was 15.9% for the division, an improvement of 1 fill percentage point. It's not often that you see restaurant margins expand with declining sales, so this highlights the extent of the China team's effort to improve profitability through cost controls. I'm proud of the team's continued focus on productivity, and I'm confident this bodes well for future profit growth in China as same-store sales continue to recover and unlock significant profit leverage in the business. Given our continued strong belief in China's long-term growth potential, I'm encouraged by continued strong cash paybacks on new units we opened 743 new restaurants in 2015. And while we are prudently dialing back the pace of new unit developments in 2016, targeting about 600 new restaurant openings, we've also expected fewer closures this year, so our net new units will be similar to 2015. Our decision to temper the pace of development balances the reality of current market conditions with the opportunities we have to enter new trade zones and expand our presence in existing ones. We are also making good progress on modernizing our estate. In 2015, we remodeled about 500 restaurants in China, and we plan to remodel about another 550 in 2016. By the end of this year, we will have remodeled our yearly built about 45% or nearly have half of our China estate in a 3-year period.
Now moving to our global KFC Division, which posted its eighth consecutive quarter of same-store sales growth. System sales growth was especially strong in emerging markets, up 10% led by Russia and Southeast Asia. International development also delivered solid system sales growth up 6% led by Australia, Japan and Western Europe. And the U.S. recorded its sixth consecutive quarter of same-store sales growth at 3%. Restaurant margins grew 90 basis points to 14.7% in the quarter and improved 150 basis points for the year to nearly 15%. Operating profit grew 7% in the quarter before the impact of foreign currency translation. Adjusting this, for a lack of a onetime favorable pension resolution, as well as incremental advertising expense associated with our U.S. acceleration agreement, operating profit grew 11% in the quarter, roughly in line with KFC's ongoing gross model. Importantly, KFC set another new record for international development in 2015 opening 705 new restaurants demonstrating the power of this global iconic brand. Our global Pizza Hut Division delivered 1% same-store sales growth for the quarter led by 2% same-store sales growth in our U.S. business, which accounts for about half of the division system sales. Operating profit improved 6% in constant currency, driven by higher franchise fees and higher restaurant markets, partially offset by an increase in U.S. G&A, including severance and other onetime costs. Restaurant margins actually improved 240 basis points in constant currency for the quarter, driven by same-store sales leverage and commodity deflation. For the year, Pizza Hut opened 429 new international units. While this was below our initial forecast for 2015, we now have a more robust development pipeline and are confident that we'll open at least 525 new international units in 2016. Finally, Taco Bell about posted 4% same-store sales growth in the quarter. Restaurant margin improved to 3.1 percentage points to 23.7% raising full year margins to approximately 22%, a remarkable achievement for this powerhouse brand. Operating profit, however, declined 7% in the fourth quarter due to an expected increase in G&A related to performance-based incentive compensation, strategic growth investments including restaurant technology and international supply chain and other nonrecurring costs. We believe these investments will strengthen the brand and help to sustain positive momentum in the business as evidence of the onetime nature of these expenses, we actually expect Taco Bell's SG&A will decline in 2016. Additionally, we expect restaurant margins to remain above 20% even with our more aggressive push on value. 
On the development front, we opened 276 new stores in 2015. This included 41 units outside the U.S, 4x the number we opened in 2014, demonstrating the progress we're making to ramp up international development. 87% of the deficiency restaurants were open by franchisees, reflecting the attractive investment returns the Taco Bell brand generates. I'd now like to talk about our 2016 outlook. Supported by the results we've seen year-to-date, we continue to expect to deliver operating profit growth of 10% in constant currency this year. And while I will be providing quarterly guidance, I would like to point out that certain brands are facing hurdles both prior year lapse and timing of current year expenses which will weigh on first half results. As a consequence, we expect second-half operating profit growth will be directionally stronger in the first half. This is consistent with our plans coming into the year, and we remained confident we will achieve our full year operating profit guidance.
Now I'd like to quickly cover off our spin-off plants. We're making good progress and are on track to complete the separation of our China business by the end of this year. A major part of our plan is to optimize the capital structure of Yum! Brands and return $6.2 billion to shareholders prior to the separation through the issuance of new debt. From the time we announced the separation through last night, we repurchased 23 million shares. While our weighted average basic share count for the quarter was $433 million, our basic share count as of February 2, 2016, was $411 million. We see value in repurchasing our shares that we consider to be at a discounted price and view this as a prudent use of shareholder capital. I'm also happy to report that we're on scheduled to complete our recapitalization in the first half of the year, issuing incremental debt of approximately $5.2 billion and plan to maintain roughly 5x EBIT to leverage going forward. We're now in the process of finalizing the form and timing of this financing. Now I'm sure you've noticed the volatility in the high-yield market, particularly within the energy and materials sectors. We'll continue to watch this closely, but we're pleased that the rates on our future debt remain very attractive in a historic basis, and we're full steam ahead with our plans.
So let me wrap things up. 2016 will be an exciting year for Yum! Brands. Not only do we expect to deliver 10% operating profit growth in constant currency, but we're proceeding as expected with the separation of our China Division into an independent publicly traded company. Yum! China will have no external debt, and we'll self-fund the growth capital while generating significant free cash flow in year 1 and on an ongoing basis. The new Yum! will be a global diversified franchise company with an optimal capital structure. By 2017, we will be 96% franchised with a stable but fast-growing free cash flow stream. I am pleased I was able to participate in this landmark decision for the company and that we are optimizing shareholders value by creating 2 powerful investment opportunities. I am very confident in both company's future growth prospects and look forward to their ongoing success.
And with that, I'll open up the call to Q&A.

componenttext: It's just a combination of both sales and spending. Clearly, in the case of Pizza Hut in China, our expectations for the first half are more muted, and we expect their sales recovery to improve in the back half of the year, so that will weigh in the first half results. At the same time we have spending some of our global brand that will be more heavily concentrated in the first half of the year. And in the second half of the year, we'll lapping some of the investments that were made in G&A and so that will contribute to the shape of earnings over the course of the year.

And also, can you just talk about why not -- is this the moment you start developing Pizza Hut delivery more aggressively since it seems it's a huge untapped opportunity at the same time there's some issues obviously with the dine-in business.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, with respect to margins in China, I'm not going to bifurcate by brand but it is fair to say and you've seen from the comps that we recorded at the sales performance at Pizza Hut Casual Dining was not as strong as for KFC in China and that's largely
componenttext: First, with respect to margins in China, I'm not going to bifurcate by brand but it is fair to say and you've seen from the comps that we recorded at the sales performance at Pizza Hut Casual Dining was not as strong as for KFC in China and that's largely due to more significant transaction decline in that business and so that did weigh more heavily on Pizza Hut China margins in particular. And then with respect to development, you're absolutely right. It's early days for the Pizza Hut delivery business in China, and so we will be picking up the pace of development for that particular concept as we look to temper the pace of development of both KFC and Pizza Hut Casual Dining in 2016.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the roll-up of value at Pizza Hut China. Is just give us perhaps a little bit of our retrospective and looking forward about what value means to that brand? Did Pizza Hut China really get away from the five-star dining at three-star pri
componenttext: Just a question on the roll-up of value at Pizza Hut China. Is just give us perhaps a little bit of our retrospective and looking forward about what value means to that brand? Did Pizza Hut China really get away from the five-star dining at three-star prices in recent years, leaving it more vulnerable now? And can you share with the rolled out so far in the sort of value might be thinking about for the brand and you think that's going to be enough to offset the casual dining weakness in the country? We'd now I think first of all the macros which have got worse since December. And I think we all know that macros impact casual dining more than the impact QSR so I think that's definitely that issue. I would agree with you that we do not have enough value used to overcome this backdrop. I think we've also -- as w5 spoken in previous calls, a lot of discussion around stake and there wasn't this much discussion if you just think about it on our pizza. So I think our ability to talk value but value around pizza, I think you'll see more of that going forward. So yes, the answer is we've got to focus of the Court the strengthen our brand positioning you got a target value to increase transaction such a smart value across dayparts. We also have to, I think, improve our in-store experience in order to stay ahead with the competition. And I think the other thing we've got to do is to be a leader in digital better stay relevant, and I think does a lot of things we can do in that market as well. To round out the answer, we got about 5 value program in test for Pizza Hut in China. We see some early encouraging results, but that's going to take us some time to get into the marketplace and as Pat said I think you'll see a much better second half than you see first half Pizza Hut.

componenttext: Two quick questions. The first one being when you look at the success of 3 global brands, particularly here in the U.S. in recent quarters, work from a sales and margin perspective. How should we think about the 3 margins through this year. We've got easing costume got very intense competition. How do we think about the margins for those 3 segments this and to follow that up, could you give us an update on the plans  to franchised those 3 brands you know the 91% to 95% by the end of '17? How is that progressing? And maybe to some extent, how does the success of these brands recently impact that refranchising effort?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly, Keith. First, in terms of margin performance at 3 global brands. Bear in mind, our equity ownership in those 3 global brand businesses I think, collectively, the order of 10% so it's a franchise driven business but nonetheless we do focus on re
componenttext: Certainly, Keith. First, in terms of margin performance at 3 global brands. Bear in mind, our equity ownership in those 3 global brand businesses I think, collectively, the order of 10% so it's a franchise driven business but nonetheless we do focus on restaurant margins above for the benefit of her company and then importantly to ensure that our franchisees are realizing good returns on their investment. I would say overall, we're pleased with the progress are making on margins for our KFC global division to improve about [ph] 1 percentage point versus last year was quite a significant accomplishment, combination of same-store sales growth and productivity improvements contributing to that. At Pizza Hut, equally happy with the progress we made this year, to your point, supported by commodity deflation as well as in the last quarter some sales growth. And then for Taco Bell, another banner year with restaurant margins on a full year basis, around 22%. As we build on that momentum into next year, we are expecting our KFC and our Pizza Hut businesses to continue to realize margin improvement aided by same-store sales leverage as well as more modest commodity outlook than we've seen in some years before. In the case of Taco Bell, my expectation is that margins will be above 20%, perhaps a bit below where they were in this year because of the more aggressive push on value and a more tempered approach to pricing. And then in terms of the refranchising, the teams are very much committed to realizing the objectives that we laid out to achieve 96% franchise ownership by the end of 2017. In the last 30 days, Greg and I have met with each one of the global brand divisions to review the refranchising plans, and they're very discreet plans around specific geographies and pacing associated with that. Given the complexity of some of these other transactions, we expect the re-franchising activity will be more heavily concentrated in 2017.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Can I just add a point on the brands? Just a point but I was really excited -- I was in Southeast Asia in January is that the global -- the positioning for the 3 global brands is really starting to see it on a global basis. So whether it's Always Original KFC, whether it's this whole idea of need to make it easier to get better at Pizza Hut and obviously, Taco Bell, I happened to be in Thailand and less than 2 months after, we sort of rolled out we need to make it easier to get better Pizza Hut on Bangkok backlog and seeing really focused plans about what we had to do to get better in what they have to do to make it easy so I think the thing I'm really encouraged about this how we've got these positioning for the 3 brands. If the pace with which I'm seeing that appear in the markets 126 countries that we operate that's giving me encouragement that we can continue to drive same-store sales growth going forward.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had a question on the new-unit development. Maybe this is more a clarification. So when we think about the units opening in China this year, can you give us a breakdown between KFC and Pizza Hut? And then is the Pizza Hut slowdown just, in your min
componenttext: I just had a question on the new-unit development. Maybe this is more a clarification. So when we think about the units opening in China this year, can you give us a breakdown between KFC and Pizza Hut? And then is the Pizza Hut slowdown just, in your mind, temporary or is it more of a shift from actual into delivery units?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly, Diane. When we look at the 740 or so we opened this year, about 350 were at KFC, 2 80 at Pizza Hut Casual Dining, and the balance split between Pizza Hut Home Service and Little Sheep. When we look out to 2016 and our expectation of around 600
componenttext: Certainly, Diane. When we look at the 740 or so we opened this year, about 350 were at KFC, 2 80 at Pizza Hut Casual Dining, and the balance split between Pizza Hut Home Service and Little Sheep. When we look out to 2016 and our expectation of around 600 new unit opening. That's about a 20% reduction. And that 20% reduction applies almost equally to KFC and to Pizza Hut, So we are looking at the deceleration the pace of development for both KFC and for Pizza Hut Casual Dining. And we don't expect that, that is an indication of how things are going to play out much longer term. It's just that essay mentioned in my prepared remarks earlier, given current market conditions, we feel that it's prudent to dial back a bit, but we continue to be very confident in the value that we will create from these investments as we're continuing to see cash paybacks of around 3 years, and we know the long term potential of the market remains significant. So we do expect at some point in time the pace of development will increase for all brands. I think the discussions that I've been having with Micky are really around you still see 20,000 plus restaurants. as an opportunity. I think that we still believe that the growth story in China the consumer classiest economic or not they used to be still better than in the world and I think as you get these brands clearly position to be get back to doing two things you spoken about that we need to do. I think, long term, we remain still committed that this is at least what I'll call my horizon of 20,000 restaurant unit opportunity for the China business.

componenttext: Karen, what I would highlight for both KFC and Pizza Hut in terms of emerging markets, which remains strong overall given the proceeding by way of system sales growth is the system sales growth has been a bit below our expectations for some of the emerging markets in Southeast Asia.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes in the line of Jeffrey Bernstein from Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes in the line of Jeffrey Bernstein from Barclays.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, just 2 restaurant margin questions. One in China. Pat, I think you said for this full year, it was 15 9 [ph] plus 100 basis points, and that was quite impressive considering the sales declines. So as we think about 2016 and we you talked about 2
componenttext: Actually, just 2 restaurant margin questions. One in China. Pat, I think you said for this full year, it was 15 9 [ph] plus 100 basis points, and that was quite impressive considering the sales declines. So as we think about 2016 and we you talked about 2% to 3% comp growth, I'm wondering why perhaps the guidance I think you mentioned in the past 15% plus margin in '16 wondering why it would be significantly higher, presumably positive comps. And maybe you could offer some food and labor commentary. And then a similar question on Taco Bell, I think you said greater than 20% margin in '16 but down from '15, it sounds like the value push perhaps coming So wondering what if you guys could just talk a little bit about the category with the discounting going on seems to intensify the and if Taco Bell's well positioned to respond to that.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly, and we'll start in China. We finished the year from a margin perspective in China stronger-than-expected. And so our current expectation is that margins in 2016 will be about in line with 2015, so around 16%. As you mentioned, we're expecting t
componenttext: Certainly, and we'll start in China. We finished the year from a margin perspective in China stronger-than-expected. And so our current expectation is that margins in 2016 will be about in line with 2015, so around 16%. As you mentioned, we're expecting to realize some benefit from same-store sales growth, but we are taking, I would say, a more tempered approach to pricing, given the focus on value as the team's emphasis is on building transactions, building healthy transactions. And so that may mean that we wouldn't take pricing that we might have in the past to fully offset inflation, and we would be much happier with an outcome where we would build transactions with flat margins as opposed to growing margins. And so that's the outlook for China. As it relates to Taco Bell, I would say things are a little bit similar in the sense that the emphasis will be on value to both of the great momentum we had in 2015. We are expecting modest inflation. I would say probably more than we realized historically in the labor category for our company stores where we're anticipating there could be some movement in wage rates, and I would say a modest outlook on commodity inflation for the Taco Bell business.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: let me just talk about the whole question about value. The great thing is Taco Bell remains well positioned. It remains the value leader. Look, we've all seen what happens in the marketplace in the year [ph] 5 for 4 [ph], 4 for 4, 2 for 2. So [indiscernib
componenttext: let me just talk about the whole question about value. The great thing is Taco Bell remains well positioned. It remains the value leader. Look, we've all seen what happens in the marketplace in the year [ph] 5 for 4 [ph], 4 for 4, 2 for 2. So [indiscernible] there's been some -- there's been a fair amount of value initiatives out there. So as you would expect from our position, they're back looking at the calendar I think you will see some changes that you'll come out obviously we've got this great new product launch coming out on Sunday, so I think that you have a positive impact on the brand. do all the right things and I'll make sure that they continue to be well positioned in the value leader in the marketplace going forward. That's what you expect great brands to do.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Bittner from Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Bittner from Oppenheimer.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2 questions. First is on China kind of following up fourth quarter you did have great margin leverage again and operating profit growth of almost 200% on a 2% comp, and you're expecting similar comps going forward as you head in the fourth quarter.
componenttext: I have 2 questions. First is on China kind of following up fourth quarter you did have great margin leverage again and operating profit growth of almost 200% on a 2% comp, and you're expecting similar comps going forward as you head in the fourth quarter. So can you just talk a little bit more about when investments are being made in China via going to keep the margin and profit growth more in check as your guidance kind of suggests? And then I do have a follow-up.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, in terms of China margin for 2016, as i mentioned, there will be much stronger emphasis on value in order to stimulate traffic. And as a consequence, we're not necessarily expecting that pricing will fully offset inflation. What we're expecting by
componenttext: First, in terms of China margin for 2016, as i mentioned, there will be much stronger emphasis on value in order to stimulate traffic. And as a consequence, we're not necessarily expecting that pricing will fully offset inflation. What we're expecting by way of inflation in 2016 is about 1% for food and high single digits for labor. But again, we're not expecting to fully offset that pricing may be best practice focusing on building transactions. We are counting on continued productivity improvements, probably not the heroic improvement that we've seen in years past. If we do better than 2% to 3% comps in 2016, we would expect margin to improve but we're not planning for that right now. The other variable though is labor efficiency because the team, let's face it, has consistently surprised as to the upside, and that can provide further detail into China margins in 2016. We think, at this stage, guiding about flat margins year-over-year is appropriate.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That make sense. The second question is just on the pending recap that you expect to be completed here in the first half. You said at the Investor Day that you're targeting kind of a 5 1/4% blended interest rate. Is that still unachievable targets targete
componenttext: That make sense. The second question is just on the pending recap that you expect to be completed here in the first half. You said at the Investor Day that you're targeting kind of a 5 1/4% blended interest rate. Is that still unachievable targets targeted rate that kind of stand here today?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: As Pat mentioned, the market has been very volatile and spreads have widened across the market. That said, there's a lot of bifurcation in the market. The good credits are still getting done at a fairly good and attractive rates, especially basis. So it r
componenttext: As Pat mentioned, the market has been very volatile and spreads have widened across the market. That said, there's a lot of bifurcation in the market. The good credits are still getting done at a fairly good and attractive rates, especially basis. So it really depends on exactly what we execute and we're evaluating some specifics on both the tender of the debt and the types of debt we put out there. So the 5 1/4% I'd say still in the game. But the 5 1/4% or plus not on the lower end of that at this point.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Brian, that 5 1/4% that we referenced was for the entire debt portfolio not just the incremental debt. So just wanted to make that clear.
componenttext: And Brian, that 5 1/4% that we referenced was for the entire debt portfolio not just the incremental debt. So just wanted to make that clear.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of John Ivankoe from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of John Ivankoe from JPMorgan.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on China margins. Obviously, you guys were happy with margins, given the comps in 2015. You're happy with the levels in the fourth quarter as well. But the question has to continue to be asked and certainly been asking it for the last couple of
componenttext: A question on China margins. Obviously, you guys were happy with margins, given the comps in 2015. You're happy with the levels in the fourth quarter as well. But the question has to continue to be asked and certainly been asking it for the last couple of years to what extent that attention to cost controls, labor efficiency, other OpEx efficiency, what have you, has actually in some way contributed to the lack of traffic recovery that you guys have consistently expect. So I just wanted to see whenever you researcher information anything, qualitative, quantitative that you may have to make everyone comfortable that you haven't gone too far and in that context, some of the guidance in China margins in 2016 that there are no more structural costs that's out within the China system and that margins are really now going to be a function of comps.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Start with that one. I'll take that. Certainly, the customer metrics -- certainly, on KFC, the customer metrics are now back pre the incident. So I think that it doesn't matter what metrics you look at, I would say all of those metrics are obviously way b
componenttext: Start with that one. I'll take that. Certainly, the customer metrics -- certainly, on KFC, the customer metrics are now back pre the incident. So I think that it doesn't matter what metrics you look at, I would say all of those metrics are obviously way back. In an absolute sense, the pizza metrics are actually higher than the KFC metrics regained as much momentum but they're, on an absolute sense, higher. I think the other thing just to address your question menu supplication as well. So I think what you've got to do is obviously besides looking at labor and other cost how do we simplify the menu so we make it easier for the customer to speed up the experience in KFC's case or in Pizza Hut's case, I think really delivered the best casual dining in-store experience in order to stay ahead. So there's a number of issues around simplified menu boards, box meals make it actually easy for the customer to order rather than standing in queue and lining up. So we're spending a lot of time making sure that the margin improvements do not impact the customer experience. And all of the evidence that I can see suggests that there is no impact on the customer experience, and Micky has on improving the speed of service, particularly in KFC, and has a number of initiatives in place that I think will actually announce it experience, enhance throughput and obviously lead to sales and transaction growth.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, what I would add to what Greg has said is we continue to believe that long term 20% is an appropriate margin target for the China business. And you have to think about that in the context where average unit volumes are today, and we know they can go
componenttext: John, what I would add to what Greg has said is we continue to believe that long term 20% is an appropriate margin target for the China business. And you have to think about that in the context where average unit volumes are today, and we know they can go. We're not putting a time frame on it, but we know there's a enormous profit leverage in the business, given all the gains that have been made in the last 2 to 3 years. And as the same-store sales continue to recover, we'll see significant margin improvement. To your point, that is up from comps, but I also wouldn't underestimate the opportunity for the China team to continue to realize some structural improvements in the business. They consistently deliver well beyond our expectations, have enormous capability. And I think the next leg of productivity improvement in the restaurants will be unlocked by technology. And it's fair to say that the digital capabilities of our China business are the best that we have in our entire company, and we're all very excited about that it's going to transform dull customer experience and that will allow further productivity activity in the restaurants that contribute to that margin over time.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Tarantino from Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Tarantino from Robert W. Baird.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is on the pizza business in China, and I know this might be a hard question to answer but I was wondering if there's any way you can sort of dissect how much of the comp weakness you seen recently more related to macro issues versus internal i
componenttext: My question is on the pizza business in China, and I know this might be a hard question to answer but I was wondering if there's any way you can sort of dissect how much of the comp weakness you seen recently more related to macro issues versus internal issues? And I guess said differently, is there any benchmark within that market that you're looking at that would say are underperforming or overperforming relative to the industry there? And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me take that one. We don't have obviously the sort of information we had in the U.S. and NPD data to try and get the specifics that you're asking. I think we all know and you seen this not just in China but outside that casual dining is impacted by ma
componenttext: Let me take that one. We don't have obviously the sort of information we had in the U.S. and NPD data to try and get the specifics that you're asking. I think we all know and you seen this not just in China but outside that casual dining is impacted by macros. It's just what happens. And it always has a bigger impact on casual dining when macro is volatile the QSR business. So if I was to say what are the 4 factors, I would say macros. I think the second one would be we do not have enough value news in order to overcome this sort of macro backdrop, which is why we got the number of tests in the marketplace right now. And obviously with a sense of urgency we need to get these tests into the marketplace, I don't think there's definitely competition definitely more competition in the marketplace. I don't think a lot of this competition is going to try to scale up so the broadscale like the Pizza Hut is and then I think the last point the aggregators at a small percentage of total sales I would say it's macro, its value, it's competition and I can't put a percentage in point. I know you'd like it, but those would be the 4 factors. And that's why our response has to be focused on the call this trend and the brand positioning target value increase transaction, deliver the best in-store dining experience and leading digital whether it's free WiFi, Q2 getting pre-ordering and in partnerships of people like Alipay and WeChat to drive cashless payment as well as the So that's the things we're doing in response to the 4 things we see driving, I guess, the performance were not happy with Pizza Hut.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess the follow-up to that, that's very helpful. But the follow-up is if it is ends up being mostly macro, it seems like you're turning into a pretty current into some of those. How much contingency have you built into the plan if the Pizza Hut bus
componenttext: And I guess the follow-up to that, that's very helpful. But the follow-up is if it is ends up being mostly macro, it seems like you're turning into a pretty current into some of those. How much contingency have you built into the plan if the Pizza Hut business doesn't stabilize as you'd expect in the second half?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, first of all, we do have a number of tests. So I don't want anyone to go away thinking that we haven't developed number of tests. Now I think the difference between KFC we can draw unproven ideas the other 100 countries where we got KFC. Th
componenttext: Well, I think, first of all, we do have a number of tests. So I don't want anyone to go away thinking that we haven't developed number of tests. Now I think the difference between KFC we can draw unproven ideas the other 100 countries where we got KFC. They have less opportunity to do that, but I can assure you that Micky and the team are really focused on what I would call these value platforms being tested and obviously what we're trying those impacts, we need to see impacts. And I think some of the early day test result suggests we've seen impact of these tests somewhere between plus 1 to plus 7. So we've a long way to go we've got to get into the rail! world but I am at least optimistic with what I'm seeing on the test but this is a hard slog. This is a lot harder than KFC in China. We're going to have to work really hard but we got the right team in order to come up with the right ideas to where we come all the barriers that either macros or competitive put in our way.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Karen Short from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions on Pizza Hut. I guess your U.S. comps seem to comment at the low end of expectations at least stated at your December Analyst Day. International is a little uninspiring. So first question is any color as to why. And then I guess 2 re
componenttext: A couple of questions on Pizza Hut. I guess your U.S. comps seem to comment at the low end of expectations at least stated at your December Analyst Day. International is a little uninspiring. So first question is any color as to why. And then I guess 2 related questions would be you outlined a path to achieving a 3% comp at Pizza Hut Analyst Day with various initiatives, but it seems a little optimistic on the blended basis. And then the last portion of the question is, is there any way to accelerate the common POS conversion because, I guess, it seems like 1 common system might really be the backbone that you before comps can really be accelerate.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me start with the U.S. comps. It wasn't our best quarter in 3 years, and I agree. That sort of pales with the KFC 2-year [ph] comps and Taco Bell at [ph] 10, but it wasn't our best quarter in 3 years. And as I indicated in my prepared remarks, I
componenttext: Okay. Let me start with the U.S. comps. It wasn't our best quarter in 3 years, and I agree. That sort of pales with the KFC 2-year [ph] comps and Taco Bell at [ph] 10, but it wasn't our best quarter in 3 years. And as I indicated in my prepared remarks, I'm very encouraged by the stock for 2016 for Pizza Hut. And what I'm encouraged about is how rapidly this whole idea that we need to make it easier to get better is going around the world. I know that in the past if I have turned up in Bangkok 2 months after we came up with [indiscernible] I probably would not have seen that be impacted or reflected in the work to make this better or make it easier. So I'm encouraged by the start of Pizza Hut in 2016. I have confidence that you'll see us deliver sequential improvement in same-store sales this quarter versus the fourth quarter. And every journey has to start somewhere. I think that journey started in the fourth quarter of 2015. And then I am encouraged by how rapidly we are taking this idea and seeing it now being impacted in addressed by all of our teams around the world.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Karen, as to your question regarding the common POS, the team estimates it will take a couple of years to migrate all of the restaurants in the U.S. to a common platform, so they're targeting end of 2017 to accomplish that. It is a high priority
componenttext: And then Karen, as to your question regarding the common POS, the team estimates it will take a couple of years to migrate all of the restaurants in the U.S. to a common platform, so they're targeting end of 2017 to accomplish that. It is a high priority but given the integration between those POS systems and other applications that will take some time in order to do it properly and minimize disruption to our business.

componenttext: In terms of the China comp for the fourth quarter, the 2% increase reflected 4% benefit from pricing. And then, we also had a positive benefit impact of mix, sales mix. And then that was offset by some transaction decline in getting to the 2% comp. With respect to our leverage event and use of proceeds, as you know, a lot of it comes down to valuation. And where things are at, at the time. So it's early to say how we're going to be returning cash.

componenttext: Your next question comes from Andrew Charles from Cowen and Company.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pat, just a quick housekeeping give us the puts and takes on China margins this quarter. And then separately, as China food costs become little bit favorable. I know there's a little bit of inflation for next year as well as some more resilient pricing, s
componenttext: Pat, just a quick housekeeping give us the puts and takes on China margins this quarter. And then separately, as China food costs become little bit favorable. I know there's a little bit of inflation for next year as well as some more resilient pricing, should we expect you to sacrifice the favorability for traffic in order to pursue value in 2016 both China brands relative to [indiscernible] in 4Q?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Andrew. First, in terms of the drivers of Q4 margin, we are very pleased with performance in the quarter. Margins were up versus prior year about 4.5 percentage points, and here's how it breaks down. When you take the 4% pricing, add to it the mix b
componenttext: Okay, Andrew. First, in terms of the drivers of Q4 margin, we are very pleased with performance in the quarter. Margins were up versus prior year about 4.5 percentage points, and here's how it breaks down. When you take the 4% pricing, add to it the mix benefit, and strip off the impact of the transaction decline that's about a net 2-point benefit. On top of that, we had a 3-point benefit from productivity and another 1 point benefit from close stores. Offsetting that was 1.5 margin attributable to inflation. Commodities were flat but we had 6% inflation on labor. And so that's basically the walk to the 4.5-point gain in margin versus prior year. In terms of how we are thinking about 2016, as a mentioned before, the team is very much focused on building transactions. So while we do expect some modest inflation from a commodity perspective, up about 1% and high single digits for labor, we're not planning to take pricing to entirely offset that. We will look to some ongoing productivity improvements to help mitigate the impact of inflation, but the goal this to at least maintain margin year-over-year at around 16% and to achieve meaningful improvement in transactions.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So essentially, food costs should be flat then within that construct?
componenttext: So essentially, food costs should be flat then within that construct?

componenttextpreview: We thought about 1 point of inflation from a commodity standpoint for the year now that you're asking 2016. .
componenttext: We thought about 1 point of inflation from a commodity standpoint for the year now that you're asking 2016. .

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Just a single follow-up from a handful of earlier questions. I believe it was at your December analyst meeting, you noted Pizza Hut Casual Dining is listed with several of the online aggregate think piece of the sales mix coming from those channels is something less than 5% mix. I'm just curious you expect that sales mix to grow and then more broadly more importantly, what's the longer-term strategy of those aggregators as you move forward eventually become a little bit more powerful.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: To answer your question, they're still low as a percentage of the sales mix, I think, in Q4. I think at KFC, they're about 2% of total sales. I think Pizza Hut Casual Dining was about 2% of total sales. I think Pizza Hut is about 30% of total sales, but o
componenttext: To answer your question, they're still low as a percentage of the sales mix, I think, in Q4. I think at KFC, they're about 2% of total sales. I think Pizza Hut Casual Dining was about 2% of total sales. I think Pizza Hut is about 30% of total sales, but obviously, it's a small part of the pizza business. Yes, we are obviously working with these aggregators and to participate with them. I think I would like to say that a turn [ph] so we don't lose the customer data or write out brands. So I think that's the critical part of the relationship is that the aggregators like working with brands like us, and we like obviously not making sure we keep our customer data and we make sure we keep our brand position really clear in this marketplace.

componenttext: And one final question, in terms of gauging momentum concepts but is it just still building or are you getting the sort of a tipping point or maybe it's gotten about as far as it's going to go it settles back down as we get deeper into '16 and '17? componenttext: Yes.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, as I said, the 4 factors that's impacting our business when I spoke about earlier, I think macros, value, competition, aggregators, I think they are the 4 [ph]. I think they probably stay the  4. I think our ability to deliver value news in
componenttext: Yes, I think, as I said, the 4 factors that's impacting our business when I spoke about earlier, I think macros, value, competition, aggregators, I think they are the 4 [ph]. I think they probably stay the  4. I think our ability to deliver value news in the marketplace will be a much greater driver about improved performance, and I see much growth there. It will continue to grow. I'm not suggesting it won't continue to grow, but I think that because we have strong brands, and the aggregators want to work with us as strong brands, I think that puts us in a more driver's seat in terms of how we play with them versus the small guy, so I think the aggregators will have different terms and arrangements. I feel good about where we are. I can tell you that the China team is all over it. Micky is very well versed. He has definitely met with the aggregators personally. So we are watching this is but I think macro will be in the short term more important for us to address.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say that we're very pleased with the progress we're making on the digital front of Taco Bell. You recall that we launched our Taco Bell app in the fourth quarter of 2014. Today, we have about 5 million app downloads. When we look at the behav
componenttext: Yes, I would say that we're very pleased with the progress we're making on the digital front of Taco Bell. You recall that we launched our Taco Bell app in the fourth quarter of 2014. Today, we have about 5 million app downloads. When we look at the behavior of those customers who were ordering through the app, the average check is higher by about 30%. So we're very much encouraged by the results. We're looking to build awareness of the app to drive utilization, and an important part of that is the introduction of a loyalty component to the app, a game that was launched in late 2015. It's the first loyalty program of its kind that rewards social behavior. And the first reward that was offered for customers who played the game was a free Taco Bell freeze, so there was a lot of excitement around that. The app is also configured in the way the tribes exploration of menu. So it helped to create a lot of buzz and a lot active engagement with our heavy users, very high levels of social sharing of the rewards we've observed, and the overall user response has been very positive. So the focus now is having to launch the app and the program to drive awareness, and so we do expect to see even greater trial in the coming months. The goal as you know for Taco Bell is to strengthen its position as an on-demand brand. And so leveraging technology to do that is an important part of the brand's priority going forward.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean what I really love about it is the customization that's going on. We recently just got certified by the American Vegetarian Association for Taco Bell. And we can highlight -- we probably can't run an ad on TV to highlight that, but using the app, w
componenttext: I mean what I really love about it is the customization that's going on. We recently just got certified by the American Vegetarian Association for Taco Bell. And we can highlight -- we probably can't run an ad on TV to highlight that, but using the app, we can. And it's really interesting to see that we're actually getting people customized out of beans as a protein. And from a margin point of view, that's really good for us, and it also makes the customer happy. So what I love is we can use the mobile app as a vehicle to actually talk, I guess, a more discrete story about the brand. It's a great story, it's a good story, but we wouldn't traditionally do on mainstream TV, but we can use this to get that message out and that's making the brand more relevant and making any brand more relevant is the name of the game.

componenttext: So first, on China, same-store sales similar to recent quarters book brands our view is the customers have been more significantly impacted by the softening economy, particularly around the industrial cities, which have been more heavily effective trade but that's the only meaningful difference to call out. And then as it relates to the Taco Bell G&A, as we mentioned, the increase in the fourth quarter was expected. And it's fair to characterize a large chunk of incremental G&A as being nonrecurring. So some components within clues performance driven incentive compensation because they have absolutely blockbuster year, and so they were paid accordingly. We planned for 100% payout, so that contributes to year-over-year decline as we think about 2016. There were some investments that were made in some strategic growth initiatives. I would highlight international supply chain developments. I would also highlight the digital initiatives that we just talked about, and that contributed to a spike in the fourth quarter. And importantly, I think about those investments to sustain positive momentum of the brand. I think good businesses strong performing businesses reinvest profit upside to sustain momentum, and that's exactly what happened to Taco Bell.

componenttext: Good morning. My name is Kyle, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Yum! Brands Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kyle. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. On our call today are Greg Creed, CEO; and Pat Grismer, CFO. Also on today's call is Larry Gathof, Yum!'s Treasurer, who will be participating in the Q&A. Following remarks from Greg and
componenttext:
Thanks, Kyle. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. On our call today are Greg Creed, CEO; and Pat Grismer, CFO. Also on today's call is Larry Gathof, Yum!'s Treasurer, who will be participating in the Q&A. Following remarks from Greg and Pat, we'll take your questions.
I want to thank all of you who joined us in Texas for our Investor Conference in December. I'd like to remind everyone that the presentations from this conference are available on our website.
Before we get started, I would like to remind you that this conference call includes forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements are subject to future events and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from these statements.
All forward-looking statements should be considered in conjunction with the cautionary statements in our earnings release and the risk factors included in our filings with the SEC. In addition, please refer to the Investors section of the Yum! Brands' website at yum.com to find disclosures and reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures that may be used on today's call.
We are broadcasting this conference call via our website. This call is also being recorded and will be available for playback. Please be advised that if you ask a question, it will be included in both our live conference and in any future use of the recording.
Finally, we would like to make you aware of the following upcoming Yum! investor event. Our first quarter 2016 earnings will be released on Wednesday, April 20. And with that, I'd like to turn the call over to Mr. Greg Creed.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased you could join us today as we share with you the opportunities ahead for Yum! as well as a review of our results.Before we get started, I want to underscore what I presented at our Investor Day i
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased you could join us today as we share with you the opportunities ahead for Yum! as well as a review of our results.
Before we get started, I want to underscore what I presented at our Investor Day in December. 2016 will be a transformational year for Yum! as we complete the spinoff of our China division, ultimately creating 2 powerful independent, focused growth companies. The fundamental goal of Yum!, however, is unchanged. We are 100% dedicated to building and strengthening KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell all around the world as strong brands are critical to delivering sustained growth and creating shareholder value over the long term. I am pleased with the positive sales momentum we generated across the majority of Yum! in the fourth quarter. 
KFC China, for example, grew same-store sales 6% in the last quarter of 2015. This was a sequential improvement from the third quarter and in line with our expectations. Outside of China, each of our brand divisions grew same-store sales on a 1- and 2-year basis. Our U.S. results in the fourth quarter were particularly strong for all 3 brands, as KFC posted its sixth consecutive quarter of same-store sales growth, Taco Bell continued to outperform the category and Pizza Hut grew same-store sales 2%. On a 2-year basis, our fourth quarter comps in the U.S. were the best of the year, with Pizza Hut at plus 2%, KFC at plus 8% and Taco Bell at plus 10%. This success has complemented our international results in the quarter where KFC posted 2% same-store sales growth, with solid results in both emerging and developed markets and Pizza Hut grew same-store sales 3% in emerging markets.
Fourth quarter EPS grew 11%, with full-year EPS growth of 3% in 2015 despite a 7% decline in the first half and a 6 percentage points of foreign currency headwinds. For the full year, our brand divisions collectively grew operating profit 8% in constant currency, which is in line with our ongoing growth model target. This was led by 12% operating profit growth at Taco Bell, a remarkable result given the significant investments we made in the fourth quarter to position the brand for continued momentum and category leadership for years to come. Operating profit grew 8% in constant currency in China, with impressive cost management partially offsetting weaker than originally expected sales results.
We opened more than 2,300 new units globally in 2015. And as I look forward, I expect 2016 to be a year of improved performance, building on the fourth quarter's momentum. This year, we expect to open nearly 2,400 new restaurants, which means we're opening over 6 restaurants a day, laying the groundwork for future growth. With all of this in mind, we are reiterating the guidance we gave you in December. Given the results we've seen year-to-date and the plans we've laid out at each of the brands, we are confident in our ability to deliver 10% operating profit growth in constant currency in 2016.
Now I'd like to discuss what gives me confidence in the future for each of our businesses. After that, Pat will walk you through the financials. So first, China. As I mentioned, KFC, which represents about 75% of the division's operating profit, grew same-store sales 6% in the fourth quarter, continuing the sequential improvement we saw throughout the year. System sales grew 9% in the quarter as we added 114 net new units, surpassing the 5,000 unit mark. I'm thrilled the China team is applying global best practices, fresh thinking and new insights to revitalize the brand and achieve traction with consumers. Early test results of proven global sales-driving tactics are encouraging, and the implementation of these programs should drive transactions and benefit the division later this year.
One example is box meals, which has proven successful globally, and we expect to be similarly well-received in China. I can assure you, we are taking the right steps to grow the business, and the momentum we are seeing makes me confident we will.
Pizza Hut Casual Dining in China, which represents about 25% of China's operating profit, has proven more challenging. System sales in constant currency grew 4% in the fourth quarter as we added 151 net new units, but same-store sales declined 8%. The macroeconomic environment and volatile stock market have impacted the casual dining segment, and we know we had to generate more exciting news and value to counter this headwind. We'll be more focused on value going forward, with workday lunch specials and value pieces as well as other initiatives to drive traffic. We have our work cut out for us at here and we'll be moderating our development pace a bit this year. Nevertheless, the China team has a number of strategies and concepts in test that we expect to improve results. We know a substantial runway for the new units in same-store sales growth for China's leading western casual dining brand.
Before I move on to the other divisions, I want to give you a quick update on January sales in China. We're encouraged by what we're seeing at KFC, but Pizza Hut sales remained soft. It's difficult to gauge exactly where the first quarter will finish, especially given the earlier timing of Chinese New Year. But at this point, we expect same-store sales growth to be up low single digits for the division, which sets us up well for the balance of the year. We expect solid KFC sales going forward. And even with the potential of negative results of Pizza Hut Casual Dining in the first half, we are reconfirming our full-year guidance for the China Division to generate same-store sales growth of 2% to 3%, operating profit growth of 10% in constant currency and to open 600 new restaurants.
Now turning to our 3 brand divisions. KFC is a franchise-led emerging powerhouse. Franchisees opened 85% of our 705 new international restaurants in 2015. Total system sales grew 11% in emerging markets for the year, with particular strength in Russia and Central and Eastern Europe. In fact, Russia has generated system sales growth of at least 40% in each of the last 4 years. I'm also encouraged by our recent performance in developed markets such as Australia, Japan and the United States. These results reinforce my confidence in the brand's ability to drive sales going forward. We don't only have an ability to generate meaningful growth in mature markets where we have a long-established presence, we also have tremendous potential in emerging markets where we have a significant lead over the competition. So we are taking our global brand identity and unifying that with local cultural insights to expand and grow our business all around the world. We are 100% focused on our real, authentic and freshly prepared food and merging that with value and innovation to drive results. On the international front we've enjoyed success with lunch and dinner box meals, and we're delighted ideas created in United States are finding their way into the system. For example, we've just introduced Nashville Hot in the U.S. This is a spicy version of our crispy chicken inspired by one of Nashville's most famous dishes. The new unit pipeline in KFC remains impressive. In KFC's top 12 emerging markets, excluding China, we only have one restaurant per 1 million people. Today, with an aggregate population of 3 billion people in these markets, think of the potential.
Across the world, we have plans in place to grow sales and to build on the division's consistent operating growth performance. I am confident KFC will continue to excel and reward shareholders for years to come.
At Pizza Hut U.S. we are starting to turn the corner with our focused emphasis on making it easier to get a better pizza. This runs the gamut from improved operations and insight-driven food innovation to digital enhancements and consistent value. While we recognize there was a lot more work to do, we're now generating consistent positive transaction and same-store sales growth in the United States. Equally significant, and as you've heard in December, we reached an important agreement with our U.S. franchisees. Starting in January, we began an overhaul of our assets, replacing ovens and upgrading in-store technology. From a marketing calendar perspective, we are focused on a balanced approach.
