This begins with premium-priced innovation such as our recent launch of stuffed garlic knots pizza to protect and improve unit level economics. You may also have seen the launch of our $5 flavor menu, the most compelling value menu in the pizza business. In conjunction with our ongoing $6.99 any pairs deal, it will provide our customers with great value on an ongoing basis. We are encouraged by the start of the year at Pizza Hut in the United States, and we believe we have the right strategy going forward. Our international business at Pizza Hut is led by strength in emerging markets but offset by weakness in some of our developed markets. We believe we can apply best practices from the U.S. business to drive growth in these developed markets going forward.
Finally, Taco Bell delivered a fantastic 2015, surpassing $9 billion in system sales, and we expect a solid year in 2016 as well. Taco Bell is on the cutting edge of QSR, and is the industry gold standard for social engagement, product development, brand positioning and advertising. We have several new exciting products launching this year, including one we'll announce during the Super Bowl. So be sure to watch the first half to see the national introduction. Our innovation focus extends beyond just food. We are encouraged by early results of our delivery program and our developing expansion plans for additional cities. The addition of our loyalty program in November builds on our mobile app and will increase brand affinity as it rewards social behavior. Furthermore, we are focused on our core value messaging to drive transactions. We continue to build on our breakfast daypart, where sales are growing at twice the rate of our business as a whole. In fact, we grew breakfast transactions 6% in the fourth quarter. Given the brand's strong economics and broad franchise appeal, we continue to accelerate new unit openings both domestically and internationally, with a record number of U.S. openings in 2015 and expect to build upon this in 2016. I'm particularly excited that we're starting to get some traction expanding the brand internationally. We know this process will take time, but we're making real progress here. Our growth plans, both domestically and internationally, will lay the groundwork for higher operating profit growth in the years to come. With all this progress, you can see why I'm very excited about what's happening in our company. We are undertaking the biggest strategic move in the history of Yum! with our spin of the China business. We're confident this will create 2 large, optimally structured, independent companies with unique investment profiles. Yum! China will target 15% ongoing EPS growth, and its focus is solely on Mainland China and will pay the new Yum! a 3% license fee. New Yum! will become a high-margin global franchise company targeting 15% shareholder return. Recapitalization plans are underway and will be completed in the first half of this year. We see substantial value in our share at current prices as we have repurchased 23 million shares from the announcement of the separation through last night. I want to assure you that while the spin-off transaction is critically important, we're not going to let it distract us from running the business in China or anywhere else. All 3 of our brands have significant opportunities for growth as they progress along the journey to brand excellence. We expect to achieve 10% constant currency growth in operating profit this year as a company and are setting up 2 separate companies that will lead the restaurant industry going forward.
Yum! is in a unique position. We have 3 iconic brands and are making them even stronger. As you've heard me say before, my goal as CEO is to build 3 global iconic brands that people trust and champion. We are well on our way to achieving this, led by our brand positioning, courageous leadership and committed team members and franchisees. Needless to say there's a lot to be excited about at Yum!, and I could not be more pleased to lead this company into its next phase. Finally, as you all know, this is Pat's last earnings call with Yum!, and I'd like to take this opportunity to thank him for his leadership, his hard work and unwavering drive to raise the bar at Yum!. He will be missed across the organization. As you may have seen in our 8-K filing, we've appointed our current Corporate Controller, Dave Russell, as interim CFO. And I look forward to working with him while we complete our search for a permanent CFO.
And with that, it gives me great pleasure to hand the call over to Pat.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Greg, and good morning, everyone. In my remarks today, I'll cover 3 areas: our fourth quarter results, our outlook for 2016 and an update on the separation of our China business. I, too, am pleased with the overall sales momentum that we demons
componenttext:
Thank you, Greg, and good morning, everyone. In my remarks today, I'll cover 3 areas: our fourth quarter results, our outlook for 2016 and an update on the separation of our China business. I, too, am pleased with the overall sales momentum that we demonstrated in the fourth quarter, where EPS excluding special items grew 11%. Reported EPS growth was considerably higher as last year's fourth quarter included a noncash special item charge related to the impairment of our Little Sheep concept in China. Excluding special items and the impact of foreign exchange, operating profit grew a healthy 17% in the fourth quarter, led by system sales growth of 6% and restaurant margin improvement of over 3 percentage points.
I'll now take you through our results by division, starting with our China business. For the division, overall, same-store sales grew 2% in the fourth quarter. As we preannounced, KFC grew same-store sales 6%, which was sequentially better than Q3 as we expected. We're encouraged by the positive momentum in our KFC China business, particularly as it sustained into the new year. Same-store sales at Pizza Hut Casual Dining, however, have remained sluggish and declined 8% in the fourth quarter. As Greg said, the China team is addressing this matter with urgency, and we will update you on our progress throughout the year. Restaurant margin management continues to be a bright spot in China's performance. For the fourth quarter, China restaurant margins improved more than 4 percentage points versus prior year to 11.4%, helped by sales leverage at KFC and productivity improvements across the division, more than offsetting sales deleverage at Pizza Hut. As a reminder, our fourth quarter is a seasonally low sales period for the China Division, so the absolute restaurant margin tends to be lower at that time of year. Full-year restaurant margin was 15.9% for the division, an improvement of 1 full percentage point. It's not often that you see restaurant margins expand with declining sales, so this highlights the extent of the China team's efforts to improve profitability through cost controls. I'm proud of the team's continued focus on productivity and confident this bodes well for future profit growth in China as same-store sales continue to recover and unlock significant profit leverage in the business. Given our continued strong belief in China's long-term growth potential, and encouraged by continued strong cash paybacks on new units, we opened 743 new restaurants in 2015. And while we are prudently dialing back the pace of new unit developments in 2016, targeting about 600 new restaurant openings, we'd also expect fewer closures this year, so our net new units will be similar to 2015. Our decision to temper the pace of development balances the reality of current market conditions, with the opportunities we have to enter new trade zones and expand our presence in existing ones. We are also making good progress on modernizing our estate. In 2015, we remodeled about 500 restaurants in China, and we plan to remodel about another 550 in 2016. By the end of this year, we will have remodeled our newly built about 45% or nearly half of our China estate in a 3-year period.
Now moving to our global KFC Division, which posted its eighth consecutive quarter of same-store sales growth. System sales growth was especially strong in emerging markets, up 10% led by Russia and Southeast Asia. International developed markets also delivered solid system sales growth, up 6% led by Australia, Japan and Western Europe. And the U.S. recorded its sixth consecutive quarter of same-store sales growth at 3%. Restaurant margins grew 90 basis points to 14.7% in the quarter and improved 150 basis points for the year to nearly 15%. Operating profit grew 7% in the quarter before the impact of foreign currency translation. Adjusting this for the lack of a onetime favorable pension resolution, as well as incremental advertising expense associated with our U.S. acceleration agreement, operating profit grew 11% in the quarter, roughly in line with KFC's ongoing gross model. Importantly, KFC set another new record for international development in 2015 opening 705 new restaurants, demonstrating the power of this global iconic brand. Our global Pizza Hut division delivered 1% same-store sales growth for the quarter, led by 2% same-store sales growth in our U.S. business, which accounts for about half of division system sales. Operating profit improved 6% in constant currency, driven by higher franchise fees and higher restaurant margins, partially offset by an increase in U.S. G&A, including severance and other onetime costs. Restaurant margins actually improved 240 basis points in constant currency for the quarter, driven by same-store sales leverage and commodity deflation. For the year, Pizza Hut opened 429 new international units. While this was below our initial forecast for 2015, we now have a more robust development pipeline and are confident that we'll open at least 525 new international units in 2016. Finally, Taco Bell posted 4% same-store sales growth in the quarter. Restaurant margin improved 3.1 percentage points to 23.7%, raising full-year margins to approximately 22%, a remarkable achievement for this powerhouse brand. Operating profit, however, declined 7% in the fourth quarter due to an expected increase in G&A related to performance-based incentive compensation, strategic growth investments including restaurant technology and international supply chain and other nonrecurring costs. We believe these investments will strengthen the brand and help to sustain positive momentum in the business. As evidence of the onetime nature of these expenses, we actually expect Taco Bell's G&A will decline in 2016. Additionally, we expect restaurant margins to remain above 20% even with our more aggressive push on value. 
On the development front, we opened 276 new stores in 2015. This included 41 units outside the U.S., 4x the number we opened in 2014, demonstrating the progress we're making to ramp up international development. 87% of the division's new restaurants were opened by franchisees, reflecting the attractive investment returns that the Taco Bell brand generates. 
I'd now like to talk about our 2016 outlook. Supported by the results we've seen year-to-date, we continue to expect to deliver operating profit growth of 10% in constant currency this year. And while I won't be providing quarterly guidance, I would like to point out that certain brands are facing hurdles both, prior year lapse and timing of current year expenses which will weigh on first half results. As a consequence, we expect second half operating profit growth will be directionally stronger in the first half. This is consistent with our plans coming into the year, and we remained confident we will achieve our full year operating profit guidance.
Now I'd like to quickly cover off our spin-off plans. We're making good progress and are on track to complete the separation of our China business by the end of this year. A major part of our plan is to optimize the capital structure of Yum! Brands and return $6.2 billion to shareholders prior to the separation through the issuance of new debt. From the time we announced the separation through last night, we repurchased 23 million shares. While our weighted average basic share count for the quarter was $433 million, our basic share count as of February 2, 2016, was $411 million. We see value in repurchasing our shares that we consider to be a discounted price and view this as a prudent use of shareholder capital. 
I'm also happy to report that we're on scheduled to complete our recapitalization in the first half of the year, issuing incremental debt of approximately $5.2 billion and plan to maintain roughly 5x EBITDA leverage going forward. We're now in the process of finalizing the form and timing of this financing. Now I'm sure you've noticed the volatility in the high-yield debt market, particularly within the energy and materials sectors. We'll continue to watch this closely, but we're pleased that the rates on our future debt remain very attractive on a historic basis, and we're full steam ahead with our plans.
So let me wrap things up. 2016 will be an exciting year for Yum! Brands. Not only do we expect to deliver 10% operating profit growth in constant currency, but we're proceeding as expected with the separation of our China Division into an independent publicly traded company. Yum! China will have no external debt, and we'll self-fund the growth capital, while generating significant free cash flow in year 1 and on an ongoing basis. The new Yum! will be a global diversified franchise company with an optimal capital structure. By 2017, we will be 96% franchised with a stable but fast-growing free cash flow stream. I'm pleased I was able to participate in this landmark decision for the company and that we are optimizing shareholder value by creating 2 powerful investment opportunities. I am very confident in both companies' future growth prospects and look forward to their ongoing success.
And with that, I'll open up the call to Q&A.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of John Glass from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of John Glass from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pat, first, can I just follow up on the question -- the comments you made about certain brands are facing certain hurdles in the first half? Are these sales hurdles profit hurdles? Which brands, if you just directionally put us in the right direction, so
componenttext: Pat, first, can I just follow up on the question -- the comments you made about certain brands are facing certain hurdles in the first half? Are these sales hurdles profit hurdles? Which brands, if you just directionally put us in the right direction, so we can model it appropriately.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's just a combination of both sales and spending. Clearly, in the case of Pizza Hut in China, our expectations for the first half are more muted, and we expect their sales recovery to improve in the back half of the year, so that will weigh on the first
componenttext: It's just a combination of both sales and spending. Clearly, in the case of Pizza Hut in China, our expectations for the first half are more muted, and we expect their sales recovery to improve in the back half of the year, so that will weigh on the first half results. At the same time, we have spending in some of our global brand division that will be more heavily concentrated in the first half of the year. And in the second half of the year, we'll be lapping some of the investments that were made in G&A, and so that will contribute to the shape of earnings over the course of the year.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. How much did Pizza Hut China impact the margins this quarter? In other words, is there are a real bifurcation occurring? I assume there is, but maybe you can quantify how much the weight that's Pizza Hut's placing on the margin for C
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. How much did Pizza Hut China impact the margins this quarter? In other words, is there are a real bifurcation occurring? I assume there is, but maybe you can quantify how much the weight that's Pizza Hut's placing on the margin for China. And also, can you just talk about why not -- is this the moment to start developing Pizza Hut delivery more aggressively? Since that seems like there's a huge untapped opportunity, at the same time, there's some issues, obviously, with the dine-in business.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, first, with respect to margins in China, I'm not going to bifurcate by brand, but it is fair to say, and you've seen from the comps that we reported, that the sales performance at Pizza Hut Casual Dining was not as strong as for KFC in China, and tha
componenttext: Yes, first, with respect to margins in China, I'm not going to bifurcate by brand, but it is fair to say, and you've seen from the comps that we reported, that the sales performance at Pizza Hut Casual Dining was not as strong as for KFC in China, and that's largely due to a more significant transaction decline in that business and so that did weigh more heavily on Pizza Hut China margins, in particular. And then with respect to development, you're absolutely right. It's early days for the Pizza Hut delivery business in China, and so we will be picking up the pace of development for that particular concept as we look to temper the pace of development of both KFC and Pizza Hut Casual Dining in 2016.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of David Palmer from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of David Palmer from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the role of value at Pizza Hut China. Could you just give us perhaps a little bit of a retrospective and looking forward about what value means to that brand? Did Pizza Hut China really get away from the five-star dining at three-star p
componenttext: Just a question on the role of value at Pizza Hut China. Could you just give us perhaps a little bit of a retrospective and looking forward about what value means to that brand? Did Pizza Hut China really get away from the five-star dining at three-star prices in recent years, leaving it more vulnerable now? And can you share what you've rolled out so far and the sort of value you might be thinking about for the brand and if you think that's going to be enough to offset the casual dining weakness in the country?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, David. Well, I think first of all, obviously, the macros which have got worse since December, since we're all together in December, and I think we all know that macros impact casual dining more than they impact QSR. So I think there's definitely tha
componenttext: Sure, David. Well, I think first of all, obviously, the macros which have got worse since December, since we're all together in December, and I think we all know that macros impact casual dining more than they impact QSR. So I think there's definitely that issue. I would agree with you that we do not have enough value news to overcome this backdrop. I think we've also -- as we've spoken about on previous calls, there's a lot of discussion around steak and fajitas, and there wasn't as much discussion if you just think around pizzas. And so I think our ability to talk value, but to talk value around pizzas, I think you'll see more of that going forward. So yes, the answer is we've got to focus on the core to strengthen our brand positioning. We've got to target value to increase transactions, such smart value across dayparts. We also have to, I think, improve our in-store experience in order to stay ahead with the competition. And I think the other thing we've got is to be leader in digital, we've got to stay relevant. And I think there's a lot of things that we can do in that market as well. To round out the answer, we've got about 5 value programs in test for Pizza Hut in China. We're starting to see some early encouraging results, but that's going to take us some time to get into the marketplace. And as Pat said, I think you'll see a much better second half than you'll see first half out of Pizza Hut China.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Keith Siegner from UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Keith Siegner from UBS.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two quick questions for you, folks. The first one being, when we look at the success of 3 global brands, particularly here in the U.S. in recent quarters, on both a sales and margin perspective, how should we think about that margin trajectory into this y
componenttext: Two quick questions for you, folks. The first one being, when we look at the success of 3 global brands, particularly here in the U.S. in recent quarters, on both a sales and margin perspective, how should we think about that margin trajectory into this year. We've got easing costs. We've got very intense competition. How do we think about the margins for those 3 segments this year? And then, to follow that up, can you give us an update on the plans to refranchise those 3 brands, the plan to go from 91% to 95% by the end of '17? How is that progressing? And maybe to some extent, how does the success of those brands recently impact that refranchising effort?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly, Keith. First, in terms of margin performance of the 3 global brands, bear in mind, our equity ownership in those 3 global brand businesses, I think, collectively, is in the order of 10%, so it's a franchise-driven business. But nonetheless, we
componenttext: Certainly, Keith. First, in terms of margin performance of the 3 global brands, bear in mind, our equity ownership in those 3 global brand businesses, I think, collectively, is in the order of 10%, so it's a franchise-driven business. But nonetheless, we do focus on restaurant margins above -- for the benefit of our company estate and importantly, to ensure that our franchisees are realizing good returns on their investment. I would say, overall, we're pleased with the progress we're making on margins for our KFC global division to improve about 1 percentage point versus last year. It was quite a significant accomplishment, a combination of same-store sales growth and productivity improvements contributing to that. At Pizza Hut, equally happy with the progress we've made this year, to your point, supported by commodity deflation as well as in the last quarter, some sales growth. And then for Taco Bell, another banner year, with restaurant margins on a full-year basis, around 22%. As we build on that momentum into next year, we are expecting our KFC and our Pizza Hut businesses to continue to realize margin improvement, aided by same-store sales leverage as well as a more modest commodity outlook than we've seen in some years before. In the case of Taco Bell, my expectation is that margins will be above 20%, perhaps a bit below where they were in this year because of the more aggressive push on value and a more tempered approach to pricing. And then in terms of the refranchising the teams are very much committed to realizing the objectives that we laid out to achieve 96% franchise ownership by the end of 2017. In the last 30 days, Greg and I had met with each one of the global brand divisions to review the refranchising plans, and there are very discreet plans around specific geographies and pacing associated with that. Given the complexity of some of these transactions, we expect the re-franchising activity will be more heavily concentrated in 2017.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I just add a point on the brands? I just want to build on the point, Keith, you asked. What I'm really excited about, and I just was in Southeast Asia in January, is that the global -- the positioning for the 3 global brands is really starting to be -
componenttext: Can I just add a point on the brands? I just want to build on the point, Keith, you asked. What I'm really excited about, and I just was in Southeast Asia in January, is that the global -- the positioning for the 3 global brands is really starting to be -- I'm starting to see it on a global basis. So whether it's Always Original at KFC, whether it's this whole idea of -- that we need to make it easier to get better at Pizza Hut and obviously, live a mark at Taco Bell, I happened to be in Thailand and -- less than 2 months after, we've sort of rolled out we need to make it easier to get better at Pizza Hut. I'm in Bangkok and I'm seeing really focused plans about what we have to do to get better and what we have to do to make it easy. So I think the thing I'm really encouraged about is now that we've got these positioning clear for the 3 brands, if the pace with which I'm seeing that appear in the markets, in the 126 countries that we operate, that's giving me encouragement that we can continue to drive same-store sales growth going forward.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Diane Geissler from CLSA.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Diane Geissler from CLSA.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had a question on the new unit development, maybe just more clarification. So when we think about the units that you're opening in China this year, can you give us a breakdown between KFC and Pizza Hut? And then, is the Pizza Hut slowdown just, in
componenttext: I just had a question on the new unit development, maybe just more clarification. So when we think about the units that you're opening in China this year, can you give us a breakdown between KFC and Pizza Hut? And then, is the Pizza Hut slowdown just, in your mind, temporary or is it more a shift from actual dine-in to delivery units?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly, Diane. When we look at the 740-or-so that we opened this year, about 350 were at KFC, 280 at Pizza Hut Casual Dining, and the balance, split between Pizza Hut Home Service and Little Sheep. When we look out to 2016 and our expectation of around
componenttext: Certainly, Diane. When we look at the 740-or-so that we opened this year, about 350 were at KFC, 280 at Pizza Hut Casual Dining, and the balance, split between Pizza Hut Home Service and Little Sheep. When we look out to 2016 and our expectation of around 600 new unit openings, that's about a 20% reduction. That about 20% reduction applies almost equally to KFC and to Pizza Hut. So we are looking at a deceleration, the pace of development for both KFC and for Pizza Hut Casual Dining. And we don't expect that, that is an indication of how things are going to play out in much longer term. It's just that as I mentioned in my prepared remarks earlier, given current market conditions, we feel that it's prudent to dial back a bit, but we continue to be very confident in the value that we will create from these investments as we're continuing to see cash paybacks of around 3 years, and we know the long term growth potential of the market remains significant. So we do expect that at some point in time, the pace of development will increase for all brands.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the discussions that I've been having with Micky are really around, we still see 20,000-plus restaurants on the horizon as an opportunity. I think that we still believe in the growth story in China, the consuming class. Yes, the economics are not
componenttext: I think the discussions that I've been having with Micky are really around, we still see 20,000-plus restaurants on the horizon as an opportunity. I think that we still believe in the growth story in China, the consuming class. Yes, the economics are not what they used to be, but it's still better than most other places in the world. And I think as we get these brands clearly positioned and we get back to doing the things that we've spoken about that we need to do, I think, long term, we remain still committed that this is, at least in what I will call my horizon, a 20,000 restaurant unit opportunity for the China business.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Karen Holthouse from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Karen Holthouse from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was surprised to see a tick-down into your conference in emerging markets at KFC and a little bit more material at Pizza Hut, particularly your commentary about strength in Russia, strength in Eastern Europe. I'm curious if there's any particular region
componenttext: I was surprised to see a tick-down into your conference in emerging markets at KFC and a little bit more material at Pizza Hut, particularly your commentary about strength in Russia, strength in Eastern Europe. I'm curious if there's any particular regions of the world you would point to that are causing a little bit of softness there, and what might be causing that.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Karen, what I would highlight for both KFC and for Pizza Hut in terms of emerging markets, which remains strong, overall, given what we're seeing by way of system sales growth is that the same-store sales growth has probably been a bit below our expectati
componenttext: Karen, what I would highlight for both KFC and for Pizza Hut in terms of emerging markets, which remains strong, overall, given what we're seeing by way of system sales growth is that the same-store sales growth has probably been a bit below our expectations for some of the emerging markets in Southeast Asia.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Bernstein from Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Bernstein from Barclays.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, just 2 restaurant margin questions. One in China. Pat, I think you've said, for this full year, it was 15.9% plus 100 basis points, and that was quite impressive, considering the sales declines. So as we think about 2016 and you talked about 2%
componenttext: Actually, just 2 restaurant margin questions. One in China. Pat, I think you've said, for this full year, it was 15.9% plus 100 basis points, and that was quite impressive, considering the sales declines. So as we think about 2016 and you talked about 2% to 3% comp growth, I'm wondering why perhaps the guidance, I think you had mentioned in the past, maybe 15% plus margin in '16, wondering why it wouldn't be significantly higher if presumably, you do those positive comps, and maybe you can offer some food and labor commentary. And then kind of a similar question on Taco Bell. I think you said greater than 20% margin in '16 but down from '15. It sounds like there's a big value push, perhaps, coming. So I'm wondering if you guys can just talk a little bit about the category, with a little bit discounting going on, it seems to have intensified of late and whether Taco Bell's well positioned to respond to that.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly. And we'll start with China. We finished the year, from a margin perspective, in China stronger than we have expected. And so our current expectation is that margins in 2016 will be about in line with 2015, so around 16%. As you mentioned, we're
componenttext: Certainly. And we'll start with China. We finished the year, from a margin perspective, in China stronger than we have expected. And so our current expectation is that margins in 2016 will be about in line with 2015, so around 16%. As you mentioned, we're expecting to realize some benefit from same-store sales growth, but we are taking, I would say, a more tempered approach to pricing, given the focus on value as the team's emphasis is on building transactions, building healthy transactions. And so that may mean that we wouldn't take pricing that we might have in the past to fully offset inflation. And we would be much happier with an outcome where we would build transactions with flat margins as opposed to growing margins. And so that's the outlook for China. As it relates to Taco Bell, I would say things are a little bit similar in the sense that the emphasis will be on value to build on the great momentum we had in 2015. We are expecting modest inflation, I would say, probably more than we've realized historically in the labor category for our company stores, where we're anticipating there could be some movement in wage rates, and I would say a modest outlook on commodity inflation for the Taco Bell business.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, let me just talk about the whole question about value. I think the great thing is that Taco Bell is incredibly well positioned, it remains the value leader. Look, we've all seen what's been happening in the marketplace in the early year: 5 for 4, 4
componenttext: Jeff, let me just talk about the whole question about value. I think the great thing is that Taco Bell is incredibly well positioned, it remains the value leader. Look, we've all seen what's been happening in the marketplace in the early year: 5 for 4, 4 for 4, 2 for 2. So let's not kid ourselves. There's been a fair amount of value initiatives out there. So as you would expect from a well-positioned brand, they're back looking at the calendar. I think you'll see some changes that will come out. Obviously, we've got this great new product launch coming out on Sunday, so I think that will have a positive impact on the brand. But they'll do the right things, and I'll make sure that they continue to be well positioned and the value leader in the marketplace, going forward. That's what you expect great brands to do.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Bittner from Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Bittner from Oppenheimer.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2 questions. First is on China, kind of following up. In the Fourth quarter, you did have great margin leverage again and operating profit growth of almost 200% on a 2% comp, and you're expecting similar comps going forward as you head into fourth
componenttext: I have 2 questions. First is on China, kind of following up. In the Fourth quarter, you did have great margin leverage again and operating profit growth of almost 200% on a 2% comp, and you're expecting similar comps going forward as you head into fourth quarter. So can you just talk again a little bit more about what investments are being made in China that are going to keep the margin and profit growth more in check as your guidance kind of suggests? And then I do have a follow-up.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, first, in terms of China margin for 2016, as i mentioned, there will be much stronger emphasis on value in order to stimulate traffic. And as a consequence, we're not necessarily expecting that pricing will fully offset inflation. What we're ex
componenttext: Yes, well, first, in terms of China margin for 2016, as i mentioned, there will be much stronger emphasis on value in order to stimulate traffic. And as a consequence, we're not necessarily expecting that pricing will fully offset inflation. What we're expecting by way of inflation in 2016 is about 1% for food and high single digits for labor. But again, we're not expecting to fully offset that through pricing as may be has been our past practice as a team, as we're focusing on building transactions. And we are counting on continued productivity improvements, but probably not the heroic improvements that we've seen in years past. If we do better than 2% to 3% comps in 2016, we would expect margin to improve, but we're not planning for that right now. The other variable, though, is labor efficiency because the team, let's face it, has consistently surprised us with the upside, and that can provide a further tailwind to China margins in 2016. We think, at this stage, guiding about flat margins year-over-year is appropriate.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes sense. And then the second question, just on the pending recap that you expect to be completed here in the first half. You said at the Investor Day that you're targeting kind of a 5 1/4% blended interest rate. Is that still an unachievable targ
componenttext: That makes sense. And then the second question, just on the pending recap that you expect to be completed here in the first half. You said at the Investor Day that you're targeting kind of a 5 1/4% blended interest rate. Is that still an unachievable target -- targeted rate as you kind of stand here today?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, it's Larry Gathof. As Pat mentioned, the markets have been very volatile and spreads definitely have widened across the market. That said, there's a lot of bifurcation in the market. The good credits are still getting done at a fairly good and attr
componenttext: Brian, it's Larry Gathof. As Pat mentioned, the markets have been very volatile and spreads definitely have widened across the market. That said, there's a lot of bifurcation in the market. The good credits are still getting done at a fairly good and attractive rates, especially on historic basis. So it really depends on exactly what we execute and we're evaluating and doing some specifics around both the tenure tender of the debt and the types of debt we put out there. So the 5 1/4%, I'd say, was still in the game. But it's probably 5 1/4% or plus, not on the lower end of that at this point.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Brian, that 5 1/4% that we referenced was for the entire debt portfolio of Yum!, not just the incremental debt. So I just want to make that clear.
componenttext: And Brian, that 5 1/4% that we referenced was for the entire debt portfolio of Yum!, not just the incremental debt. So I just want to make that clear.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of John Ivankoe from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of John Ivankoe from JPMorgan.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on China margins. Obviously, you guys were happy with margins, given the comps in 2015. You're happy with the levels in the fourth quarter as well. But the question has to continue to be asked and certainly we've been asking it for the last cou
componenttext: A question on China margins. Obviously, you guys were happy with margins, given the comps in 2015. You're happy with the levels in the fourth quarter as well. But the question has to continue to be asked and certainly we've been asking it for the last couple of years. To what extent that attention to cost controls, labor efficiency, other OpEx efficiency, what have you, have actually, in some way, contributed to the lack of traffic recovery that you guys have consistently expected. So I just wanted to see whenever you research your information anything, qualitative, quantitative that you may have to make everyone comfortable that you haven't gone too far. And in that context, some of the guidance on China margins in 2016 is admission that there are no more structural cost cuts or tactical cost cuts that exist within the China system, and that margins are really now going to be a function of comps.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, let me start with that one. I'll take that. I think the -- certainly, the customer metrics -- certainly, on KFC, the customer metrics are now back pre the incident. So I think it doesn't matter what metrics you look at. I would say all of those metr
componenttext: John, let me start with that one. I'll take that. I think the -- certainly, the customer metrics -- certainly, on KFC, the customer metrics are now back pre the incident. So I think it doesn't matter what metrics you look at. I would say all of those metrics are, obviously, way back. In an absolute sense, the Pizza Hut metrics are actually higher than the KFC metrics, probably had a -- regained as much momentum, but they're, on an absolute sense, higher. I think the other thing, just to address your question, there's a lot of work being done on menu simplification as well. And so I think what we've got to do is, obviously, besides looking at labor and other cost that go into it, how do we simplify the menu so that we make it easier for the customer to speed up the experience. In KFC's case or in Pizza Hut's case, I think, really deliver the best casual dining in-store experience in order to stay ahead. So there's a number of initiatives around simplified menu boards, box meals, to make it actually easier for the customer to order rather than standing in queue and lining up. So we're spending a lot of time making sure that the margin improvements do not impact the customer experience. And all of the evidence that I can see suggests that there is no impact on the customer experience, and Micky has bit between the teeth on improving the speed of service, particularly in KFC, and there's a number of initiatives in place that I think will actually enhance that experience, enhance throughput and, obviously, lead to sales and transaction growth.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And john, what I would add to what Greg has said is that we continue to believe that long term, 20% is an appropriate margin target for the China business. And you have to think about that in the context of where average unit volumes are today, and we kno
componenttext: And john, what I would add to what Greg has said is that we continue to believe that long term, 20% is an appropriate margin target for the China business. And you have to think about that in the context of where average unit volumes are today, and we know they can go. We're not putting a time frame on it, but we know there's enormous profit leverage in the business, given all the productivity gains that have been made in the last 2 to 3 years and that as the same-store sales continue to recover, we'll see significant margin improvement. To your point, that is up from comps. But I also wouldn't underestimate the opportunity for the China team to continue to realize some structural improvements in the business. They've consistently delivered well beyond our expectations, they have enormous capability, and I think the next leg of productivity improvement in the restaurants will be unlocked by technology. And it's fair to say that the digital capabilities of our China business are the best that we have in our entire company, and we're all very excited about how that's going to transform the customer experience. And that will unlock further productivity opportunity in our restaurants and contribute to that margin, over time.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Tarantino from Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Tarantino from Robert W. Baird.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is on the Pizza Hut business in China, and I know this might be a hard question to answer. But I was wondering if there's any way you can sort of dissect how much of the comps weakness you've seen recently is more related to macro issues versu
componenttext: My question is on the Pizza Hut business in China, and I know this might be a hard question to answer. But I was wondering if there's any way you can sort of dissect how much of the comps weakness you've seen recently is more related to macro issues versus internal issues? And I guess, said differently, is there any benchmark within that market that you're looking at that would say you're underperforming or overperforming relative to the industry there? And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, David, let me take that one. We don't have, obviously, the sort of information we had in the U.S., that Crest and NPD data, to try and get the specifics that you're asking. But I think we all know, and we've seen this not just in China but outside,
componenttext: Okay, David, let me take that one. We don't have, obviously, the sort of information we had in the U.S., that Crest and NPD data, to try and get the specifics that you're asking. But I think we all know, and we've seen this not just in China but outside, that casual dining is impacted by macros. It's just what happens. And it always has a bigger impact on casual dining when macros are volatile and changing than it does on the QSR business. So if I was to say what are the 4 factors, I would say macros. I think the second one would be we do not have enough value news in order to overcome this sort of macro backdrop, which is why we've got a number of macro tests in the marketplace right now. And obviously, with a sense of urgency, we need to get these tests into the marketplace. I think there is definitely competition, there's definitely more competition in the marketplace. I don't think a lot of this competition is going to try and scale up on a sort of broad scale like the Pizza Hut is. And then I think the last point or factor, I think would be aggregators, but that's a small percentage of total sales. So I would say, it's macros, its value, it's competition and it's aggregators. That would be -- I can't put a percentage on for you. I know you'd like it, but those would be the 4 factors. And that's why our response has to be focused on the core, to strengthen the brand positioning, target value-increased transactions, deliver the best in-store dining experience and then leading digital, as Pat said, whether it's free WiFi, queue ticketing, pre-ordering and then partnerships with people like Alipay and WeChat to drive cashless payment, as well as the loyalty program. So that's the things we're doing in response to the 4 things we see driving the sort of, I guess, the performance were not happy with Pizza Hut China.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess the follow-up to that -- that's very helpful. But the follow-up is if it is -- ends up being mostly macro, it seems like you're swimming into a pretty stiff current on some of those. How much contingency have you built into the plan if the Piz
componenttext: And I guess the follow-up to that -- that's very helpful. But the follow-up is if it is -- ends up being mostly macro, it seems like you're swimming into a pretty stiff current on some of those. How much contingency have you built into the plan if the Pizza Hut business doesn't stabilize as you expect in the second half?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, there's 2 things. First of all, we do have a number of tests. So I don't want anyone to go away thinking that we haven't developed a number of tests on those. Now I think the difference between KFC and Pizza Hut is in KFC, we can draw unpro
componenttext: Well, I think, there's 2 things. First of all, we do have a number of tests. So I don't want anyone to go away thinking that we haven't developed a number of tests on those. Now I think the difference between KFC and Pizza Hut is in KFC, we can draw unproven ideas from the other 100 countries we've got KFC. There's less opportunity to do that, but I can assure you that Micky and the team are really focused on what I would call these value platforms being tested and, obviously, what we're trying those sales impacts, we need to see positive sales impacts. And I think some of the early-day test result suggests we've seen impacts in these tests somewhere between plus 1% to plus 75. So we still got a long way to go. We've got to get them into the real world, but I am at least optimistic with what I'm seeing in the tests. But this is a hard slog. This is definitely a lot harder than KFC in China. We're going to have to work really hard, but we've got the right team in order to come up with the right ideas to overcome all the barriers that either macros or competitors put in our way.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Karen Short from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Karen Short from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple of questions on Pizza Hut. I guess your U.S. comps seem to come in at the low end of expectations, at least as you stated at your December Analyst Day. International is a little uninspiring. So first question is any color as to why. And then I
componenttext: So a couple of questions on Pizza Hut. I guess your U.S. comps seem to come in at the low end of expectations, at least as you stated at your December Analyst Day. International is a little uninspiring. So first question is any color as to why. And then I guess 2 related questions would be, you outlined the path to achieving a 3% comp at Pizza Hut in the Analyst Day, with various initiatives, but it seems a little optimistic on a blended basis. And then the last portion of the question is, is there any way to accelerate the common POS conversion because, I guess, it seems like 1 common system might really be the backbone that you'd need before comps can really re-accelerate.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me start with the U.S. comps. It wasn't our best quarter in 3 years, and I agree. It doesn't -- it sort of pales with the KFC 2-year comps at 8% and Taco Bell at 10%. But it wasn't our best quarter in 3 years. And as I indicated in my prepared r
componenttext: Okay. Let me start with the U.S. comps. It wasn't our best quarter in 3 years, and I agree. It doesn't -- it sort of pales with the KFC 2-year comps at 8% and Taco Bell at 10%. But it wasn't our best quarter in 3 years. And as I indicated in my prepared remarks, I'm very encouraged by the stock for 2016 for Pizza Hut. And what I'm encouraged about is how rapidly this whole idea that we need to make it easier to get better is going around the world. I know that in the past, if I had turned up in Bangkok 2 months after we came up with an insight of easy beats better, I probably would not have seen that being impacted or reflected in the work either to make this better or make it easier. So I'm encouraged by the start of Pizza Hut in 2016. I have confidence that you'll see us deliver sequential improvement in same-store sales this quarter versus the fourth quarter. And every journey has to start somewhere, and I think that journey started in the fourth quarter of 2015. And then I am encouraged by how rapidly we are taking this idea and seeing it now being impacted and addressed by all of our teams around the world.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Karen, as to your question regarding the common POS, the team estimates it will take a couple of years to migrate all of the restaurants in the U.S. to a common platform, so they're targeting end of 2017 to accomplish that. It is a high priority
componenttext: And then Karen, as to your question regarding the common POS, the team estimates it will take a couple of years to migrate all of the restaurants in the U.S. to a common platform, so they're targeting end of 2017 to accomplish that. It is a high priority but given the extent of integration between those different POS systems and back-house and other applications, it will take some time in order to do it properly and minimize disruption to our business.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jason West from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jason West from Credit Suisse.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 separate questions. One, can you break out in the China comp for the quarter kind of where you are on pricing and then, I guess, if mix was meaningful there as well. And then separately, Pat, now that we're a little closer to the leverage event, do
componenttext: Just 2 separate questions. One, can you break out in the China comp for the quarter kind of where you are on pricing and then, I guess, if mix was meaningful there as well. And then separately, Pat, now that we're a little closer to the leverage event, do you have any updates about you're thinking about use of proceeds? Would you lean more on an accelerated share repurchase? Are you also considering a special dividend or more of a gradual buyback?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly. In terms of the China comp for the fourth quarter, the 2% increase reflected 4% benefit from pricing. And then we also had a positive benefit impact of mix, sales mix. And then that was offset by some transaction decline in getting to the 2% co
componenttext: Certainly. In terms of the China comp for the fourth quarter, the 2% increase reflected 4% benefit from pricing. And then we also had a positive benefit impact of mix, sales mix. And then that was offset by some transaction decline in getting to the 2% comp. With respect to our leverage event and use of proceeds, as you know, a lot of it comes down to valuation and where things are at, at the time. So it's early to say exactly how we're going to be returning the cash.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Andrew Charles from Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Andrew Charles from Cowen and Company.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pat, just a quick housekeeping. Can you give us the puts and takes on China margins this quarter? And then separately, as China food costs continue to be quite favorable, I know there's a little bit of inflation for next year as well as some more resilien
componenttext: Pat, just a quick housekeeping. Can you give us the puts and takes on China margins this quarter? And then separately, as China food costs continue to be quite favorable, I know there's a little bit of inflation for next year as well as some more resilient pricing, should we expect you to sacrifice the favorability for traffic in order to more aggressively pursue value in 2016, both the China brands relative to the promotions you ran in 4Q?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Andrew. First, in terms of the drivers of Q4 margin, we were very pleased with the performance in the quarter. Margins were up versus prior year about 4.5 percentage points, and here's how it breaks down. When you take the 4% pricing, add to it the
componenttext: Okay, Andrew. First, in terms of the drivers of Q4 margin, we were very pleased with the performance in the quarter. Margins were up versus prior year about 4.5 percentage points, and here's how it breaks down. When you take the 4% pricing, add to it the mix benefit, and strip off the impact of the transaction decline, that's about a net 2-point benefit. On top of that, we had a 3-point benefit from productivity and another 1 point benefit from closed stores. Offsetting that was 1.5 margin attributable to inflation. Commodities were flat but we had 6% inflation on labor. And so that's basically the walk to the 4.5-point gain in margin versus the prior year. In terms of how we're thinking about 2016, as I mentioned before, the team is very much focused on building transactions. So while we do expect some modest inflation from a commodity perspective, up about 1% and high single digits for labor, we're not planning to take pricing to entirely offset that. We will look to some ongoing productivity improvements to help mitigate the impact of inflation. But the goal is to at least maintain margin year-over-year at around 16% and to achieve meaningful improvement in transactions.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So essentially, food costs should be flat, then, within that construct?
componenttext: So essentially, food costs should be flat, then, within that construct?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, we thought it would be about 1 point of inflation from a commodity standpoint for the year, now that you're asking 2016. .
componenttext: Andrew, we thought it would be about 1 point of inflation from a commodity standpoint for the year, now that you're asking 2016. .

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of Jeff Farmer from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Jeff Farmer from Wells Fargo.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a single follow-up on a handful of earlier questions. I believe it was at your December Analyst Meeting, you noted that Pizza Hut Casual Dining is listed with several of the online aggregators. I think you said the sales mix coming from those channel
componenttext: Just a single follow-up on a handful of earlier questions. I believe it was at your December Analyst Meeting, you noted that Pizza Hut Casual Dining is listed with several of the online aggregators. I think you said the sales mix coming from those channels is something less than 5% mix. I'm just curious, do you expect that sales mix to grow? And then more broadly ad more importantly, what's the longer-term strategy with those aggregators as you move forward and maybe potentially become a little bit more powerful?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, I think to answer your question, they're still low with the percentage of the sales mix, I think, in Q4. I think at KFC, they're about 2% of total sales. I think Pizza Hut Casual Dining was about 2% of total sales. I think Pizza Hut Home Service is
componenttext: Jeff, I think to answer your question, they're still low with the percentage of the sales mix, I think, in Q4. I think at KFC, they're about 2% of total sales. I think Pizza Hut Casual Dining was about 2% of total sales. I think Pizza Hut Home Service is about 30% of total sales, but obviously, it's a small part of the pizza business. Yes, we are obviously working with these aggregators and we continue to participate with them. I think I would like to say they are now turned, so we don't lose the customer data or erode our brands. So I think that's the critical part of the relationship is that the aggregators like working with big brands like us, and we like, obviously not -- making sure we keep our customer data and we make sure that we keep our brand positioning really clear in this marketplace.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one final question. In terms of just gauging momentum, I know it's hard to do across multiple concepts. But is it just still building or are you getting the sort of a tipping point or maybe it's gotten about as far -- gone about as far as it's go
componenttext: And just one final question. In terms of just gauging momentum, I know it's hard to do across multiple concepts. But is it just still building or are you getting the sort of a tipping point or maybe it's gotten about as far -- gone about as far as it's going to go, and then maybe it sort of settles back down as we get deeper into '16 and 2017? Or then, really, is this still continuing to be a building competitive issue as you move forward?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mean aggregators?
componenttext: You mean aggregators?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, look, I think, as I said, the 4 factors that's impacting our business when I spoke about earlier, I think for Pizza Hut, which were macros, value, competition and aggregators. I think they are the 4. I think they'll probably stay the 4. I think our a
componenttext: Yes, look, I think, as I said, the 4 factors that's impacting our business when I spoke about earlier, I think for Pizza Hut, which were macros, value, competition and aggregators. I think they are the 4. I think they'll probably stay the 4. I think our ability to deliver new value news in the marketplace will be a much greater driver of our improved performance, and I see much growth with that. It will continue to grow. I'm not suggesting it won't continue to grow, but I think that because we have strong brands, and the aggregators want to work with us as strong brands, I think that puts us in a more driver's seat in terms of how we play with them versus the small guys, who I think the aggregators will have different terms and arrangements with. So I feel good about where we are. I can tell you that the China team is all over it. Micky is very well versed. He has definitely met with the aggregators personally. So we're watching this. It will grow. But I think that growth and value will be, in the short term, more important for us to address.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You next question comes from the line of RJ Hottovy from Morningstar.
componenttext: You next question comes from the line of RJ Hottovy from Morningstar.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a technology question. During the prepared remarks, you said you were pleased with the level of mobile engagement at the Taco Bell brand and the deliveries that may come out of that. I just wonder if you had any additional color on that and kind of
componenttext: I had a technology question. During the prepared remarks, you said you were pleased with the level of mobile engagement at the Taco Bell brand and the deliveries that may come out of that. I just wonder if you had any additional color on that and kind of the quantitative measures that we might be able to look at. And then secondly, any kind of takeaways or learnings you can apply to either the rest of the U.S. or potentially, on a global basis from those technology endeavors?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say that we're very pleased with the progress we're making on the digital front at Taco Bell. You'll recall that we launched our Taco Bell app in the fourth quarter of 2014. Today, we have about 5 million app downloads. When we look at the be
componenttext: Yes, I would say that we're very pleased with the progress we're making on the digital front at Taco Bell. You'll recall that we launched our Taco Bell app in the fourth quarter of 2014. Today, we have about 5 million app downloads. When we look at the behavior of those customers who were ordering through the app, the average check is higher by about 30%. So we're very much encouraged by those early results. We're looking to build awareness of the app to drive utilization, and an important part of that is the introduction of a loyalty component to the app, a game that was launched in late 2015. It's the first loyalty program of its kind that rewards social behavior. And the first reward that was offered for customers who played the game was a free Taco Bell freeze, so there was a lot of excitement around that. The app is also configured in the way the drives exploration of the menu. So it's helped to create a lot of buzz and a lot active engagement with our heavy users, very high levels of social sharing of the rewards we've observed, and the overall user response has been very positive. So the focus now is having to launch the app and more recently, the loyalty program is to drive awareness, and so we do expect to see even greater trial in the coming months. The goal, as you know, for Taco Bell is to strengthen its position as an on-demand brand. And so leveraging technology to do that is an important part of the brand's priority going forward.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, what I really love about it is the customization that's going on. We recently just got certified by the American Vegetarian Association for Taco Bell. And we can highlight -- we probably can't run an ad on TV to highlight that, but using the app,
componenttext: I mean, what I really love about it is the customization that's going on. We recently just got certified by the American Vegetarian Association for Taco Bell. And we can highlight -- we probably can't run an ad on TV to highlight that, but using the app, we can. And it's really interesting to see that we're actually getting people customized out of beef and into beans as their protein. And from a margin point of view, that's really good for us, but it also makes the customer happy. So what I love is that we can use the mobile app as a vehicle to actually talk, I guess, a more discrete story about the brand. It's a great story, it's a good story, but something we wouldn't traditionally do on mainstream TV. But we can use this to sort of get that message out, and that's making the brand more relevant and making any brand more relevant is the name of the game.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Westra from Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Westra from Stifel.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two quick ones. One more on China, I was wondering if you could give us a general sales trends update on maybe where you saw some weaknesses or some strength by tiers or geographies or perhaps, locations. And then second, at Taco Bell, I was wondering if
componenttext: Two quick ones. One more on China, I was wondering if you could give us a general sales trends update on maybe where you saw some weaknesses or some strength by tiers or geographies or perhaps, locations. And then second, at Taco Bell, I was wondering if you can give us a little bit more color on those G&A investments, what were they exactly. And can you confirm that the majority of this year-over-year spike in G&A at Taco Bell was of onetime nature, which you alluded to?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly, Paul. So first, on China, same-store sales, similar to recent quarters, performance was stronger in Tier 1 cities for both brands. Our view is that customers in lower-tier cities have been more significantly impacted by the softening economy, p
componenttext: Certainly, Paul. So first, on China, same-store sales, similar to recent quarters, performance was stronger in Tier 1 cities for both brands. Our view is that customers in lower-tier cities have been more significantly impacted by the softening economy, particularly around the industrial cities, which have been more heavily affected by China's slowing trade. But that's the only meaningful difference, really, to call out. And then as it relates to the Taco Bell G&A, as we mentioned, the increase in the fourth quarter was expected. And it's fair to characterize a large chunk of the incremental G&A as being nonrecurring. So some components would include performance-driven incentive compensation because they have an absolutely blockbuster year, and so they were paid accordingly. We planned for a 100% payout, so that contributes to year-over-year decline as we think about 2016. There were some investments that were made and some strategic growth initiatives. I would highlight international supply chain developments. I would also highlight the digital initiatives like the ones we just talked about, and so that contributed to a spike in the fourth quarter. And importantly, we think about those as investments to sustain the positive momentum of the brand. I think good businesses that are stronger-performing businesses reinvest profit upside to sustain the momentum, and that's exactly what's happened to Taco Bell.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, the way I look at it, look, the new plants that you -- trees that plant and the ones that are growing both need water. You just can't throw water on the new plants. You've got to throw water on the big strong trees to make sure they continue to be
componenttext: I mean, the way I look at it, look, the new plants that you -- trees that plant and the ones that are growing both need water. You just can't throw water on the new plants. You've got to throw water on the big strong trees to make sure they continue to be big, strong and keep growing. That's what I saw with that investment in the fourth quarter. I'm glad we made it. I'm delighted we made it. It was the right thing to do, and you're going to see that in the performance of Taco Bell, going forward.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your last question comes from the line of Joseph Buckley from Bank of America.
componenttext: Your last question comes from the line of Joseph Buckley from Bank of America.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Some more questions on Pizza Hut China. First, you mentioned the smaller-tier markets being hit harder by the macro. The Pizza Hut expansion numbers the last 3 or 4 years have been pretty aggressive. And have you extended the brand into areas where the ec
componenttext: Some more questions on Pizza Hut China. First, you mentioned the smaller-tier markets being hit harder by the macro. The Pizza Hut expansion numbers the last 3 or 4 years have been pretty aggressive. And have you extended the brand into areas where the economic development did not follow, or are there cannibalization issues behind Pizza Hut? And then secondly, on Pizza Hut, I know you mentioned a 20% reduction in expansion will be across both brands. But within Pizza Hut, how will that break down in financial plans for 2016 between home delivery and casual dining?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, I'll address your first -- or your last question, first, Joe, and that is that the slowdown in development is on -- for the Pizza Hut brand is only for the casual dining business, not for the delivery business. And then as it relates to the
componenttext: First of all, I'll address your first -- or your last question, first, Joe, and that is that the slowdown in development is on -- for the Pizza Hut brand is only for the casual dining business, not for the delivery business. And then as it relates to the performance of Pizza Hut across cities, I would not attribute variable performance to development decisions and higher-than-expected cannibalization necessarily. It would be more a function of variable levels of macro pressure across these cities.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just to follow up, then. So the casual dining Pizza Hut expansion will be down much more than 20%, with the difference made up by Pizza Hut home delivery? And what about the sales volume differences there in terms of trying to figure out the growth?
componenttext: Okay. Just to follow up, then. So the casual dining Pizza Hut expansion will be down much more than 20%, with the difference made up by Pizza Hut home delivery? And what about the sales volume differences there in terms of trying to figure out the growth?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now Joe, the 20% -- the approximately 20% applies exclusively to the casual dining business. That's not a composite number for both brands, for both businesses under the Pizza Hut banner.
componenttext: Now Joe, the 20% -- the approximately 20% applies exclusively to the casual dining business. That's not a composite number for both brands, for both businesses under the Pizza Hut banner.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But it's 20% for both KFC and Pizza Hut, or...
componenttext: Okay. But it's 20% for both KFC and Pizza Hut, or...

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: For KFC and for Pizza Hut Casual Dining. We are not slowing down the development of Pizza Hut Home Service.
componenttext: For KFC and for Pizza Hut Casual Dining. We are not slowing down the development of Pizza Hut Home Service.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Will that accelerate the latter?
componenttext: Okay. Will that accelerate the latter?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're expecting it to be at least as much as we developed in 2015.
componenttext: We're expecting it to be at least as much as we developed in 2015.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, I think that wraps it up. I want to thank everyone for being on the call today. Thanks for taking the time to be with us. And I know I said this as well, but I do want to thank Pat. Pat joined Yum! at Taco Bell when I was the CMO, and he was t
componenttext: Okay. Well, I think that wraps it up. I want to thank everyone for being on the call today. Thanks for taking the time to be with us. And I know I said this as well, but I do want to thank Pat. Pat joined Yum! at Taco Bell when I was the CMO, and he was the Head of Strategic Planning. He has been a true friend. He has been a great resource. He has been a great leader, and I want to thank him and I want to wish him and his family all the very best for the future.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks.
componenttext: Thanks.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, everybody.
componenttext: Thanks, everybody.
