It'll  grow. But I think that macros and value will be, in the short term, more important for us to address.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You next question comes from the line of RJ Hottovy from Morningstar.
componenttext: You next question comes from the line of RJ Hottovy from Morningstar.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a technology question. During the prepared remarks, you said you were pleased with the level of mobile engagement at the Taco Bell brand and the deliveries that may have come out of that. I just wonder if you had any additional color on that and kin
componenttext: I had a technology question. During the prepared remarks, you said you were pleased with the level of mobile engagement at the Taco Bell brand and the deliveries that may have come out of that. I just wonder if you had any additional color on that and kind of the quantitative measures that we might be able to look at. And then secondly, any kind of takeaways or learnings you can apply to either the rest of the U.S. or potentially, on a global basis from those technology endeavors?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say that we're very pleased with the progress we're making on the digital front at Taco Bell. You'll recall that we launched our Taco Bell app in the fourth quarter of 2014. To date, we have about 5 million app downloads. When we look at the
componenttext: Yes, I would say that we're very pleased with the progress we're making on the digital front at Taco Bell. You'll recall that we launched our Taco Bell app in the fourth quarter of 2014. To date, we have about 5 million app downloads. When we look at the behavior of those customers who were ordering through the app, the average check is higher by about 30%. So we're very much encouraged by those early results. We're looking to build awareness of the app to drive utilization, and an important part of that is the introduction of a loyalty component to the app, a game that was launched in late 2015. It's the first loyalty program of its kind that rewards social behavior. And the first reward that was offered for customers who played the game was a free Taco Bell freeze, so there was a lot of excitement around that. The app is also configured in a way that drives exploration of the menu. So it's helped to create a lot of buzz and a lot of active engagement with our heavy users, very high levels of social sharing of the rewards we've observed, and the overall user response has been very positive. So the focus now is having to launch the app and more recently, the loyalty program is to drive awareness, and so we do expect to see even greater trial in the coming months. The goal, as you know, for Taco Bell is to strengthen its position as an on-demand brand. And so leveraging technology to do that is an important part of the brand's priority going forward.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, what I really love about it is the customization that's going on. We recently just got certified by the American Vegetarian Association for Taco Bell. And we can highlight that. We probably can't run an ad on TV to highlight that, but using the ap
componenttext: I mean, what I really love about it is the customization that's going on. We recently just got certified by the American Vegetarian Association for Taco Bell. And we can highlight that. We probably can't run an ad on TV to highlight that, but using the app, we can. And it's really interesting to see that we're actually getting people customized out of beef and into beans as a protein. And from a margin point of view, that's really good for us, but it also makes the customer happy. So what I love is that we can use the mobile app as a vehicle to actually talk, I guess, a more discrete story about the brand. It's a great story, it's a good story, but something we wouldn't traditionally do on mainstream TV. But we can use this to sort of get that message out, and that's making the brand more relevant and making any brand more relevant is the name of the game.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Westra from Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Westra from Stifel.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two quick ones. One more on China, I was wondering if you could give us a general sales trends update on maybe where you saw some weaknesses or some strength by tiers or geographies or perhaps, locations. And then second, at Taco Bell, I was wondering if
componenttext: Two quick ones. One more on China, I was wondering if you could give us a general sales trends update on maybe where you saw some weaknesses or some strength by tiers or geographies or perhaps, locations. And then second, at Taco Bell, I was wondering if you can give us a little bit more color on those G&A investments, what were they exactly. And can you confirm that the majority of this year-over-year spike in G&A at Taco Bell was of onetime nature, which you alluded to?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly, Paul. So first, on China, same-store sales, similar to recent quarters, performance was stronger in Tier 1 cities for both brands. Our view is that customers in lower-tier cities have been more significantly impacted by the softening economy, p
componenttext: Certainly, Paul. So first, on China, same-store sales, similar to recent quarters, performance was stronger in Tier 1 cities for both brands. Our view is that customers in lower-tier cities have been more significantly impacted by the softening economy, particularly around the industrial cities, which have been more heavily affected by China's slowing export trade. But that's the only meaningful difference, really, to call out. And then as it relates to  Taco Bell G&A, as we mentioned, the increase in the fourth quarter was expected. And it's fair to characterize a large chunk of the incremental G&A as being nonrecurring. So some components would include performance-driven incentive compensation because they had an absolutely blockbuster year, and so they were paid accordingly. We planned for a 100% payout, so that contributes to a year-over-year decline as we think about 2016. There were some investments that were made in some strategic growth initiatives. I would highlight international supply chain developments. I would also highlight the digital initiatives like the ones we just talked about, and so that contributed to a spike in the fourth quarter. And importantly, we think about those as investments to sustain the positive momentum of the brand. I think good businesses that are strong-performing businesses reinvest profit upside to sustain the momentum, and that's exactly what's happened to Taco Bell.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, the way I look at it, look, the new plants that you -- trees that you plant and the ones that are growing, both need water. You just can't throw water on the new plants. You've got to throw water on the big strong trees to make sure they continue
componenttext: I mean, the way I look at it, look, the new plants that you -- trees that you plant and the ones that are growing, both need water. You just can't throw water on the new plants. You've got to throw water on the big strong trees to make sure they continue to be big, strong and keep growing. That's what I saw  that investment in the fourth quarter as. I'm glad we made it. I'm delighted we made it. It was the right thing to do, and you're going to see that in the performance of Taco Bell going forward.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your last question comes from the line of Joseph Buckley from Bank of America.
componenttext: Your last question comes from the line of Joseph Buckley from Bank of America.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two more questions on Pizza Hut China. First, you mentioned the smaller-tier markets being hit harder by the macro. The Pizza Hut expansion numbers the last 3 or 4 years have been pretty aggressive. And have you extended the brand into areas where the eco
componenttext: Two more questions on Pizza Hut China. First, you mentioned the smaller-tier markets being hit harder by the macro. The Pizza Hut expansion numbers the last 3 or 4 years have been pretty aggressive. And have you extended the brand into areas where the economic development did not follow, or are there cannibalization issues behind Pizza Hut? And then secondly, in Pizza Hut, I know you mentioned a 20% reduction in expansion will be across both brands. But within Pizza Hut, how will that break down in financial plans for 2016 between home delivery and casual dining?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, for -- first of all, I'll address your first -- or your last question first, Joe, and that is that the slowdown in development is on -- for the Pizza Hut brand is only for the casual dining business, not for the delivery business. And then as it rela
componenttext: Yes, for -- first of all, I'll address your first -- or your last question first, Joe, and that is that the slowdown in development is on -- for the Pizza Hut brand is only for the casual dining business, not for the delivery business. And then as it relates to the performance of Pizza Hut across cities, I would not attribute variable performance to development decisions and higher-than-expected cannibalization necessarily. It would be more a function of variable levels of macro pressure across these cities.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Amy, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Yum! Brands First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Steve Schmitt, Vice President of Investor Re
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Amy, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Yum! Brands First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Steve Schmitt, Vice President of Investor Relations and Corporate Strategy, you may begin your conference.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Amy. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. On our call today are Greg Creed, our CEO; and Dave Russell, our interim CFO. Also on today's call is Larry Gathof, Yum!'s Treasurer. And we're very pleased to have Micky Pant, Yum!'s Chin
componenttext:
Thanks, Amy. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. On our call today are Greg Creed, our CEO; and Dave Russell, our interim CFO. Also on today's call is Larry Gathof, Yum!'s Treasurer. And we're very pleased to have Micky Pant, Yum!'s China CEO, on our call as well. Following remarks from Greg and Dave, we'll open up the call for questions for the entire team. Please keep in mind Micky is dialing in from Shanghai, so there could be a slight delay in some of his responses.
Before we get started, I would like to remind you that this conference call includes forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements are subject to future events and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from these statements.
All forward-looking statements should be considered in conjunction with the cautionary statements in our earnings release and the risk factors included in our filings with the SEC. In addition, please refer to the Investors section of the Yum! Brands' website, www.yum.com to find disclosures and reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures that may be used on today's call.
We are broadcasting this conference call via our website. This call is also being recorded and will be available for playback. Please be advised that if you ask a question, it will be included in both our live conference and in any future use of the recording.
We would like to make you aware of the following upcoming Yum! investor event. Our second quarter 2016 earnings will be released on Wednesday, July 13.
Now before I turn the call over to Greg, I would like to bring your attention to 2 items you may have noticed in yesterday's release. First, the new terminology. We reported core operating profit growth of 21% for the first quarter 2016. Core operating profit growth is our operating profit growth year-over-year excluding foreign currency translation and special items. Second, as previously announced, effective January of this year, the company's India business integrated its 3 brands into our global brand divisions. The prior year figures have been restated in the release. 
Now it's my pleasure to hand the call over to Mr. Greg Creed.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased we're off to a strong start in 2016 with better-than-expected core operating profit growth of 21% in the first quarter. This includes 42% growth in our China business due to outstanding Chinese New
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased we're off to a strong start in 2016 with better-than-expected core operating profit growth of 21% in the first quarter. This includes 42% growth in our China business due to outstanding Chinese New Year results at KFC, underscoring the power of the KFC brand in China when we delivered insight-driven marketing that resonates with our customers. 
Companywide, all 4 of our divisions posted positive same-store sales and operating profit growth in constant currency. Furthermore, we are on track to finalize the spin-off of our China business by year-end, creating 2 powerful, independent, focused growth companies. As you saw in our release, we're raising full year core operating growth guidance for Yum! Brands to 12% from 10% previously. Even though it is still early in the year, we are confident about the revised guidance, and we'll update you as the year progresses.
Today, I'll give you an overview of each of our operating division, and then Dave Russell, our interim CFO, will walk you through the financials. 
So first, China. For the China division, same-store sales grew 6%, led by 12% same-store sales growth of KFC. Our KFC business, as a reminder, represents about 75% of our operating profit in China. We saw particular success of KFC during the Chinese New Year with bucket meals, which we tailored across 4 customer groups ranging from kids buckets to larger group meals. As a result, buckets makes a much higher percentage than normally. This lifted average ticket as we focused more on group occasions. And we gained even more consumer insights this year, which would help our business both going forward as well as next new year. Pizza Hut Casual Dining, which represents about 25% of our operating profit in China remained challenging. System sales declined 1%, and same-store sales declined 12% in the quarter. Our tough macro environment and competitive landscape continued to weigh on performance. We're addressing this with urgency but realize our recovery will take time.
So wrapping up in China. We are pleased with our first quarter's overall operating profit growth, which came in well ahead of our expectations. The strong margin performance reinforces our confidence in the future earnings power of this business. When we generate sales growth, profit flow-through is impressive. As Steve mentioned, Micky Pant, our China division CEO, is on the call today and will be happy to assist in answering questions you may have in the China business.
Now turning to our 3 global brands divisions. In our KFC division, same-store sales grew 1% in the first quarter or 5% on a 2-year stack. Operating profit grew 7% in constant currency when adjusting for incremental advertising spend in the the U.S. The division opened 79 new international restaurants in 32 countries. 77% of these units were opened by franchisees, and 71% of our new international openings were in emerging markets. I'm encouraged by our ability to generate growth in both emerging and developed markets. System sales and international developed markets grew 5%, and in international emerging markets grew 8%. I recently visited with the team in Canada and was thrilled to see the assets being upgraded and the marketing position around Always Original. With 6% same-store sales growth in the quarter, I'd say it's working. I'm also pleased to see success in emerging markets, which are our key contributor to KFC's growth story. KFC is our franchise-led emerging powerhouse, and I'm confident the brand's get even stronger and will produce strong growth this year and for many years to come.
Pizza Hut grew same-store sales 3% in the quarter and was led by 5% same-store sales growth in the U.S., which makes up approximately 60% of total sales. Our $5 flavor menu helped drive system transactions with company stores leading the way, up 8% in the quarter. Our discipline around making it easier to get a better pizza is holistic and driving traffic. We are focused on the entire customer experience from ordering, payment and delivery tracking to our assets and menu, and I believe this quarter's results are further testament to our maniacal emphasis on this way of thinking. We are on track to replace over 1300 U.S. ovens in 2016. For those stores replacing older ovens, this should result in average energy savings of 25% in ongoing operational costs and a faster cook time. From a marketing calendar perspective, we are focusing on balancing premium product innovation such as stuffed garlic pizza to protect and improve unit economics with compelling value offerings such as their ongoing $6.99 Any deal. All of this will enable us to provide our customers with a better pizza at great value.
Our international business at Pizza Hut saw system sales growth of 3% in constant currency and a 1% decline in same-store sales in the quarter. Sales were especially strong in Latin America and Canada but offset by weaknesses in Korea, Australia and India. We are committed to offering consistent everyday value to our customers and will leverage proven value strategies across markets with similar characteristics. We have high expectations for the international Pizza Hut business. Over the last 5 years, we have opened 1200 international restaurants, and we will continue to grow this business over time. The bottom line is we have established solid momentum with our strategy in the U.S. especially around the $5 flavor menu. And as we roll this overall strategy internationally, we hope to achieve similar success.
Now turning to Taco Bell. Same-store sales grew 1%, lapping 6% growth a year ago, and operating profit grew 4% in the quarter. Restaurant margins were an impressive 21%. While 1% same-store sales growth is not what we're used to seeing at Taco Bell, the timing of our key launches have an impact on same-store sales growth for the quarter. The Quesalupa, which launched in February, makes it almost 10% and drove a meaningful lift in transactions. We also launched our $1 breakfast menu in March. The $1 price point is consistent with Taco Bell's reputation as the value leader in QSR. Taco Bell's new breakfast $1 value menu differentiates itself from the competitive and puts it at the forefront of value in a growing daypart. We now have 10 $1 items on the breakfast menu and are seeing breakfast sales hold at 8% and transaction growth accelerating. The Taco Bell team is exhibiting great flexibility to reap and reacted the competitive value pressures and adjusted their 2016 promotional calendar accordingly to highlight even more value. Insight-driven innovation, favorable food and breakthrough value such as the upcoming launches of the $1 BB crunch burrito should boost sales and further the brand's momentum.
So we're off to a great start at Yum! Over the past several quarters, we really had 3 businesses that needed dramatic improvement: KFC China, Pizza Hut China and Pizza Hut U.S. I'm pleased that we've been able to turn 2 of these 3 businesses as KFC China and Pizza Hut U.S. are on more solid footing. Now let's be clear: we're not out of the woods on these businesses, but we've made a lot of progress, and we'll continue to focus on delivering better results. As you heard me say before, this is a transformational year for Yum! as we finalize the spin-off of our China business, creating 2 powerful, independent, focused growth companies. Our brand strength, unwavering focus on the customer and innovative food driven by insights will allow us to grow Yum! into an even better global company. This is an exciting time, a pivotal time for our company, and I look forward to what the future holds
And with that, I'll hand the call over to Dave.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg, and good morning, everyone. In my remarks today, I'll cover 3 areas: our first quarter results, our outlook for 2016 and an update on our planned recapitalization and the spin-off of our China business. As Greg mentioned, we are very pleased
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg, and good morning, everyone. In my remarks today, I'll cover 3 areas: our first quarter results, our outlook for 2016 and an update on our planned recapitalization and the spin-off of our China business. As Greg mentioned, we are very pleased with our strong first quarter results where core operating profit increased 21%. EPS before special items grew 19%, including a 5-point negative impact from foreign currency. These results were led by better-than-expected sales in restaurant margins in KFC China. EPS also benefited from a 5% reduction in our diluted share count compared to our first quarter last year due to our significant share buybacks over the past 12 months. 
I'll now take you through our results by divisions, starting with our China business. For the China division overall, same-store sales grew 6% in the quarter. KFC grew same-store sales 12%, which was sequentially better than Q4 and exceeded our expectations as successful Chinese New Year promotion drove results. As Greg said, the KFC brand in China is really powerful delivered insight-driven marketing that resonates with our customers.
Same-store sales of Pizza Hut Casual Dining remain sluggish declining 12% in the quarter. We're working to turn the Pizza Hut business around in a difficult macro and competitive environment.
Restaurant margin improved 3.5 percentage points versus the prior year to 22.4%, helped our sales leverage in KFC and commodity deflation, more than offsetting sales deleveraging at Pizza Hut. While our first quarter is a seasonally higher sales period for the China division, restaurant margins of over 22% give us tremendous confidence in the future earning power of this business. When we deliver solid top line growth, the profits are impressive. One other note on China's first quarter results, we had a leap year benefit that added an additional $6 million [ph] of operating profit Q1 to China's results. However, we pool sales from the leap date out of our same-store sales calculation as the extra day had no impact on reported 6% same-store sales growth. The way reporting here at Yum!, none of our other divisions saw an impact from leap year in Q1. 
Now moving to our global KFC division, which posted its ninth consecutive quarter of same-store sales and profit growth. Emerging and international developed markets each grew comps 1%. U.S. recorded seventh consecutive quarter of same-store sales growth despite overlapping 7% comps in the first quarter of last year. Operating margins improved 30 basis points in constant currency, and core operating profit grew 4% in the quarter. Adjusting for the incremental advertising expense associated with the acceleration agreement we reached with our franchisees in 2015, core operating profit grew 7% in the quarter. As a reminder, the acceleration agreement with our U.S. franchisees, which went into effect during the second quarter of last year, called for us to invest incremental media of $20 million in 2016 as opposed to $10 million last year.
Our global Pizza Hut division delivered 3% same-store sales growth for the quarter, led by 5% same-store sales growth in our U.S. business. Same-store sales growth and lower G&A expenses drove core operating profit growth of 9%. This is the best result we've seen our Pizza Hut U.S. in years, and we believe our strategy is working to drive incremental transactions. I am pleased to see momentum behind the business and believe we can transfer our U.S. earnings to benefit the system globally. Digital continues to grow in importance to our sales, comprising 46% of U.S. delivery and carryout sales, a 3 percentage point increase versus a year ago. On Super Bowl Sunday alone, we took over 500,000 digital orders, representing about 50% of sales along with an all-time record day for the business. With digital orders comes higher levels of and higher average of spend, so we're investing as you would expect. Along those lines, we're making progress in migrating to a single point-of-sale system in the U.S. by the end of 2017, which will allow us to be more nimble as we roll out our digital initiatives going forward.
Finally, Taco Bell faced increased value pressure from the change in the first quarter and posted 1% same-store sales growth. Same-store sales improved throughout the quarter, and we remain confident in achieving 3% same-store sales growth for the year with a stronger second half than first half. Despite the lower-than-expected full quarter sales, operating margin improved 150 basis points to 28%, and operating profit grew 4%. Restaurant margins also improved 150 basis points at 21%, and we expect full year margins to be greater than 20% this year albeit slightly lower than last year. On the development front, we opened 49 new restaurants in the quarter with 90% open [indiscernible] franchisees and licensees. Of our new openings, 7 were international units. We expect to open a record number of Taco Bell units internationally in 2016 as we continue to make progress in building up the unit level economics as we enter the new countries.
I'd now like to shift to our 2016 outlook. With our strong first quarter results and the change in China's tax laws whereby a value-added tax or VAT is replacing the business tax, we are raising our full year core operating profit growth forecast to 12% from 10% for Yum!. For a little bit of background on the VAT. China recently announced a reform to its retail tax which is intended to be a progressive and positive shift to more closely align with a more modern service-based economy. Under this reform, a 6% output VAT would replace the 5% business tax currently applied to certain restaurant sales. Input VAT would be credible to the aforementioned 6% outlook VAT. This change is effective May 1, 2016, so in no way had any impact on their first quarter performance. While it's difficult to estimate the impact of the VAT reform prior to its actual implementation, Yum! China currently expects a positive financial business, further enabling continued investment in the business and creating thousands of additional jobs in China. While we are raising our forecast for core operating profit growth from Yum! from 10% to 12%, we are maintaining our guidance for China same-store sales of 2% to 3% for the full year. From a modeling standpoint, there are 2 other things to bear in mind as you build your forecast. First, the second quarter in China, which is typically our seasonally low quarter happens to be our toughest hurdle of the year of a 2-, 3- and 4-year stack same-store sales base. Second, we have an RGM commission the second quarter that we didn't have last year that we expect to cost around $7 million. It's important for you to know that these factors were fully factored into our initial guidance, and our first half and full year performance is expected to exceed our expectations coming to the year.
All in for Yum!, we can outperform our expectations in the first quarter and are raising our full year guidance to 12% core operating profit growth, including the 53rd week. This takes into account the strong first quarter produced by KFC China, weakness in casual dining and the expected VAT benefit in China in addition to our brand divisions continuing to produce results consistent with our initial 2016 targets. It's early in the year to rate guidance, but we feel confident given where things stand, and we'll update you as the year progresses.
Now I'd like to quickly update you on our spin-off plans. We are on track to complete the spin-off by year-end. We plan on filing our initial Form 10 by early May and conducting comprehensive roadshows ahead of the separation. This spin-off will establish 2 unique investment opportunities and create one of the largest U.S.-listed China retail businesses. Another key aspect of our strategy is to optimize the capital structure of Yum!. Given the significant improvement we've seen recently in the debt markets, we'd like to announce another milestone in our previously indicated plan of targeting company-wide leverage of approximately 5x EBITDA. In early May, we into a new financing facility of at least $2 billion [ph], securitizing Taco Bell U.S. royalties. As a next step in our plan, subsidiaries our Pizza Hut and Taco Bell's businesses excluding the Taco Bell subsidiaries included in the securitization financing are expected to enter into a new senior secured credit facility and issue new high-yield notes. More details will be forthcoming as separate release later today. In line with what we previously communicated, we plan to complete our capitalization and have approximately $9 billion of debt outstanding by the end of the second quarter.
Finally, since we announced in October 2015 our intention to separate the China business, we have bought back 24.7 million shares at an average price of $71, returning a total of $1.8 billion to shareholders excluding dividends. As previously announced, a recap will enable us to complete an additional $4.4 billion return of capital to shareholders. 
So let me wrap things up. I'm pleased to started 2016 off with a strong quarter. We're confident we'll deliver 12% core operating profit for the full year, and we're proceeding as expected with the separation of our China business into an independent publicly traded company. We are working diligently to set up both companies for future success and look forward to updating you on any progress throughout the year. And with that, I'll hand the call back to Greg.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dave. Before we start Q&A, I wanted to provide a brief update in the plans for the China business. You may have seen recent new stories about a sale or a potential strategic investor. I want to assure you that we are fully committed to maximizi
componenttext: Thank you, Dave. Before we start Q&A, I wanted to provide a brief update in the plans for the China business. You may have seen recent new stories about a sale or a potential strategic investor. I want to assure you that we are fully committed to maximizing the value of our China business for the benefit of our shareholders, and we will carefully consider all options to achieve that goal. As you know, we announced in October the careful consideration, we believe that the best way to maximize shareholder value is to spin off our China business by the end of this year, and we are making great progress towards the spin-off. We wouldn't have any further comment on this. And with that, I'll open the call up to Q&A.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes with the line of David Palmer with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes with the line of David Palmer with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fundamental question about China for Micky. Regarding Pizza Hut, what have you done so far, perhaps even through the second quarter to date with regards to the menu and the marketing. I know you wanted to get to that 5-star dining at 3-star prices. Have y
componenttext: Fundamental question about China for Micky. Regarding Pizza Hut, what have you done so far, perhaps even through the second quarter to date with regards to the menu and the marketing. I know you wanted to get to that 5-star dining at 3-star prices. Have you done stuff so far? How is that working? And how has your thinking generally evolved about the timetable for turnaround in the Pizza Hut brand?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll speak slowly. First, on Pizza Hut, I just wanted to say to all of you that it is an extremely strong brand in China. All our consumer metrics, the brand image tracking that we do regularly shows that brand regard, value scores, food scores are very h
componenttext: I'll speak slowly. First, on Pizza Hut, I just wanted to say to all of you that it is an extremely strong brand in China. All our consumer metrics, the brand image tracking that we do regularly shows that brand regard, value scores, food scores are very high as they recovered fully from the crisis that they had a couple of years ago. We opened 280 new Pizza Huts last year, and new unit returns are very good. Over the last 4 years, we've opened 1,000 Pizza Huts dine-in restaurants alone, and we drove off the competition. So it is a very strong brand. It is true that same-store sales have been negative. But in 2015, for example, our system sales were up 10 points, and we do track through in 22 cities and also through publicly reported companies that operate in casual dining here the overall casual dining performance and, it is our understanding that to gain market share. Part of the reason the casual dining sector has been hit, has been due to a decline in consumer confidence. And as we explained in December last year, part of it was on account of the fact that home delivery through aggregators is growing. This latter phenomenon has tapered off a bit on account of burnouts, et cetera. So we fully expect that Pizza Hut will turn a corner. It is a strong brand. Margin performance is good. Sales were kind of minus 1 system sales in the first quarter, but our goal is to get to same-store sales positive. I cannot put a date on it, David, because the market is volatile, but we're doing a number of things. First is that we have shifted the focus back to the core menu with a lot of pizza activity. So we'd have more pizza innovation in the next 6 months than we've had in a long time, and tested very well. The second, I believe, is our value scores are actually good. You can eat lunch at a Pizza Hut just a little more than KFC, so there's no need for any margin compression, but we do need to communicate that value better, which we have started doing. We the brand position significantly, and we've hired one of the best celebrities in China to bring that point home. And lastly, we continue to emphasize customer service for the programs that we presented in September. So with that, I feel much better about Pizza Hut than I did a few months ago but, of course, I'm disappointed that same-store sales are still negative. And I might also remind you, as you know very well, that Pizza Hut is about 25% of our sales and our profits. So one way to look at it is the 3 or [ph] 4 engines that drive the Yum! China business are KFC and KFC performing well, I think we have the ability to Pizza Hut in coming quarters.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Glass with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Glass with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Micky, I'll keep you on the line. On KFC, you talked about the bucket promotion being an essential drivers, so how much of this success in the first quarter was related just to that? And I guess, related, how -- if it was a successful promotion, how much
componenttext: Micky, I'll keep you on the line. On KFC, you talked about the bucket promotion being an essential drivers, so how much of this success in the first quarter was related just to that? And I guess, related, how -- if it was a successful promotion, how much of that sustains going forward? If you can talk about sustainability of those sales, maybe since we're well into April here. And could you also just -- commodities were significantly deflationary this quarter there supposed to be up this year so are you changing your view on commodities or was this just the timing of better commodities in the first quarter but not for the year?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, it's Greg. I'm just going to jump in first and obviously let you provide detail. First, I want to commend Micky and the entire China team for what I think is a fantastic Q1. KFC China delivered 12% same-store sales growth. And as you can see from th
componenttext: John, it's Greg. I'm just going to jump in first and obviously let you provide detail. First, I want to commend Micky and the entire China team for what I think is a fantastic Q1. KFC China delivered 12% same-store sales growth. And as you can see from the 42% growth in our profit, the earnings power of our business is extraordinary when it's working in our favor. And we're very encouraged that we've now had 3 consecutive quarters of same-store sales at KFC China. I think, fortunately, we didn't assume that we don't need heroic numbers like they continued throughout the year to reach out 2016 guidance of 2% to 3% same-store sales growth. And recent history shows that China has been difficult for us to call. So regarding our expectations coming into the year, KFC sales were obviously much better in Q1 than we could've imagined. In Q2, we're closer to where we thought we could be for KFC as we believe that our successful Chinese New Year may have pulled forward some of early Q2 sales into Q1. That said, 6 weeks into the quarter, KFC sells a slightly positive, and we're encouraged with where the business is going, and I'll let Micky speak to that in more detail. And as you know, we know that we still got a lot of to do in Pizza Hut and China. And quarter to date, sales have remained double-digit negative. But again, as Dave mentioned, our Q2 lap for both KFC and Pizza Hut more difficult, especially when you look at these multi-year stacks. We feel great about the start of the year. We're confident in raising our guidance. We still expect China full year China division same-store sales to be in the 2% to 3% range, which is consistent with our expectations. So with that, I'll just let Micky -- I just wanted to compliment Micky and the team for a job well done.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, John, there were some factors unique to Q1, and that has to do with the Chinese New Year. It was the year of the monkey, and we were fortunate that the -- actually not just fortune, but the team at KFC really has hit their stride. So Joy was a ve
componenttext:
I think, John, there were some factors unique to Q1, and that has to do with the Chinese New Year. It was the year of the monkey, and we were fortunate that the -- actually not just fortune, but the team at KFC really has hit their stride. So Joy was a very accomplished retail executive now really understood the rhythm of the KFC business, and they put together a sort of 1, 2, 3 punch around the Chinese New Year, extending it from the traditional 10 days to about 4 weeks, centered around a very powerful bucket promotion but also then with activity afterwards featuring a greater sandwich, which was good thinking because after a heavy Chinese New Year, people are looking for a healthy affair. So that aspect is unique to the Chinese New Year, and I think it's a spectacular successful promotion. Somebody asked me how we level up that next year, and I think the one bit of good news we have is next year is the year of the chicken. So we started work already on the promotions that would be running. But some of the factors that worked in Q1 actually give me encouragement for KFC overall. The first is the success of selling our core products, our fried chicken, hot wings, french fries, hotdogs and all the familiar favorites in China. And we are extending that principle by doing more activity around buckets in the back half of the year and also introducing boxed meals, which are a proven international success where you can buy a fairly -- a good -- just like a little bit more money but significantly more product. As you can imagine, following a very large success in January and February we hit almost record volumes in the amount of chicken that we did sell. And also, that sale was accompanied by corresponding traffic growth. The ticket impact on our sales of plus 12% in Q1 was about 3%. So it wasn't as though the pricing impact. It wasn't as though we took pricing to get there. The price impact is only plus 3. The rest of it is on account of the fact that party sizes for these large buckets are very large. And also, there was a significant increase in the number of items brought per person because the promotion was very well run.
In Q2, we're about halfway through the quarter, but the pleasing thing is that KFC is positive. But as Greg said, there's a lot of volatility around it. It's a difficult quarter because they've got tough laps, we've got some expenses. Our goal as a team here is to make Q2 this year the fourth consecutive quarter of positive KFC same-store sales, but I cannot say that that's a guarantee until we have more visibility. But the fact that the flow-through was very strong and profit terms the simplification of the menu boards, which is well conducted, the strength of the marketing calendar in the back half gives me and the team a lot more confidence than we had 6 months ago.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, the -- further what Micky said, the timing of Chinese New Year with being a little bit earlier this year did provide a slight benefit to Q1, which will be a little bit -- which hurts Q2 a little bit, so that was a little bit on the sales line. As f
componenttext: First, the -- further what Micky said, the timing of Chinese New Year with being a little bit earlier this year did provide a slight benefit to Q1, which will be a little bit -- which hurts Q2 a little bit, so that was a little bit on the sales line. As far as your commodity question, John, we saw a 2% decline in commodities in China during the first quarter, and we are still on our forecast for plus 1 for the full year.

componenttext: We had positive transactions at KFC, and as I said that the transaction numbers we measure is the number of tickets we cut in the store. But as I explained, the 5 of the picket is bigger on the counter shareable meals, principally the bucket. So we estimate that the price impact on our sales is about 3, and the rest of it is an account of traffic plus a larger check and [indiscernible] So there's a fairly healthy growth.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just switching topics for a moment. Pizza Hut U.S. numbers were pretty good. Pizza Hut international is slightly negative. Can you talk a little bit about Pizza Hut international and what's going on in there and what changes you can implement the
componenttext: And then just switching topics for a moment. Pizza Hut U.S. numbers were pretty good. Pizza Hut international is slightly negative. Can you talk a little bit about Pizza Hut international and what's going on in there and what changes you can implement there?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, certainly, Joe. I think the good news, as you said, is Pizza Hut U.S. had an excellent quarter. Same-store sales up 5%. Company transactions are up 8%. I think the combination of the $6.99 pairs and the $5 flavor menu have certainly worked. And certa
componenttext: Yes, certainly, Joe. I think the good news, as you said, is Pizza Hut U.S. had an excellent quarter. Same-store sales up 5%. Company transactions are up 8%. I think the combination of the $6.99 pairs and the $5 flavor menu have certainly worked. And certainly, what we're doing now is in the process of taking that success and all the tactics that are associated with that and expanding that rapidly on a global basis. So like all things, these businesses are very much driven by our U.S. success, and I think what we're doing now is in the process of rolling out that U.S. success and taking around in a global basis. I happened to be in Thailand actually in January earlier in of the year, and you can see already that the team was starting to take the successful tactics of our and start to see how we can implement those in country, and it's happening around the world.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two unrelated questions if I may. First one for you Micky. For a number of years now, labor cost, labor dollars per operating week in China have been a pretty major contributor to margins. As you do plan to regrow customer traffic, obviously, in the segme
componenttext: Two unrelated questions if I may. First one for you Micky. For a number of years now, labor cost, labor dollars per operating week in China have been a pretty major contributor to margins. As you do plan to regrow customer traffic, obviously, in the segment and want to stay competitive with wages. I mean, are we at the point now where labor starts to inflect the other way and adding that cost into the system taking out over the last several years?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's true that over the last 5 years, labor has inflated in China on account of minimum wage increases by the government, but we've seen a moderation of that. I think the authority has recognized that the economy has to be supported, so I think we'r
componenttext: Well, it's true that over the last 5 years, labor has inflated in China on account of minimum wage increases by the government, but we've seen a moderation of that. I think the authority has recognized that the economy has to be supported, so I think we're seeing more reasonable picture there. What we did get in the quarter, particularly, was some good productivity gains on account of using more part time and student labor, which is a phenomena that did not exist in China in the long past, and that is making a difference. So looking forward, it's always a risk, but I don't see labor price inflation as being a significant risk. I think the key for us is going to be product innovation, sensible pricing and get traffic scores back. So I hope that helps.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Secondly, the commentary on the capital structure was interesting in that part of the new capital structure is going to be royalty securitization only to Taco Bell, which I don't think your previously -- your previous actually assigned itself to individua
componenttext: Secondly, the commentary on the capital structure was interesting in that part of the new capital structure is going to be royalty securitization only to Taco Bell, which I don't think your previously -- your previous actually assigned itself to individual brand. So I just wanted to understand the symbolism behind that, that security that's only related to Taco Bell and could people's imagination start to think that Taco Bell doesn't necessarily remain a part of Yum! over the long term as an opportunity arises.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Larry Gathof. I'll answer the debt aspect of it anyways, but what we're doing is we're trying to take advantage of the debt market in total. So we're looking at doing both the securitization, bank and bond debt, so we're putting debt across all the d
componenttext: It's Larry Gathof. I'll answer the debt aspect of it anyways, but what we're doing is we're trying to take advantage of the debt market in total. So we're looking at doing both the securitization, bank and bond debt, so we're putting debt across all the different avenues to again take the best pricing and optimize our balance sheet. The Taco Bell securitization is only going to be on the U.S. Taco Bell franchise and licensees, so it's just a part -- the rest of the Taco Bell business will also be part of the other borrowings. So again, the securitization market deep enough to do any one of our entire businesses. So we just peeled off the that we talked was most appropriate for securitization and are accessing that market. And again, we'll have the balance of borrowings across all 3 brands after that's completed.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So John, I wouldn't want anyone to take away any thinking it will be doing anything to Taco Bell other than love its portfolio, love its growth, love its profit contribution and love that, that is the brand that we can take global.
componenttext: So John, I wouldn't want anyone to take away any thinking it will be doing anything to Taco Bell other than love its portfolio, love its growth, love its profit contribution and love that, that is the brand that we can take global.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Keith Siegner with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Keith Siegner with UBS.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question for you. Having come from the Taco Bell brand and having watched that brand be one of the leaders in terms of overall digital engagement, mobile ordering and more, where do you -- how do you feel about the rest of the U.S. portfolio and po
componenttext: Just a question for you. Having come from the Taco Bell brand and having watched that brand be one of the leaders in terms of overall digital engagement, mobile ordering and more, where do you -- how do you feel about the rest of the U.S. portfolio and positioning now? Are you making the progress you want? Is Pizza Hut becoming more of a leader in each category? Is KFC also coming on? And what about test on delivery for other brands like replacement for KFC and even for Taco Bell? Is the rest of the U.S. portfolio catching up to Taco Bell? How -- where do we stand?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question. And I would say yes. I think the great thing is we can what makes Taco Bell successful. And obviously, the other 2 brands can obviously track with what they've done and obviously replicate it but in their own brand voice. So I'm very please
componenttext: Good question. And I would say yes. I think the great thing is we can what makes Taco Bell successful. And obviously, the other 2 brands can obviously track with what they've done and obviously replicate it but in their own brand voice. So I'm very pleased with the progress that Pizza Hut is making. I think this positioning around, making it easier to get a better pizza, I think the -- not only the sales growth, but the transaction growth that we just got. Obviously, part of making it easier was to get out value better Pizza Hut, which we have done. But I think, as we also said on the call, we are investing in technology. We do need to get from 9 POS systems down to 1 POS system. But as we also said, 46% of our delivery carryout sales are digital, and that's growing. And I do think we're making good progress there on the KFC side. I think the always original position move back to finger-licking good. The great thing about KFC in the U.S. is it's the brand is now being talked about. And I think for a long time, it wasn't on anyone's radar screen. So I'm very comfortable I think the launch of national has really helped. Obviously, there's a value game being played by the burger boys because of beat pricing, but the return $5 boxes has been a good move by the KFC team. And then for Taco Bell, the answer is, I think, we're now in 500 stores doing delivery in a couple of the key cities, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Dallas, I'm not quite sure where else, but -- so that's been expanded. And I think if you just take the overall concept of easy beats better, which I know the Pizza Hut team originated, but what it basically says is "Yes, we've got to find ways to make it easier for our people, for customers to get to our brand." But we do that 2 way: we build more units, but we also obviously will start looking at delivery as a way to get our food to 2 customers in their homes. So very good question. We are making progress. The other brands, I think, are moving to where the Taco Bell brand strength is. A lot of work to be done, but I think we're moving in the right direction, and we're encouraged by that.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question's on the guidance for the year, and I was wondering if you could provide some additional detail or insight on what you're assuming for China profit growth for the year and guidance and maybe also the margin that you expect to deliver in that b
componenttext: My question's on the guidance for the year, and I was wondering if you could provide some additional detail or insight on what you're assuming for China profit growth for the year and guidance and maybe also the margin that you expect to deliver in that business for the full year.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So the first thing I'd say is if you want to have a good quarter, you want it to be the first quarter in the year, which is what we certainly did and had a blowout quarter in China. So when we look at that first quarter, as well as some of the other
componenttext: Sure. So the first thing I'd say is if you want to have a good quarter, you want it to be the first quarter in the year, which is what we certainly did and had a blowout quarter in China. So when we look at that first quarter, as well as some of the other tailwinds we have in the business with regards to the VAT we talked about earlier, which is difficult to quantify we noticed something there, some of the commodity deflation that we're seeing. We felt very confident that even with some of the headwinds we're facing, particularly Pizza Hut Casual Dining and China are getting to a number that was 12% for the year. As we said, we have not yet -- we have not adjusted the same-store sales forecast for the balance of the year for China. It's too difficult to call, given we're only 2, 3.5 months in. But at this point, we feel very comfortable with the 12%.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, the way I look at it is it's the right guidance in the first quarter, demonstrated the degree of confidence we've got on the year. As we said, there'd be some puts and calls as the year unfolds, but we felt confident in raising it from 10 to 12.
componenttext: I mean, the way I look at it is it's the right guidance in the first quarter, demonstrated the degree of confidence we've got on the year. As we said, there'd be some puts and calls as the year unfolds, but we felt confident in raising it from 10 to 12.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you asked specifically about the margins in China, since we're so dependent upon sales, we're still thinking we're not coming off our guidance from the beginning of the year around 16 at this point.
componenttext: And you asked specifically about the margins in China, since we're so dependent upon sales, we're still thinking we're not coming off our guidance from the beginning of the year around 16 at this point.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I'm still on, I guess, if the margin guidance still is around 16 for the year, I guess I'm a little confused on that, given the overperformance in Q1. Is there something that changed about the outlook for the last 3 quarters or is it some level of cons
componenttext: If I'm still on, I guess, if the margin guidance still is around 16 for the year, I guess I'm a little confused on that, given the overperformance in Q1. Is there something that changed about the outlook for the last 3 quarters or is it some level of conservatism that you're basing in or...

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think so. I don't think we're thinking about it necessarily in that level of detail. I think we're saying it's just too early. We're off to a great start. With the Q1 success that we had, we feel very good with the 12%, but I don't think you s
componenttext: No, I don't think so. I don't think we're thinking about it necessarily in that level of detail. I think we're saying it's just too early. We're off to a great start. With the Q1 success that we had, we feel very good with the 12%, but I don't think you should be reading that into the balance of the forecast.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes in the line of Jeffrey Bernstein with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes in the line of Jeffrey Bernstein with Barclays.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two things. Just one, I'm hoping to get a little bit more color from Micky on the China side, obviously, with the short-term strength, which seems to be attributed to the New Year's promotion, just wondering how in your mind you perhaps separate that from
componenttext: Two things. Just one, I'm hoping to get a little bit more color from Micky on the China side, obviously, with the short-term strength, which seems to be attributed to the New Year's promotion, just wondering how in your mind you perhaps separate that from the longer-term recovery efforts. Just it seems like you're confident that the brand you said has really turned that it seems like maybe in March and in April, things have really eased. And just wondering how you think about the business over the next 12 months in terms of your short-term spikes because of promotion versus the long-term trajectory improving. And then I had one follow-up on Taco Bell U.S.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Like I said, I think the team and myself are feeling very much more confident. We just this week had all of our store managers. We have a stadium in the City of with 8,000 people talking about the theme for the future, which is strength to strength. And i
componenttext: Like I said, I think the team and myself are feeling very much more confident. We just this week had all of our store managers. We have a stadium in the City of with 8,000 people talking about the theme for the future, which is strength to strength. And in particular, when the KFC section was discussed, and we put out plans for the rest of the year and the positioning and the proposed marketing, there was just confidence. I feel that I really feel the brand is making a lot of progress. It is much stronger. I think the positioning is very clear. The calendars are strong. We're doing sensible things around of the core of the brand. We've already cleaned up the menu boards. We will do that even more. We're introducing proven international winners. I think you always have to be cautious when you come to China because there is economic volatility, and there is also unexpected twists and turns. So there's nothing hidden. It's not as though we're worried about specific events or something happening that causes us to worry, but just want to be cautious. We'd had 2 or 3 years of a lot of volatility. So the way we look at it right now is it's a "show me, don't tell me" sort of story, and we're hoping quarter after quarter to improve and strengthen the business. I think it's been mentioned a number of times, Q2 is going to be a difficult quarter on account of a variety of factors, but we are very focused in seeing whether we can deliver positive same-store sales and take it from there. So on KFC, I feel confident. I feel that the brand is making a lot of progress. And the other thing we talked about today is we spent a lot of energy, and were going to be taking very good care of store refurbishments. So we have good designs, good plans for aggressive refurbs in some of our older stores. We are opening a symbolically important 5,000 store in Shanghai, which is I think maybe the best KFC in the world. It's a state-of-the-art green store, which will open next week. Also, I think the brand is making progress on every front. On Pizza Hut, like I said before, I'm very disappointed negative same-store sales, and I don't see any reason why we cannot turn it around. There's no our scores are good, our competitive position is fantastic. There really is no international competitor with the name. And in addition to the 1500 dine-in stores, we got about 300 delivery units, which dwarf the competition. So I feel the brands are genuinely making progress. It's just that it's been 2 months. The first quarter was 2 months, and they make a call on the rest of the year, knowing what we've seen over the last 3 years out of the bound of what we should be doing. So that hopefully gave you some context on the way we're looking at it.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just, Greg, I wanted to follow up. You made a comment about Taco Bell U.S. It seems like it was a little light of your internal expectation, which I think you attributed to maybe some of the QSR burger competitors taking advantage of favorable be
componenttext: And then just, Greg, I wanted to follow up. You made a comment about Taco Bell U.S. It seems like it was a little light of your internal expectation, which I think you attributed to maybe some of the QSR burger competitors taking advantage of favorable beef. I'm just wondering to get a better understanding of your response, does it seem like you're now getting more aggressive presumably on value? I know you've obviously been with the brand for a long term and gone through these stages before, but just the idea you progressively pursue discounting versus kind of staying the course with your initial plan. Just want to get your thoughts.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jeffrey. I think, first thing I you want to do is just correct a [indiscernible] in my prepared remarks. I think I said the breakfast mix was 8%. It's actually 6%. The 8% is actually the transaction growth that we've got on breakfast in Q1, so I jus
componenttext: Sure, Jeffrey. I think, first thing I you want to do is just correct a [indiscernible] in my prepared remarks. I think I said the breakfast mix was 8%. It's actually 6%. The 8% is actually the transaction growth that we've got on breakfast in Q1, so I just want to clarify that. By the way, I'm very happy with 8% transaction growth in breakfast with one of our competitors doing all-day breakfast, so let me just say that. So to answer your question, yes, we had tied the launch of the Quesalupa to the Super Bowl. I tried to get the Super Bowl a couple of weeks because that would have really helped us, but unfortunately, the NFL wasn't going to play along. So we were so tied up to the launch with that event that there was a couple of weeks where we were a little naked, I would say. And so obviously, sales and transactions [indiscernible] were soft. The good news is that after that event, the Quesalupa had mix of over 10% and have done well for us. And even more importantly, Brian who's doing a great job leading the brand has -- he and the team have already changed the calendar. And in fact, today, we will launch some new $1 items into the marketplace. There's been a number of revisions to the calendar. So I think we can still be an incredibly innovative brand, socially conscious brand led by digital, but we can also just get out value, so it's more than comparative in the marketplace. And I think talking to Brian the other day, we still have a lot of confidence we'll deliver the at least 3% same-store sales growth for the year on Taco Bell.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Howard Penney with Hedgeye Risk Management.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could help me with Chinese culture and what the zodiac calendar in chicken means next year in terms of what that asset potentially could do for business.
componenttext: I was wondering if you could help me with Chinese culture and what the zodiac calendar in chicken means next year in terms of what that asset potentially could do for business.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't it's a very serious factor, frankly. I mean, the year of the dragon and the monkey are particular significance. Every year is important. One interesting feature that Julie and the team put together was actually introduced a Christmas bucket in 201
componenttext: I don't it's a very serious factor, frankly. I mean, the year of the dragon and the monkey are particular significance. Every year is important. One interesting feature that Julie and the team put together was actually introduced a Christmas bucket in 2015 December, which was reasonably successful, so that up. The point really is that if we do a good bucket-oriented for the calendar in December for Christmas and the Chinese New Year next year, we can look to good performance. The success of the monkey -- the year of the monkey promotion has shown us the importance of choosing the character well, the toys that go over it, the kid's meals that accompany it, which will help us to build for the future. And I think the year of the chicken does help. I mean there's no better authority on chicken than KFC, but I don't think it's going to be culturally that significant that people have chicken in the year of the chicken. It's a help. All I'm saying is lap is very successful year of the monkey promotion. That's one little gift on our side.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I could -- Greg, 9 months ago, obviously, the quarter wasn't as strong as you would've hoped, and then we go through the process of you spinning out the China business and talking about the change of the structure of the company, and now 9 months f
componenttext: And if I could -- Greg, 9 months ago, obviously, the quarter wasn't as strong as you would've hoped, and then we go through the process of you spinning out the China business and talking about the change of the structure of the company, and now 9 months forward, things look a lot better. I was wondering if you could maybe put tangible evidence around an intangible question, and that is what sort of the changes internally to the employees of Yum! and Yum! China has done to help turn the business around? I don't know if I'm asking that correctly, but I think part of the reason for doing this spin was maybe to focus on the different assets. And I mean, this, obviously, was a fantastic quarter. And for all those reasons, maybe some of those reasons. I'm struggling to ask the question properly, but I'm just wondering if some of them -- sorry, go ahead.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll have a go. I think I couldn't be happier to have Micky leading the team. Micky has an enormous amount of just experience, the confidence of all of us and did an amazing job running our international business for such a long of period of time on all 3
componenttext: I'll have a go. I think I couldn't be happier to have Micky leading the team. Micky has an enormous amount of just experience, the confidence of all of us and did an amazing job running our international business for such a long of period of time on all 3 brands. So I've got a leader in there who I have the utmost confidence in and who has rallied the team in China. We've got great people leading the brands, Joey and Peter. I mean, they're really -- I was there in March, looking at the plans, looking at what they learned from the lessons. Our culture is alive and well in China. So the whole recognition culture, and I believe that culture fuels results I think was absolutely evident. And I think the same time was also happening in a whole businesses are getting much better at brand building and strengthening our brand positioning. And so I think, China, I would say the words aren't exactly always original, I think it's be your true self. But they pretty much resonate. We've now got this brand on the global positioning, so we can leverage things. Micky has reached out and taken things like the $5 boxes that incredibly successful in a number of markets. As he said, they will go into the market soon in China. The Pizza Hut team is looking for a new positioning for Pizza Hut. And as Micky said, focusing on the pizza and less on the more and getting back to the core will help that brand as well. So I would sum it up as new leader, great leader, fresh perspective, great team, more global alignment and a real focus on brand building, all underpinned by our fundamental belief that we leverage culture to fuel results.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Brian Bittner with Oppenheimer and Company.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to ask a question on Taco Bell. You did roll out your pretty aggressive dollar breakfast menu at March. You said didn't really impact the full first quarter. Can you just talk about how this is impacting the overall business? Is it accretive t
componenttext: I just want to ask a question on Taco Bell. You did roll out your pretty aggressive dollar breakfast menu at March. You said didn't really impact the full first quarter. Can you just talk about how this is impacting the overall business? Is it accretive to your sales trends? Is it doing what you expect it to do? And externally, looking at the margin, how should we think about how this impacts the food margin going forward as [indiscernible] margin?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the good news is, as I said, we had 8% transaction growth in the breakfast daypart in the first quarter before we get the full impact of the dollar menu. So I think we feel really good that that's going to continue to have an impact on our b
componenttext: Well, I think the good news is, as I said, we had 8% transaction growth in the breakfast daypart in the first quarter before we get the full impact of the dollar menu. So I think we feel really good that that's going to continue to have an impact on our breakfast business. Our food and paper cost for breakfast are in line with the balance of the business. So whether it grows faster or slower, it doesn't impact the overall food and paper cost. The good news is, obviously, Taco Bell is benefiting from the price of beef right now, and that's honestly why are seeing in the marketplace a lot of value by both the burger chains and why Taco Bell can play an aggressive play in beef as well and...

componenttext: I think the good news is it's growing. It's growing in the face of us being focused. We're doing the right thing which innovated products. We got value now in that category, in that daypart, and I feel really good. I was in restaurants in the U.S. just recently. Visited Taco Bell's for breakfast, got great food, had a great experience, and I think the general feeling is that this is something we're going to be investing in the long term.

componenttext: Well, I think 2 things. I do believe we'll deliver at least 3% same store sales growth for the full year. So obviously, we got off to a slower-than-expected start, but as we said, we are rolling out the big numbers plus 6. So -- but discussions I've had with Brian, he still feels very confidence. I think we're confident we will deliver the same store sales growth in the U.S. and, obviously, commodities are favorable. And I think all signs are the stay favorable through the balance of 2016.

componenttext: I think when you're in 120 -- 130 countries, I always 0I'm not sure how many countries we are in, in any one day. That was plus 5, which if you think you can [indiscernible] We were soft in a number of places, but there's also real signs of real strength both in emerging and developed. And I think the team believes they also can obviously get sales up to at least the 3% same-store sales number in the year.

componenttext: That if you look at overall store productivity growth so just sales per unit versus comp growth that looks like the gap between those 2 numbers is still getting wider.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I see. Well, when you look at our performance by years, it's pretty consistent, so I don't think there's a particular factor there. And I really can't, at the moment, think of a particular reason. That has not struck me as the new units that we are buildi
componenttext: I see. Well, when you look at our performance by years, it's pretty consistent, so I don't think there's a particular factor there. And I really can't, at the moment, think of a particular reason. That has not struck me as the new units that we are building are in any way have inferior economics are such as entirely smaller units. It's true more stores in smaller cities, but our comps sales growth across tiers have been fairly consistent. We are experimenting with multiple store formats to take into account the fact that there is still very rapid buildout in infrastructure in China, so we are expecting very large number of malls already under construction, the high-speed rail network is being expanded and in China, like the U.S., there's at the moment highways, the drive-throughs, the rest stops, and all those are being developed. I don't really see the character of our productivity per unit changing in the years to come. I think, worldwide, there is a trend what we call small box, which is in line is becoming more popular mall stores etc. so there may be in the longer term slightly smaller format units, but China is not that impacted because we hardly have any drive-through, we hardly have any drive-throughs at all, so most of them will be in line anyway. So maybe we need to think about this question a little bit more, but we don't see any reason why the sort of growth we've enjoyed should not be projected long term in the future.
