componenttextpreview: Yes, just a quick follow-up on that and then one other quick one. On the Taco Bell margin maintenance in terms of your guidance for the year even with more sharp and value focus, is lower commodity cost really the primary reason you feel confident in that
componenttext: Yes, just a quick follow-up on that and then one other quick one. On the Taco Bell margin maintenance in terms of your guidance for the year even with more sharp and value focus, is lower commodity cost really the primary reason you feel confident in that still?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think 2 things. I do believe we'll deliver at least 3% same-store sales growth for the full year. So obviously, we got off to a slower-than-expected start. But as we said, we are rolling out the big numbers plus 6%. So -- but the discussions I've
componenttext: Well, I think 2 things. I do believe we'll deliver at least 3% same-store sales growth for the full year. So obviously, we got off to a slower-than-expected start. But as we said, we are rolling out the big numbers plus 6%. So -- but the discussions I've had with Brian, he still feels very confident. So I think we're confident we will deliver the same-store sales growth within the U.S. and, obviously, commodities are favorable. And I think all signs are that certainly beef will stay favorable probably through the balance of 2016.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just quickly on emerging markets at KFC. I know you called out a couple of Pizza Hut markets. That number is only up 1%. Is there any specific country or area that was a little softer this quarter?
componenttext: And then just quickly on emerging markets at KFC. I know you called out a couple of Pizza Hut markets. That number is only up 1%. Is there any specific country or area that was a little softer this quarter?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I think that when you're in 120 -- 130 countries, I always -- I'm never quite sure how many countries we are in on any one day. I think the good news is we had -- in 130 countries, you're going to have some up markets and some downs. India was minus
componenttext: Look, I think that when you're in 120 -- 130 countries, I always -- I'm never quite sure how many countries we are in on any one day. I think the good news is we had -- in 130 countries, you're going to have some up markets and some downs. India was minus 1%, but Russia was plus 27% in system sales for KFC. We also had strong developed markets. Australia delivered another really good quarter: they were plus 5%, which if you think about what [indiscernible]. So we were soft in a number of places, but there's also real signs of real strength both in emerging and developed. And I think that Roger Eaton and the team believe that they also can obviously get sales up into at least the 3% same-store sales growth number for the year.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Karen Holthouse with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Karen Holthouse with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a question on China that's actually not on comp sales but on new store productivity. It looked like there's still a growing gap between comp growth and average weekly sales growth. And just curious if you could comment on that. Is it being driven by on
componenttext: So a question on China that's actually not on comp sales but on new store productivity. It looked like there's still a growing gap between comp growth and average weekly sales growth. And just curious if you could comment on that. Is it being driven by one of the 2 brands, units in 1 area or another? And any sort of update on how to be thinking about unit economics for the year, because I think the last disclosures we have really only go through like 2014.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Karen, what were you quoting as the reason why you had that feeling?
componenttext: Okay. Karen, what were you quoting as the reason why you had that feeling?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That if you look at sort of overall store productivity growth, so just sales per unit versus comp growth, it looks like the gap between those 2 numbers is still getting wider.
componenttext: That if you look at sort of overall store productivity growth, so just sales per unit versus comp growth, it looks like the gap between those 2 numbers is still getting wider.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I see. Well, when we look at our performance by peers, it's pretty consistent. So I don't think there's a particular factor there. And I really can't, at the moment, think of a particular reason. That certainly has not struck me that the new units that we
componenttext: I see. Well, when we look at our performance by peers, it's pretty consistent. So I don't think there's a particular factor there. And I really can't, at the moment, think of a particular reason. That certainly has not struck me that the new units that we are building are in any way have inferior economics or any such. It's not as though we're building necessarily smaller units. It is true that we build more stores in smaller cities, but our comp sales growth across tiers has been fairly consistent. We are experimenting with multiple store formats to take into account the fact that there is still very rapid build-out in infrastructure in China. So we are expecting very large number of malls that are already under construction, the high-speed rail network is being expanded and then in China, unlike the U.S., there's not a phenomenon at the moment of highways with drive-thrus, or the rest stops, and all of those are being developed. I don't really see the character of our productivity per unit changing in the years to come. I think, worldwide, there is a trend to, what we call, small box, which is because in line they're becoming more popular in mall stores, et cetera. So there may be in the longer term slightly smaller format units, but not -- China is not that impacted because we hardly have any drive-thrus. We hardly have any drive-thrus at all. So most of them are in line anyway. So maybe we need to think about this question a little more, but we don't intrinsically see any reason why the sort of growth we've enjoyed should not be projected long term into the future.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

It would be helpful just to understand that a little bit better.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just your outlook for franchising in China. Do you -- if you like to convert more company source of franchising?
componenttext: Just your outlook for franchising in China. Do you -- if you like to convert more company source of franchising?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Well, at the moment, as you know, the state of about just over 7,000 stores. About 10% are franchised and 90% are equity. I think, at the moment, as long as we have -- and the way -- we never chase a number of stores that we have to build, but when
componenttext: Right. Well, at the moment, as you know, the state of about just over 7,000 stores. About 10% are franchised and 90% are equity. I think, at the moment, as long as we have -- and the way -- we never chase a number of stores that we have to build, but when we get new trade zones opening and opportunities that make commercial sense and has a very disciplined process for capital allocation and measuring new unit returns, we have a lot of surplus capital, as you know, in China. All the stores here have been built with Chinese-generated capital, there's no intrinsic reason why we would want to give that up to franchisees. The 2 reasons why we do expect, however, franchising to up marginally is, firstly, there are our regions of the country where it makes sense for franchisees to operate. We recently opened in the Autonomous Region of Tibet, our first store in Lhasa, Tibet. And for a variety of reasons, including difficult operating conditions and local market knowledge, that was given to a franchisee, and it's been successful and I think that will grow. So there are parts of the country where we will do it for reasons that it makes sense to do it that way. And the other is that there will be opportunities to do franchising, for example, with a gas station chain, et cetera. And for those technical reasons, the percentage of franchising might go up for 10 to maybe 15 or something in the foreseeable future, but we don't expect a significant change there. Now of course, if we do not find the ability to invest our capital in productive equity investment, sure, we'll look at franchising more actively. We're not at the moment -- we're agnostic to whether it's franchising or equity, frankly. I mean, both have advantages. Franchisees can -- obviously, their capital-light and also they're very innovative. But at the moment, with the capital that we have, especially as they become independent, I think it will be a good use for the capital to continue to invest. I mean, China is a growth market, the way we see it. And we still have the vision doubling or tripling our store base. So that's the way we're looking at it. So I would say the franchising percentage will edge up, but it will not be a game-changer in our business.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So on the VAT, so currently China is paying 5% of all their sales in the form of a business tax to the government. What's happening now is China is moving to a more traditional VAT regime for -- which is similar to the regime in many other parts of
componenttext: Okay. So on the VAT, so currently China is paying 5% of all their sales in the form of a business tax to the government. What's happening now is China is moving to a more traditional VAT regime for -- which is similar to the regime in many other parts of the world, where we will pay 6% of those top line sales to the government, but we'll get a credit for some of the inputs that we have into our P&L commodities, utilities, rent against that 6% credit. What's difficult for us to say right now is exactly how that -- those credits are going to accumulate and when is that exactly is going to be creditable and we are working through that, as you can imagine, with 6,000 stores. It's going to be a monumental effort, and there's also some lack of clarity around the rules at this point still. So we're going to have a lot more for you in July. We'll have 1 month worth of this in our Q2 results, the benefit in our Q2 results, and we'll be able to quantify much more detail at that point in time.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Andrew Charles with Cowen and Company.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Micky, as you saw success with an operationally simple promotion at KFC in the first quarter, I realize Pizza Hut is not as time-sensitive of an occasion, but are there opportunities to implement better operational practice at that brand, particularly on
componenttext: Micky, as you saw success with an operationally simple promotion at KFC in the first quarter, I realize Pizza Hut is not as time-sensitive of an occasion, but are there opportunities to implement better operational practice at that brand, particularly on the breadth of the menu?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely, Andrew, there are. I think the menu is complicated. I think I've mentioned this in December as well. It's a tabbed menu. You actually have -- it's very large number of pages. It's a book. It's a little difficult to navigate, so simplifyin
componenttext: Yes, absolutely, Andrew, there are. I think the menu is complicated. I think I've mentioned this in December as well. It's a tabbed menu. You actually have -- it's very large number of pages. It's a book. It's a little difficult to navigate, so simplifying that is a priority. Pizza Hut is celebrated and known for the variety of menu here. We do not want to lose that, but at the same time, I think we can make it far more controlled. It also speeds up service, and table turns are an issue at Pizza Hut at peak times. So for those reasons, we are rationalizing the menu. We're also, like I said earlier, pointing out the great value that we have through lunch combos and other offers, so we'll -- we're redesigning that part of the menu as well. And lastly, does it -- this -- I mean, I'm constantly amazed at how advanced China is digitally. It's got twice the number of cell phones, smartphones as the U.S. population. And even on our offices, people go up and down the elevator to go to lunch. They're looking up where the offers are available and where they can book a table, et cetera. So the action is shifting very rapidly to mobile devices, and both the menu as well as digital marketing is becoming very significant. So we are working on that. The good news is that both -- for both our brands, we are in a leadership position when it comes to that whole digital interface, cashless payment, et cetera. But to your question, yes, I think the sort of operational simplicity at KFC, making it easier for consumers to choose our bestselling products, and the general philosophy that the menu should not be a -- should be used more as guiding customers to our best-selling products than to give open choices, which they get confused about, is something that is applicable at Pizza Hut as well.

componenttext: Sure. So the plan is still to be 96% franchised by the end of 2017, which that will include the China units, post-spin. This year what's going to get -- what's more -- what's going to get done are the U.S. re-franchising, which is going to be KFCs and -- I'm sorry, Taco Bells and, to a lesser degree, Pizza Hut. We would expect significant gains in those regards. Quite frankly, selling some of the international markets is a little bit more difficult, so that will take a little bit more time. We expect that to be more 2017-loaded.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Amy, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Yum! Brands First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Steve Schmitt, Vice President of Investor Re
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Amy, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Yum! Brands First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Steve Schmitt, Vice President of Investor Relations and Corporate Strategy, you may begin your conference.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Amy. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. On our call today are Greg Creed, our CEO; and Dave Russell, our interim CFO. Also on today's call is Larry Gathof, Yum!'s Treasurer. And we're very pleased to have Micky Pant, Yum!'s Chin
componenttext:
Thanks, Amy. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. On our call today are Greg Creed, our CEO; and Dave Russell, our interim CFO. Also on today's call is Larry Gathof, Yum!'s Treasurer. And we're very pleased to have Micky Pant, Yum!'s China CEO, on our call as well. Following remarks from Greg and Dave, we'll open the call to questions from the entire team. Please keep in mind Micky is dialing in from Shanghai, so there could be a slight delay in some of his responses.
Before we get started, I would like to remind you that this conference call includes forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements are subject to future events and uncertainties that could cause our actual results to differ materially from these statements.
All forward-looking statements should be considered in conjunction with the cautionary statements in our earnings release and the risk factors included in our filings with the SEC. In addition, please refer to the Investors section of the Yum! Brands website, www.yum.com, to find disclosures and reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures that may be used on today's call.
We are broadcasting this conference call via our website. This call is also being recorded and will be available for playback. Please be advised that if you ask a question, it will be included in both our live conference and in any future use of the recording.
We would like to make you aware of the following upcoming Yum! investor event. Our second quarter 2016 earnings will be released on Wednesday, July 13.
Now before I turn the call over to Greg, I would like to bring your attention to 2 items you may have noticed in yesterday's release. First, the new terminology. We reported core operating profit growth of 21% for the first quarter 2016. Core operating profit growth is our operating profit growth year-over-year excluding foreign currency translation and special items. Second, as previously announced, effective January of this year, the company's India business integrated its 3 brands into our global brand divisions. The prior year figures have been restated in the release. 
Now it's my pleasure to hand the call over to Mr. Greg Creed.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased we're off to a strong start in 2016 with better-than-expected core operating profit growth of 21% in the first quarter. This includes 42% growth in our China business due to outstanding Chinese New
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased we're off to a strong start in 2016 with better-than-expected core operating profit growth of 21% in the first quarter. This includes 42% growth in our China business due to outstanding Chinese New Year results at KFC, underscoring the power of the KFC brand in China when we deliver insight-driven marketing that resonates with our customers. 
Companywide, all 4 of our divisions posted positive same-store sales and operating profit growth in constant currency. Furthermore, we are on track to finalize the spin-off of our China business by year-end, creating 2 powerful, independent, focused growth companies. As you saw in our release, we're raising full year core operating profit growth guidance for Yum! Brands to 12% from 10% previously. Even though it is still early in the year, we are confident about the revised guidance, and we'll update you as the year progresses.
Today, I'll give you an overview of each of our operating divisions. And then Dave Russell, our interim CFO, will walk you through the financials. 
So first, China. For the China division, same-store sales grew 6%, led by 12% same-store sales growth at KFC. Our KFC business, as a reminder, represents about 75% of our operating profit in China. We saw particular success at KFC during the Chinese New Year with bucket meals, which we tailored across 4 customer groups ranging from kids buckets to larger group meals. As a result, buckets mixed a much higher percentage than normally. This lifted average ticket as we focused more on group occasions. And we gained even more consumer insights this year, which will help our business both going forward as well as next new year. Pizza Hut Casual Dining, which represents about 25% of our operating profit in China, remained challenging. System sales declined 1%, and same-store sales declined 12% in the quarter. A tough macro environment and competitive landscape continued to weigh on performance. We're addressing this with urgency but realize our recovery will take time.
So wrapping up on China. We are pleased with our first quarter's overall operating profit growth, which came in well ahead of our expectations. The strong margin performance reinforces our confidence in the future earnings power of this business. When we generate sales growth, profit flow-through is impressive. As Steve mentioned, Micky Pant, our division -- China division CEO, is on the call today and will be happy to assist in answering questions you may have on the China business.
Now turning to our 3 global brand divisions. In our KFC division, same-store sales grew 1% in the first quarter or 5% on a 2-year stack. Operating profit grew 7% in constant currency when adjusting for incremental advertising spend in the U.S. The division opened 79 new international restaurants in 32 countries. 77% of these units were opened by franchisees, and 71% of our new international openings were in emerging markets. I'm encouraged by our ability to generate growth in both emerging and developed markets. System sales in international developed markets grew 5%, and in international emerging markets, grew 8%. I recently visited with the team in Canada and was thrilled to see the assets being upgraded and the marketing position around Always Original. With 6% same-store sales growth in the quarter, I'd say it's working. I'm also pleased to see success in emerging markets, which are a key contributor to KFC's growth story. KFC is a franchise-led emerging powerhouse, and I'm confident the brand is getting even stronger and will produce strong growth this year and for many years to come.
Pizza Hut grew same-store sales 3% in the quarter and was led by 5% same-store sales growth in the U.S., which makes up approximately 60% of total sales. Our $5 flavor menu helped drive system transactions with company stores leading the way, up 8% in the quarter. Our discipline around making it easier to get a better pizza is holistic and driving traffic. We are focused on the entire customer experience from ordering, payment and delivery tracking to our assets and menu, and I believe this quarter's results are a further testament to our maniacal emphasis on this way of thinking. We are on track to replace over 1,300 U.S. ovens in 2016. For those stores replacing older ovens, this should result in average energy savings of 25% in ongoing operational costs and a faster cook time. From a marketing calendar perspective, we are focusing on balancing premium product innovation such as stuffed garlic knots pizza to protect and improve unit-level economics with compelling value offerings such as their ongoing $6.99 Any pairs deal. All of this will enable us to provide our customers with a better pizza at great value.
Our international business at Pizza Hut saw system sales growth of 3% in constant currency and a 1% decline in same-store sales in the quarter. Sales were especially strong in Latin America and Canada, but offset by weaknesses in Korea, Australia and India. We are committed to offering consistent everyday value to our customers and will leverage proven value strategies across markets with similar characteristics. 
We have high expectations for the international Pizza Hut business. Over the last 5 years, we have opened 1,200 international restaurants, and we will continue to grow this business over time. The bottom line is that we have established solid momentum with our strategy in the U.S., especially around the $5 flavor menu. And as we roll this overall strategy out internationally, we hope to achieve similar success.
Now turning to Taco Bell. Same-store sales grew 1%, lapping 6% growth a year ago, and operating profit grew 4% in the quarter. Restaurant margins were an impressive 21%. While 1% same-store sales growth is not what we're used to seeing at Taco Bell, the timing of our key launches had an impact on same-store sales growth for the quarter. The Quesalupa, which launched in February, mixed at almost 10% and drove a meaningful lift in transactions. We also launched our $1 breakfast menu in March. The $1 price point is consistent with Taco Bell's reputation as the value leader in QSR. Taco Bell's new breakfast $1 value menu differentiates itself from the competitors and puts it at the forefront of value in a growing daypart. We now have 10 $1 items on the breakfast menu and are seeing breakfast sales hold at 8% and transaction growth accelerating. The Taco Bell team is exhibiting great flexibility to read and react to the competitive value pressures and adjusted their 2016 promotional calendar accordingly to highlight even more value. Insight-driven innovation, crave-able food and breakthrough value, such as the upcoming launches of the $1 Beefy Crunch Burrito and steak value [ph] later this year, should boost sales and further the brand's momentum.
So we're off to a great start at Yum! Over the past several quarters, we really had 3 businesses that needed dramatic improvement: KFC China, Pizza Hut China and Pizza Hut U.S. I'm pleased that we've been able to turn 2 out of these 3 businesses, as KFC China and Pizza Hut U.S. are on more solid footing. Now let's be clear: We're not out of the woods on these businesses, but we've made a lot of progress and we'll continue to focus on delivering better results. As you heard me say before, this is a transformational year for Yum! as we finalize the spin-off of our China business, creating 2 powerful, independent, focused growth companies. Our brand strength, unwavering focus on the customer and innovative food offerings driven by consumer insights will allow us to grow Yum! into an even better global company. This is an exciting time and pivotal time for our company, and I look forward to what the future holds.
And with that, I will hand the call over to Dave.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg, and good morning, everyone. In my remarks today, I'll cover 3 areas: our first quarter results, our outlook for 2016 and an update on our planned recapitalization and the spin-off of our China business. As Greg mentioned, we are very pleased
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg, and good morning, everyone. In my remarks today, I'll cover 3 areas: our first quarter results, our outlook for 2016 and an update on our planned recapitalization and the spin-off of our China business. As Greg mentioned, we are very pleased with our strong first quarter results, where core operating profit increased 21%. EPS before special items grew 19%, including a 5-point negative impact from foreign currency. These results were led by better-than-expected sales in restaurant margins at KFC China. EPS also benefited from a 5% reduction in our diluted share count compared to our first quarter last year due to our significant share buybacks over the past 12 months. 
I'll now take you through our results by divisions, starting with our China business. For the China division overall, same-store sales grew 6% in the quarter. KFC grew same-store sales 12%, which was sequentially better than Q4 and exceeded our expectations. A successful Chinese New Year promotion drove results. As Greg said, the KFC brand in China is really powerful when you deliver insight-driven marketing that resonates with our customers.
Same-store sales at Pizza Hut Casual Dining remained sluggish, declining 12% in the quarter. We are working to turn the Pizza Hut business around in a difficult macro and competitive environment.
Restaurant margin improved 3.5 percentage points versus the prior year to 22.4%, helped by sales leverage at KFC, productivity initiatives and commodity deflations, more than offsetting sales deleverage at Pizza Hut. While our first quarter is a seasonally high sales period for the China division, restaurant margins of over 22% give us tremendous confidence in the future earnings power of this business. When we deliver solid top line growth, the profits are impressive. 
One other note on China's first quarter results. We had a leap year benefit that added an additional $6 million of operating profit in Q1 to China's results. However, we pull sales from the leap date out of our same-store sales calculation, such that the extra day had no impact on reported 6% same-store sales growth. The way our reporting with calendars works here at Yum!, none of our other divisions saw any impact from leap year in Q1. 
Now moving to our global KFC division, which posted its ninth consecutive quarter of same-store sales and profit growth. Emerging and international developed markets each grew comps 1%. U.S. recorded its seventh consecutive quarter of same-store sales growth despite overlapping 7% comps in the first quarter of last year. Operating margins improved 30 basis points in constant currency and core operating profit grew 4% in the quarter. Adjusting for the incremental advertising expense associated with the acceleration agreement we reached with our franchisees in 2015, core operating profit grew 7% in the quarter. As a reminder, the acceleration agreement with our U.S. franchisees, which went into effect during the second quarter of last year, called for us to invest incremental media of $20 million in 2016 as opposed to $10 million last year.
Our global Pizza Hut division delivered 3% same-store sales growth for the quarter, led by 5% same-store sales growth in our U.S. business. Same-store sales growth and lower G&A expenses drove core operating profit growth of 9%. This is the best result we've seen in our Pizza Hut U.S. in years, and we believe our strategy is working to drive incremental transactions. I am pleased to see momentum behind the business and believe we can transfer our U.S. learnings to benefit the system globally. Digital continues to grow in importance to our sales, comprising 46% of U.S. delivery and carryout sales, a 3 percentage point increase versus a year ago. On Super Bowl Sunday alone, we took over 500,000 digital orders, representing about 50% of sales along with an all-time record day for the business. With digital orders comes higher levels of loyalty and higher average spend, so we're investing as you would expect. Along those lines, we're making progress in migrating to a single point-of-sale system in the U.S. by the end of 2017, which will allow us to be more nimble as we roll out digital initiatives going forward.
Finally, Taco Bell faced increased value pressure from the burger chains in the first quarter and posted 1% same-store sales growth. Same-store sales improved throughout the quarter, and we remain confident in achieving 3% same-store sales growth for the year with a stronger second half than first half. Despite the lower-than-expected full quarter sales, operating margin improved 150 basis points to 28%, and operating profit grew 4%. Restaurant margins also improved 150 basis points at 21%, and we expect full year margins to be greater than 20% this year, albeit slightly lower than last year. 
On the development front, we opened 40 new -- 49 new restaurants in the first quarter, with 90% opened by franchisees and licensees. Of our new openings, 7 were international units. We expect to open a record number of Taco Bell units internationally in 2016 as we continue to make progress in building out the unit-level economics as we enter into new countries.
I'd now like to shift to our 2016 outlook. With our strong first quarter results and the change in China's tax laws, whereby a value-added tax or VAT is replacing the business tax, we are raising our full year core operating profit growth forecast to 12% from 10% for Yum!. 
For a little bit of background on the VAT. China recently announced further reform to its retail tax structure, which is intended to be a progressive and positive shift to more closely align with a more modern service-based economy. Under this reform, a 6% output VAT would replace the 5% business tax currently applied to certain restaurant sales. Input VAT would be creditable to the aforementioned 6% output VAT. This change is effective May 1, 2016, so it in no way had any impact on our first quarter performance. While it's difficult to estimate the impact of this VAT reform prior to its actual implementation, Yum! China currently expects a positive financial benefit, further enabling continued investment in the business and creating thousands of additional jobs in China. While we are raising our forecast for core operating profit growth from Yum! from 10% to 12%, we are maintaining our guidance for China same-store sales of 2% to 3% for the full year. 
From a modeling standpoint, there are 2 other things to bear in mind as you build your forecast. First, the second quarter in China, which is typically our seasonally low quarter, happens to be our toughest hurdle of the year on a 2-, 3- and 4-year stack same-store sales base. Second, we have an RGM convention in the second quarter that we did not have last year that we expect to cost around $7 million. It is important for you to know that these factors were fully factored into our initial guidance, and our first half and full year performance is expected to exceed our expectations coming into the year.
All-in for Yum!, we outperformed our expectations in the first quarter and are raising our full year guidance to 12% core operating profit growth, including the 53rd week. This takes into account the strong first quarter we produced at KFC China, weakness at Pizza Hut Casual Dining and the expected VAT benefit in China, in addition to our brand divisions continuing to produce results consisting -- consistent with our 2 -- initial 2016 targets. It's early in the year to raise guidance, but we feel confident given where things stand, and we'll update you as the year progresses.
Now I'd like to quickly update you on our spin-off plans. We remain on track to complete the spin-off by year-end. We plan on filing our initial Form 10 by early May and conducting comprehensive roadshows ahead of the separation. This spin-off will establish 2 unique investment opportunities and create one of the largest U.S.-listed China retail businesses. Another key aspect of our strategy is to optimize the capital structure of Yum!. Given the significant improvement we've seen recently in the debt markets, we'd like to announce another milestone in our previously communicated plan of targeting companywide leverage of approximately 5x EBITDA. In early May, we plan to enter into a new financing facility of at least $2 billion, securitizing Taco Bell's U.S. royalties. As a next step in our plan, subsidiaries that operate our KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell's businesses, excluding the Taco Bell subsidiaries included in the securitization financing, are expected to enter into a new senior secured credit facility and issue new high-yield notes. More details will be forthcoming in a separate release later today. In line with what we previously communicated, we plan to complete our rate [ph] capitalization and have approximately $9 billion of debt outstanding by the end of the second quarter.
Finally, since we announced in October 2015 our intention to separate the China business, we have bought back 24.7 million shares at an average price of $71, returning a total of $1.8 billion to shareholders excluding dividends. As previously announced, our recap will enable us to complete an additional $4.4 billion return of capital to shareholders. 
So let me wrap things up. I'm pleased we started 2016 off with a strong quarter. We're confident we'll deliver 12% core operating profit growth for the full year and we're proceeding as expected with the separation of our China business into an independent publicly traded company. We are working diligently to set up both companies for future success and look forward to updating you on any progress throughout the year. 
And with that, I'll hand the ball -- call back to Greg.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dave. Before we start Q&A, I wanted to provide a brief update on our plans for the China business. You may have seen recent news stories about a sale or a potential strategic investor. I want to assure you that we are fully committed to maximiz
componenttext:
Thank you, Dave. Before we start Q&A, I wanted to provide a brief update on our plans for the China business. You may have seen recent news stories about a sale or a potential strategic investor. I want to assure you that we are fully committed to maximizing the value of our China business for the benefit of our shareholders and we will carefully consider all options to achieve that goal. 
As you know, we announced in October that after careful consideration, we believe that the best way to maximize shareholder value is to spin off our China business by the end of this year, and we are making great progress towards the spin-off. We won't have any further comment on this. 
And with that, I'll open the call up to Q&A.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes with the line of David Palmer with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes with the line of David Palmer with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fundamental question about China for Micky, if I may. Regarding Pizza Hut, what have you done so far, perhaps even through the second quarter to date with regards to the menu and the marketing? I know you wanted to get back to that 5-star dining at 3-star
componenttext: Fundamental question about China for Micky, if I may. Regarding Pizza Hut, what have you done so far, perhaps even through the second quarter to date with regards to the menu and the marketing? I know you wanted to get back to that 5-star dining at 3-star prices. Have you done stuff so far? How is that working? And how has your thinking generally evolved about the timetable for a turnaround of the Pizza Hut brand?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. I hope you can hear me because I had a bit of trouble. I'll speak slowly. First, on Pizza Hut, I just wanted to say to all of you that it is an extremely strong brand in China. All our consumer metrics, the brand image tracking that we d
componenttext: Thank you, David. I hope you can hear me because I had a bit of trouble. I'll speak slowly. First, on Pizza Hut, I just wanted to say to all of you that it is an extremely strong brand in China. All our consumer metrics, the brand image tracking that we do regularly shows that brand regard, value scores, food scores are very high, and they recovered fully from the crisis that we had a couple of years ago. We opened 280 new Pizza Huts last year, and new unit returns are very good. Over the last 4 years, we've opened 1,000 Pizza Huts dine-in restaurants alone and we dwarfed the competition. So it is a very strong brand. It is true that same-store sales have been negative. But in 2015, for example, our system sales were up 10 points, and we do track through CREST in 22 cities and also through publicly reported companies that operate in casual dining here, the overall casual dining performance, and it is our understanding that we gained market share. Part of the reason the casual dining sector has been hit has been due to a decline in consumer confidence. And as we explained in December last year, part of it was on account of the fact that home delivery through aggregators was growing. This latter phenomenon has tapered off a bit on account of burnouts, et cetera. So we fully expect that Pizza Hut will turn the corner. It is a strong brand. Margin performance have been good. Sales were kind of minus 1, system sales in the first quarter, but our goal is to get to same-store sales positive. I cannot put a date on it, David, because the market is volatile, but we are doing a number of things. First is that we have shifted the focus back to the core menu with a lot of pizza activity. So we will have more pizza innovation in the next 6 months than we've had in a long time, and these have tested very well. The second, I believe, is our value scores are actually good. You can eat lunch at a Pizza Hut at just a little more than at a KFC. So there's no need for any margin compression, but we do need to communicate that value better, which we have started doing. We've clarified the brand position significantly and we've hired one of the best celebrities in China to bring that point home. And lastly, we continue to emphasize customer service for the programs that would be presented in December. So with that, I feel much better about Pizza Hut than I did a few months ago but, of course, I'm disappointed that same-store sales are still negative. And I might also remind you, as you know very well, that Pizza Hut is about 25% of our sales and our profits. So one way to look at it is that 3 of the 4 engines that drive the Yum! China business are KFC. And with KFC performing well, I think we have the ability to support [ph] Pizza Hut in coming quarters.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Glass with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Glass with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Micky, I'll keep you on the line. On KFC, you talked about the bucket promotion being an essential driver. So how much of the success in the first quarter was related just to that? And I guess, related, how -- if it was very -- if it was a successful prom
componenttext: Micky, I'll keep you on the line. On KFC, you talked about the bucket promotion being an essential driver. So how much of the success in the first quarter was related just to that? And I guess, related, how -- if it was very -- if it was a successful promotion, how much of that sustains going forward? If you can talk about sustainability of those sales, maybe since we're well into April here. And can you also just -- commodities were significantly deflationary this quarter. I think they were supposed to be up this year. So are you changing your view on commodities? Or was this just the timing of better commodities in the first quarter, but not for the year?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, it's Greg. I'm just going to jump in first and then obviously let you provide the detail. But first, I want to commend Micky and the entire China team for what I think is a fantastic Q1. KFC China delivered 12% same-store sales growth. And as you ca
componenttext: John, it's Greg. I'm just going to jump in first and then obviously let you provide the detail. But first, I want to commend Micky and the entire China team for what I think is a fantastic Q1. KFC China delivered 12% same-store sales growth. And as you can see from the 42% growth in op profit, the earnings power of the business is extraordinary when sales are working in our favor. And we're very encouraged that we've now had 3 consecutive quarters of same-store sales at KFC China. I think, fortunately, we didn't assume and we don't need heroic numbers like this to continue throughout the year to reach our 2016 guidance of 2% to 3% same-store sales growth. And recent history shows that sales in China have been difficult for us to call. So regarding our expectations coming into the year, KFC sales were obviously much better in Q1 than we could've imagined. In Q2, we're closer to where we thought we'd be for KFC as we believe that our successful Chinese New Year may have pulled forward some of early Q2 sales into Q1. That said, 6 weeks into the quarter, KFC sales were slightly positive, and we're encouraged by where the business is going. And obviously, I'll let Micky speak to that in more detail. And as you know, we know that we still got a lot of work to do on Pizza Hut in China. And quarter to date, sales have remained double-digit negative. But again, as Dave mentioned, our Q2 laps for both KFC and Pizza Hut are more difficult, especially when you look at these multi-year stacks. So we feel great about the start to the year. We're confident in raising our guidance. We still expect China full year -- China division same-store sales to be in the 2% to 3% range, which is consistent with our expectations. So with that, I'll just let Micky take over. I just wanted to compliment Micky and the team for a job well done.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Greg. I think, John, there were some factors that were unique to Q1, and that has to do with the Chinese New Year. It was the year of the monkey and we were fortunate that the -- actually, it was not just fortune, but the team at KFC has really
componenttext: Thank you, Greg. I think, John, there were some factors that were unique to Q1, and that has to do with the Chinese New Year. It was the year of the monkey and we were fortunate that the -- actually, it was not just fortune, but the team at KFC has really hit their stride. So Joey Wat, who was a very accomplished retail executive, has now really understood the rhythm of the KFC business, and they put together a sort of 1, 2, 3 punch around the Chinese New Year. Extending it from the traditional 10 days to about 4 weeks, centered around a very powerful bucket promotion but also then with activity afterwards featuring a grilled sandwich, which was good thinking because after a heavy Chinese New Year, people are looking for a healthier fare. So that aspect is unique to the Chinese New Year, and I think it was a spectacularly successful promotion. Somebody asked me how we'll ever lap that next year, and I think the one bit of good news we have is next year is actually the year of the chicken. So we started work already on the sort of promotions that we'll be running. But some of the factors that worked in Q1 actually give me encouragement for KFC overall. The first is the success of selling our core products, our fried chicken, hot wings, french fries, egg tarts and all the familiar favorites in China. And we are extending that principle by doing more activity around buckets in the back half of the year and also introducing boxed meals, which are a proven international success where you can buy a fairly -- a good -- just like a little bit more money, but significantly more product. As you can imagine, following a very large success in January and February, we hit almost record volumes in the amount of chicken that we did sell. And also, that sale was accompanied by corresponding traffic growth. The ticket impact on our sales of plus 12% in Q1 was about 3%. So it wasn't as though that we -- no, sorry, the pricing impact. So it wasn't as though we took pricing to get there. The price impact was only plus 3%. The rest of it is on account of the fact that party sizes for these large buckets were very large. And also, there was a significant increase in the number of items bought per person because the promotion was very well run. In Q2, we're about halfway through the quarter, but the pleasing thing is that KFC is positive. But as Greg said, there's a lot of volatility around it. It's a difficult quarter because we've got tough laps, we've had some expenses. Our goal as a team here is to make Q2 this year the fourth consecutive quarter of positive KFC same-store sales, but I cannot say that that's a guarantee until we have more visibility. But the fact that the flow-through was very strong in profit terms, the simplification of the menu boards, which is well conducted, the strength of the marketing calendar in the back half gives me and the team a lot more confidence than we had 6 months ago.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Micky.
componenttext: Thanks, Micky.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, the -- part of what Micky said a little bit too, the timing of Chinese New Year, with it being a little bit earlier this year, did provide a slight benefit to Q1, which will be a little bit -- which hurts Q2 a little bit, so that was a little bit o
componenttext: First, the -- part of what Micky said a little bit too, the timing of Chinese New Year, with it being a little bit earlier this year, did provide a slight benefit to Q1, which will be a little bit -- which hurts Q2 a little bit, so that was a little bit on the sales line. As far as your commodities question, John, we saw a 2% decline in commodities in China during the first quarter, and we are still on our forecast for plus 1% for the full year.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: You gave a little bit of this in your answer to the last question, but could you talk about traffic versus price versus mix for both KFC China and KFC, Pizza Hut during the quarter?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Joe, it's Steve. For the division, we had about -- for the 6% comp in the division, we had 9 points in check growth and a 3-point decline in transactions overall.
componenttext: Joe, it's Steve. For the division, we had about -- for the 6% comp in the division, we had 9 points in check growth and a 3-point decline in transactions overall.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And presumably, though, positive transactions at KFC?
componenttext: Okay. And presumably, though, positive transactions at KFC?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: That's the number for the divisions.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We had positive transactions at KFC. And as I said that the transaction numbers we measure is the number of tickets we cut in the store. But as I explained, the size of the ticket is bigger on account of shareable meals, principally the bucket. So we esti
componenttext: We had positive transactions at KFC. And as I said that the transaction numbers we measure is the number of tickets we cut in the store. But as I explained, the size of the ticket is bigger on account of shareable meals, principally the bucket. So we estimate that the price impact on our sales is about 3%, and the rest of it is on account of traffic plus a larger check on account of more items being bought. So it was a fairly healthy growth.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just switching topics for a moment. Pizza Hut U.S. numbers looked pretty good. Pizza Hut international is slightly negative. Can you talk a little bit about Pizza Hut international and kind of what's going on there and what changes you can implem
componenttext: And then just switching topics for a moment. Pizza Hut U.S. numbers looked pretty good. Pizza Hut international is slightly negative. Can you talk a little bit about Pizza Hut international and kind of what's going on there and what changes you can implement there?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, certainly, Joe. I think the good news, as you said, is Pizza Hut U.S. had an excellent quarter. Same-store sales up 5%. Company transactions are up 8%. I think a combination of the $6.99 pairs and the $5 flavor menu have certainly worked. And obvious
componenttext: Yes, certainly, Joe. I think the good news, as you said, is Pizza Hut U.S. had an excellent quarter. Same-store sales up 5%. Company transactions are up 8%. I think a combination of the $6.99 pairs and the $5 flavor menu have certainly worked. And obviously, what we're doing now is in the process of taking that success and all the tactics that are associated with that and expanding that rapidly on a global basis. So like all things, these businesses are very much driven by our U.S. success, and I think what we're doing now is in the process of rolling out that U.S. success and taking it around on a global basis. I happened to be in Thailand actually in January earlier in the year, and you can see already that, that team was starting to take the successful tactics that were working and start to see how we can implement those in that country, and that's happening around the world.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two unrelated questions, if I may. First one for you, Micky. For a number of years now, labor cost, labor dollars per operating week in China have been a pretty major contributor to margins. As you do plan to regrow customer traffic, obviously, in the seg
componenttext: Two unrelated questions, if I may. First one for you, Micky. For a number of years now, labor cost, labor dollars per operating week in China have been a pretty major contributor to margins. As you do plan to regrow customer traffic, obviously, in the segment and want to stay competitive with wages. I mean, are we at the point now where labor starts to inflect the other way and adding back costs into the system that have been taken out over the last several years?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's true that over the last 5 years, labor has inflated in China on account of minimum wage increases by the government, but we've seen a moderation of that. I think the authority has recognized that the economy has to be supported, so I think we'r
componenttext: Well, it's true that over the last 5 years, labor has inflated in China on account of minimum wage increases by the government, but we've seen a moderation of that. I think the authority has recognized that the economy has to be supported, so I think we're seeing a more reasonable picture there. What we did get in the quarter, particularly, was some good productivity gains on account of using more part-time and student labor, which is a phenomena that did not exist in China in the long past, and that is making a difference. So looking forward, it's always a risk, but I don't see labor price inflation as being a significant risk. I think the key for us is going to be product innovation, sensible pricing and get traffic scores back. So I hope that helps.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, I thought the commentary on the capital structure was interesting in that part of the new capital structure is going to be a royalty securitization only to Taco Bell, which I don't think your previously -- your previous debt actually as
componenttext: And then secondly, I thought the commentary on the capital structure was interesting in that part of the new capital structure is going to be a royalty securitization only to Taco Bell, which I don't think your previously -- your previous debt actually assigned itself to individual brands. So I just wanted to understand the symbolism behind the debt security that's only related to Taco Bell. And could people's imagination start to think that Taco Bell doesn't necessarily remain a part of Yum! over the long term as an opportunity arises?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, it's Larry Gathof. I'll answer the debt aspect of it anyways, but what we're doing is we're trying to take advantage of the debt markets in total. So we're looking at doing both the securitization, bank and bond debt. So we're putting debt across al
componenttext: John, it's Larry Gathof. I'll answer the debt aspect of it anyways, but what we're doing is we're trying to take advantage of the debt markets in total. So we're looking at doing both the securitization, bank and bond debt. So we're putting debt across all the different avenues to, again, take the -- get the best pricing and optimize our balance sheet. The Taco Bell securitization is only going to be on the U.S. Taco Bell franchise and licensees, so it's just that part. The Taco -- the rest of the Taco Bell business will also be part of the other borrowings. So again, the securitization market, quite honestly, isn't deep enough to do any one of our entire businesses. So we just peeled off the piece that we thought was most appropriate for securitization and are accessing that market. And then again, we'll have the balance of the borrowings across all 3 brands after that's completed.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So John, to put it bluntly, I wouldn't want anyone to take away any thinking that we're going to be doing anything to Taco Bell other than love it as a part of the portfolio, love its growth, love its profit contribution and love that it is a brand that w
componenttext: So John, to put it bluntly, I wouldn't want anyone to take away any thinking that we're going to be doing anything to Taco Bell other than love it as a part of the portfolio, love its growth, love its profit contribution and love that it is a brand that we can take global.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Keith Siegner with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Keith Siegner with UBS.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, just a question for you. Having come from the Taco Bell brand and having watched that brand be one of the leaders in terms of overall digital engagement, mobile ordering and more, where do you -- how do you feel about the rest of the U.S. portfolio
componenttext: Greg, just a question for you. Having come from the Taco Bell brand and having watched that brand be one of the leaders in terms of overall digital engagement, mobile ordering and more, where do you -- how do you feel about the rest of the U.S. portfolio and positioning now? Are you making the progress you want? Is Pizza Hut becoming more of a leader in its category? Is KFC also coming along? And then -- and what about tests on delivery for other brands, like home meal replacement for KFC and even for Taco Bell? Is the rest of the U.S. portfolio catching up to Taco Bell? How -- where do we stand?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Keith, it's a good question, and I would say yes. I think the great thing is we can codify what makes Taco Bell successful. And obviously, the other 2 brands can obviously track with what they've done and obviously attempt to replicate it, but in their ow
componenttext: Keith, it's a good question, and I would say yes. I think the great thing is we can codify what makes Taco Bell successful. And obviously, the other 2 brands can obviously track with what they've done and obviously attempt to replicate it, but in their own brand voice. So I'm very pleased with the progress that Pizza Hut is making. I think there's positioning around making it easier to get a better pizza. I think the -- not only the sales growth, but the transaction growth that we just got. Obviously, part of making it easier was to get our value better on Pizza Hut, which we have done. But I think you -- as we also said on the call, we are investing in technology. We do need to get from 9 POS systems down to 1 POS system. But as we also said, 46% of our delivery/carryout sales are digital, and that's growing. So I do think we're making good progress there. On the KFC side, I think the Always Original positioning to move back to "finger lickin' good". The great thing about KFC in the U.S. is it's a brand that's now being talked about. And I think for a long time, it wasn't on anyone's radar screen. So I'm very comfortable. I think the launch of Nashville Hot has really helped. Obviously, there's a value game being played by the burger boys because of beef pricing, but I think the return of $5 boxes has been a good move by the KFC team. And then for Taco Bell, yes, the answer is we -- I think we're now in 500 stores doing delivery in a couple of the key cities, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Dallas. I'm not quite sure where else, but -- so that's been expanded. And I think if you just take the overall concept of "easy beats better," which I know the Pizza Hut team originated, but what it basically says is, "Yes, we've got to find ways to make it easier for our people, for customers to get to our brand." But we do that 2 ways: we build more units, but we also obviously will start looking at delivery as a way to get our food to customers in their homes. So a very good question. We are making progress. The other brands, I think, are moving to where the Taco Bell brand strength is. A lot of work to be done, but I think we're moving in the right direction, and I'm encouraged by that.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from David Tarantino with Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from David Tarantino with Baird.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is on the guidance for the year, and I was wondering if you could provide some additional detail or insight on what you're assuming for China profit growth for the year in that guidance, and maybe also the margin that you expect to deliver in
componenttext: My question is on the guidance for the year, and I was wondering if you could provide some additional detail or insight on what you're assuming for China profit growth for the year in that guidance, and maybe also the margin that you expect to deliver in that business for the full year.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So the first thing I'd say is if you're going to have a good quarter at Yum!, you want it to be the first quarter of the year, which is what we certainly did, and had a blowout quarter in China. So when we looked at that first quarter, as well as so
componenttext: Sure. So the first thing I'd say is if you're going to have a good quarter at Yum!, you want it to be the first quarter of the year, which is what we certainly did, and had a blowout quarter in China. So when we looked at that first quarter, as well as some of the other -- the tailwinds we have in the business with regards to the VAT we talked about earlier, though we -- it is very difficult to quantify but that we know there's something there, some of the commodity deflation that we're seeing. We felt very confident that even with some of the other headwinds we're facing, particularly Pizza Hut Casual Dining in China, of getting to a number that was 12% for the year. We -- as we said, we have not yet -- we have not adjusted the same-store sales forecast for the balance of the year for China. It's just too difficult to call, given we're only 2 -- 3.5 months in. But at this point, we feel very comfortable with the 12%.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, the way I look at it is, to raise guidance in the first quarter demonstrates the degree of confidence we've got in the year. As we said, there'd be some puts and calls as the year unfolds, no doubt, but we felt confident in raising it from 10% to
componenttext: I mean, the way I look at it is, to raise guidance in the first quarter demonstrates the degree of confidence we've got in the year. As we said, there'd be some puts and calls as the year unfolds, no doubt, but we felt confident in raising it from 10% to 12%.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you asked specifically about the margins in China. I mean, given -- they're so dependent upon sales, we're still thinking somewhere along -- we're not coming off our guidance from the beginning of the year, around 16% at this point.
componenttext: And you asked specifically about the margins in China. I mean, given -- they're so dependent upon sales, we're still thinking somewhere along -- we're not coming off our guidance from the beginning of the year, around 16% at this point.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess -- if I'm still on, I guess, if the margin guidance still is around 16% for the year, I guess, I'm a little confused on that, given the overperformance in Q1. Was there something that changed about the outlook for the last 3 quarters? Or is th
componenttext: And I guess -- if I'm still on, I guess, if the margin guidance still is around 16% for the year, I guess, I'm a little confused on that, given the overperformance in Q1. Was there something that changed about the outlook for the last 3 quarters? Or is this some level of conservatism that you're basing in or perhaps...

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think so. I don't think we're thinking about it necessarily in that level of detail. I think we're saying it's just too early. We're off to a great start. With the Q1 success that we had, we feel very good with the 12%, but I don't think you s
componenttext: No, I don't think so. I don't think we're thinking about it necessarily in that level of detail. I think we're saying it's just too early. We're off to a great start. With the Q1 success that we had, we feel very good with the 12%, but I don't think you should be reading that into the balance of your forecast.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Bernstein with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Bernstein with Barclays.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two things. Just one, I'm hoping to get a little bit more color from Micky on the China side, obviously, with the short-term strength, which seems to be attributed to the New Year's promotion. Just wondering how, in your mind, you perhaps separate that fr
componenttext: Two things. Just one, I'm hoping to get a little bit more color from Micky on the China side, obviously, with the short-term strength, which seems to be attributed to the New Year's promotion. Just wondering how, in your mind, you perhaps separate that from the longer-term recovery efforts? Just, I mean, it seems like you're confident that the brand, I think you said, has really turned, but then it seems like maybe in March and in April things have really eased. And just wondering how you think about the business over the next 12 months in terms of just short-term spikes because of promotion versus kind of the long-term trajectory improving, and then I had one follow-up on Taco Bell U.S.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, thanks, Jeffrey. Like I said, I think the team and myself are feeling very much more confident. We just, this week, had all of our store managers. So we had a stadium in the city of Dalian with 8,000 people talking about the theme for the futur
componenttext: Yes, well, thanks, Jeffrey. Like I said, I think the team and myself are feeling very much more confident. We just, this week, had all of our store managers. So we had a stadium in the city of Dalian with 8,000 people talking about the theme for the future, which is from "strength to strength." And in particular, when the KFC section was discussed, and we put out plans for the rest of the year and the positioning and the proposed marketing, there was just unbounded confidence. I feel that -- I really feel the brand is making a lot of progress. It is much stronger. I think the positioning is very clear. The calendars are strong. We are doing sensible things around the core of the brand. We've already cleaned up the menu boards. We will do that even more. We're introducing proven international winners. I think you always have to be cautious when it's -- when you come to China because there is economic volatility and there is also unexpected twists and turns. So there's nothing hidden. It's not as though we are worried about some specific event or there's something happening that causes us to worry, but we just want to be cautious. We've had 2 or 3 years of a lot of volatility. So the way we're looking at it right now is it's a "show me, don't tell me" sort of story, and we're hoping quarter after quarter to improve and strengthen the business. I think it's been mentioned a number of times, Q2 is going to be a difficult quarter on account of a variety of factors, but we are very focused on seeing whether we can deliver positive same-store sales and take it from there. So on KFC, I feel confident. I feel that the brand is making a lot of progress. And the other thing we didn't talk about today is we that we've spent a lot of energy and are going to be taking very good care of store refurbishment. So we have good designs, we've got good plans for aggressive refurbs in some of our older stores. We are opening a symbolically important 5,000th store in Shanghai, which is I think maybe the best KFC in the world. It's a state-of-the-art green store, which will open next week. Also, I think the brand is making progress on every front. On Pizza Hut, like I said before, I'm very disappointed it's at negative same-store sales, and I don't see any reason why we cannot turn it around. There's no entrance decrees [ph] and all our scores are good, our competitive position is fantastic. There really is no international competitor with the name. And in addition to the 1,500 dine-in stores, we've got about 300 delivery units, which are -- dwarfed the competition. So I feel the brands are really genuinely making progress. It's just that it's been 2 months. The first quarter was 2 months, and to make a call on the rest of the year, knowing what we've seen over the last 3 years, seems to be out of the bounds of what we should be doing. So that hopefully gives you some context on the way we're looking at it.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: For sure. And then just, Greg, I just wanted to follow up. You made a comment about the Taco Bell U.S. It seems like maybe it was a little light of your internal expectation, which I think you attributed to maybe some of the QSR burger competitors taking
componenttext: For sure. And then just, Greg, I just wanted to follow up. You made a comment about the Taco Bell U.S. It seems like maybe it was a little light of your internal expectation, which I think you attributed to maybe some of the QSR burger competitors taking advantage of favorable beef. So I'm just wondering, just to get a better understanding of your response, does it seem like you're now getting more aggressive presumably on value? I know you've obviously been with the brand for a long time and gone through these phases before, but just the idea that you progressively pursue the discounting versus kind of staying the course with your initial plan. Just trying to get your thoughts.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jeffrey. I think the first thing I want to do is just correct that apparently in my prepared remarks, I think I said the breakfast mix was 8%. It's actually 6%. The 8% is actually the transaction growth that we've got in breakfast in Q1, so I just w
componenttext: Sure, Jeffrey. I think the first thing I want to do is just correct that apparently in my prepared remarks, I think I said the breakfast mix was 8%. It's actually 6%. The 8% is actually the transaction growth that we've got in breakfast in Q1, so I just want to clarify that. By the way, I'm very happy with 8% transaction growth in breakfast with one of our competitors doing all-day breakfast, so let me just say that. So to answer your question, yes, we had tied the launch of the Quesalupa to the Super Bowl. I tried to get the Super Bowl brought forward a couple of weeks because that would have really helped us, but unfortunately, the NFL wasn't going to play along. So we were so tied up to the launch with that event that there was a couple of weeks where we were a little naked, I would say. And so obviously, sales and transactions up to there were soft. The good news is that after that event, the Quesalupa had mix of over 10% and has done well for us. But I think even more importantly, Brian, who is doing a great job leading the brand, had -- he and the team have already changed the calendar. And in fact, today, we will launch some new $1 items into the marketplace. There's been a number of revisions to the calendar. So I think we can still be an incredibly innovative brand, a socially conscious brand, led by digital, but we can also just get out value so it's more than competitive in the marketplace. And I think talking to Brian the other day, he and I have -- still have a lot of confidence we'll deliver the at least 3% same-store sales growth for the year at Taco Bell.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Howard Penney with Hedgeye Risk Management.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Howard Penney with Hedgeye Risk Management.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could help me with the Chinese culture and what the zodiac calendar and chicken means next year in terms of what that asset potentially could do for business.
componenttext: I was wondering if you could help me with the Chinese culture and what the zodiac calendar and chicken means next year in terms of what that asset potentially could do for business.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think -- I don't think it is a very serious factor, frankly. I mean, the year of the dragon and the monkey are of particular significance. Every year is important. One interesting feature that Joey and the team put together was they actually introd
componenttext: Yes, I think -- I don't think it is a very serious factor, frankly. I mean, the year of the dragon and the monkey are of particular significance. Every year is important. One interesting feature that Joey and the team put together was they actually introduced a Christmas bucket in 2015 December, which was reasonably successful, so they're dialing that up. So I think the point really is that if we do a good bucket-oriented for the calendar in December for Christmas and then Chinese New Year next year, we can look to a good performance. The success of the monkey -- the year of the monkey promotion has shown to us the importance of choosing the character well, the toys that go with it, the kid's meals that accompany it, which will all help us to build for the future. And I think the year of the chicken does help. I mean there's no better authority on chicken than KFC, but I don't think it's going to be culturally that significant that people have to eat chicken in the year of the chicken or something like that. It's a help. And all I was saying was that to lap this very successful year of the monkey promotion, that's one little gift on our side.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I could -- sorry. So Greg, 9 months ago, obviously, the quarter wasn't as strong as you would've hoped, and then we go through the process of you spinning out the China business and talking about the change of the structure of the company, and now
componenttext: And if I could -- sorry. So Greg, 9 months ago, obviously, the quarter wasn't as strong as you would've hoped, and then we go through the process of you spinning out the China business and talking about the change of the structure of the company, and now 9 months forward, things look a lot better. I was wondering if you could maybe put tangible evidence around an intangible question, and that is what sort of the changes internally to the employees of Yum! and Yum! China has done to help turn the business around. I don't know if I'm asking that correctly, but I think part of the reason for doing this spin was maybe to focus on the different assets. And I mean, this, obviously, was a fantastic quarter and for all those reasons -- maybe some of those reasons. I don't -- I'm struggling to ask the question properly, but I'm just wondering if some of them -- sorry, go ahead.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Howard, I'll have a go. I think I couldn't be happier to have Micky leading the team. Micky has an enormous amount of just experience, has the confidence of all of us and did an amazing job running our international business for such a long of period of t
componenttext: Howard, I'll have a go. I think I couldn't be happier to have Micky leading the team. Micky has an enormous amount of just experience, has the confidence of all of us and did an amazing job running our international business for such a long of period of time on all 3 brands. So I've got a leader in there who I have the utmost confidence in and who has rallied the team in China. We've got great people leading the brands, Joey and Peter. I mean, they're just -- they're really having -- I was there in March, looking at the plans, looking at what they've learned from the lessons. Our culture is alive and well in China. So the whole recognition culture, and our belief that culture fuels results I think was absolutely evident. And I think at the same time, what's also happening in the whole business is that we're getting much better at brand building and strengthening our brand positioning. And so I think, China, I would say the words aren't exactly Always Original. I think it's Be Your True Self, but they pretty much resonate. We've now got this brand on a global positioning, so we can leverage things. Micky has reached out and taken things like the $5 boxes that had been incredibly successful in a number of markets. As he said, they will go into the market soon in China. The Pizza Hut team is looking at a new positioning for Pizza Hut. And as Micky said, I think focusing on the pizza and less on the more and getting back to the core will help that brand as well. So I would sum it up as new leader, great leader, fresh perspective, great team, more global alignment and a real focus on brand building, all underpinned by our fundamental belief that we leverage culture to fuel results.
