componenttext: That's the number for the divisions.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We had positive transactions at KFC. And as I said that the transaction numbers we measure is the number of tickets we cut in the store. But as I explained, the size of the ticket is bigger on account of the shareable meals, principally the bucket. So we
componenttext: We had positive transactions at KFC. And as I said that the transaction numbers we measure is the number of tickets we cut in the store. But as I explained, the size of the ticket is bigger on account of the shareable meals, principally the bucket. So we estimate that the price impact on our sales is about 3%, and the rest of it is on account of traffic plus a larger check on account of more items being bought. So it was a fairly healthy growth.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just switching topics for a moment. Pizza Hut U.S. numbers looked pretty good. Pizza Hut international is slightly negative. Can you talk a little bit about Pizza Hut international and kind of what's going on there and what changes you can implem
componenttext: And then just switching topics for a moment. Pizza Hut U.S. numbers looked pretty good. Pizza Hut international is slightly negative. Can you talk a little bit about Pizza Hut international and kind of what's going on there and what changes you can implement there?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, certainly, Joe. I think the good news, as you said, is Pizza Hut U.S. had an excellent quarter. Same-store sales up 5%. Company transactions are up 8%. I think a combination of the $6.99 pairs and the $5 flavor menu have certainly worked. And obvious
componenttext: Yes, certainly, Joe. I think the good news, as you said, is Pizza Hut U.S. had an excellent quarter. Same-store sales up 5%. Company transactions are up 8%. I think a combination of the $6.99 pairs and the $5 flavor menu have certainly worked. And obviously, what we're doing now is in the process of taking that success and all the tactics that are associated with that and expanding that rapidly on a global basis. So like all things, these businesses are very much driven by our U.S. success. And I think what we're doing now is in the process of rolling out that U.S. success and taking it around on a global basis. I happened to be in Thailand actually in January earlier in the year, and you can see already that, that team was starting to take the successful tactics that were working and start to see how we can implement those in that country, and that's happening around the world.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two unrelated questions, if I may. First one for you, Micky. For a number of years now, labor costs, labor dollars per operating week in China have been a pretty major contributor to margins. As you do plan to regrow customer traffic, obviously, in the se
componenttext: Two unrelated questions, if I may. First one for you, Micky. For a number of years now, labor costs, labor dollars per operating week in China have been a pretty major contributor to margins. As you do plan to regrow customer traffic, obviously, in the segment and want to stay competitive with wages. I mean, are we at the point now where labor starts to inflect the other way and adding back costs into the system that have been taken out over the last several years?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's true that over the last 5 years, labor has inflated in China on account of minimum wage increases by the government, but we've seen a moderation of that. I think the authorities has recognized that the economy has to be supported, so I think we
componenttext: Well, it's true that over the last 5 years, labor has inflated in China on account of minimum wage increases by the government, but we've seen a moderation of that. I think the authorities has recognized that the economy has to be supported, so I think we're seeing a more reasonable picture there. What we did get in the quarter, particularly, was some good productivity gains on account of using more part-time and student labor, which is a phenomena that did not exist in China in the long past, and that is making a difference. So looking forward, it's always a risk, but I don't see labor price inflation as being a significant risk. I think the key for us is going to be product innovation, sensible pricing and get traffic scores back. So I hope that helps.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, I thought the commentary on the capital structure was interesting in that part of the new capital structure is going to be a royalty securitization only to Taco Bell, which I don't think your previously -- your previous debt actually as
componenttext: And then secondly, I thought the commentary on the capital structure was interesting in that part of the new capital structure is going to be a royalty securitization only to Taco Bell, which I don't think your previously -- your previous debt actually assigned itself to individual brands. So I just wanted to understand the symbolism behind the debt security that's only related to Taco Bell. And could people's imagination start to think that Taco Bell doesn't necessarily remain a part of Yum! over the long term as an opportunity arises?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, it's Larry Gathof. I'll answer the debt aspect of it anyway, but what we're doing is we're trying to take advantage of the debt markets in total. So we're looking at doing both the securitization, bank and bond debt. So we're putting debt across all
componenttext: John, it's Larry Gathof. I'll answer the debt aspect of it anyway, but what we're doing is we're trying to take advantage of the debt markets in total. So we're looking at doing both the securitization, bank and bond debt. So we're putting debt across all the different avenues to, again, take the -- get the best pricing and optimize our balance sheet. The Taco Bell securitization is only going to be on the U.S. Taco Bell franchise and license fees, so it's just that part. The Taco -- the rest of the Taco Bell business will also be part of the other borrowings. So again, the securitization market, quite honestly, isn't deep enough to do any one of our entire businesses. So we just peeled off the piece that we thought was most appropriate for securitization and are accessing that market. And then again, we'll have the balance of the borrowings across all 3 brands after that's completed.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So John, to put it bluntly, I wouldn't want anyone to take away any thinking that we're going to be doing anything to Taco Bell other than love it as a part of the portfolio, love its growth, love its profit contribution and love that it is a brand that w
componenttext: So John, to put it bluntly, I wouldn't want anyone to take away any thinking that we're going to be doing anything to Taco Bell other than love it as a part of the portfolio, love its growth, love its profit contribution and love that it is a brand that we can take global.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Keith Siegner with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Keith Siegner with UBS.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, just a question for you. Having come from the Taco Bell brand and having watched that brand be one of the leaders in terms of overall digital engagement, mobile ordering and more, where do you -- how do you feel about the rest of the U.S. portfolio
componenttext: Greg, just a question for you. Having come from the Taco Bell brand and having watched that brand be one of the leaders in terms of overall digital engagement, mobile ordering and more, where do you -- how do you feel about the rest of the U.S. portfolio and positioning now? Are you making the progress you want? Is Pizza Hut becoming more of a leader in its category? Is KFC also coming along? And then -- and what about tests on delivery for other brands, like home meal replacement for KFC and even for Taco Bell? Is the rest of the U.S. portfolio catching up to Taco Bell? How -- where do we stand?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Keith, it's a good question, and I would say yes. I think the great thing is we can codify what makes Taco Bell successful. And obviously, the other 2 brands can obviously track with what they've done and obviously attempt to replicate it, but in their ow
componenttext: Keith, it's a good question, and I would say yes. I think the great thing is we can codify what makes Taco Bell successful. And obviously, the other 2 brands can obviously track with what they've done and obviously attempt to replicate it, but in their own brand voice. So I'm very pleased with the progress that Pizza Hut is making. I think its positioning around making it easier to get a better pizza. I think the -- not only the sales growth, but the transaction growth that we just got. Obviously, part of making it easier was to get our value better on Pizza Hut, which we have done. But I think you -- as we also said on the call, we are investing in technology. We do need to get from 9 POS systems down to 1 POS system. But as we also said, 46% of our delivery/carryout sales are digital, and that's growing. So I do think we're making good progress there. On the KFC side, I think the Always Original positioning to move back to "finger lickin' good". The great thing about KFC in the U.S. is it's a brand that's now being talked about. And I think for a long time, it wasn't on anyone's radar screen. So I'm very comfortable. I think the launch of Nashville Hot has really helped. Obviously, there's a value game being played by the burger boys because of beef pricing, but I think the return of $5 boxes has been a good move by the KFC team. And then for Taco Bell, yes, the answer is we -- I think we're now in 500 stores doing delivery in a couple of the key cities, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Dallas. I'm not quite sure where else, but -- so that's been expanded. And I think if you just take the overall concept of "easy beats better," which I know the Pizza Hut team originated, but what it basically says is, "Yes, we've got to find ways to make it easier for our people, for customers to get to our brand." And we do that two ways: we build more units, but we also obviously will start looking at delivery as a way to get our food to customers in their homes. So very good question. We are making progress. The other brands, I think, are moving to where the Taco Bell brand strength is. A lot of work to be done, but I think we're moving in the right direction, and I'm encouraged by that.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from David Tarantino with Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from David Tarantino with Baird.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is on the guidance for the year, and I was wondering if you could provide some additional detail or insight on what you're assuming for China profit growth for the year in that guidance, and maybe also the margin that you expect to deliver in
componenttext: My question is on the guidance for the year, and I was wondering if you could provide some additional detail or insight on what you're assuming for China profit growth for the year in that guidance, and maybe also the margin that you expect to deliver in that business for the full year.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So the first thing I'd say is if you're going to have a good quarter at Yum!, you want it to be the first quarter of the year, which is what we certainly did, and had a blowout quarter in China. So when we looked at that first quarter, as well as so
componenttext: Sure. So the first thing I'd say is if you're going to have a good quarter at Yum!, you want it to be the first quarter of the year, which is what we certainly did, and had a blowout quarter in China. So when we looked at that first quarter, as well as some of the other -- the tailwinds we have in the business with regards to the VAT we talked about earlier, though we  it is very difficult to quantify but that we know there's something there, some of the commodity deflation that we're seeing. We felt very confident that even with some of the other headwinds we're facing, particularly Pizza Hut Casual Dining in China, of getting to a number that was 12% for the year. We -- as we said, we have not yet -- we have not adjusted the same-store sales forecast for the balance of the year for China. It's just too difficult to call, given we're only 2 -- 3.5 months in. But at this point, we feel very comfortable with the 12%.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, the way I look at it is, to raise guidance in the first quarter demonstrates the degree of confidence we've got in the year. As we said, there'll be some puts and calls as the year unfolds, no doubt, but we felt confident in raising it from 10% to
componenttext: I mean, the way I look at it is, to raise guidance in the first quarter demonstrates the degree of confidence we've got in the year. As we said, there'll be some puts and calls as the year unfolds, no doubt, but we felt confident in raising it from 10% to 12%.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you asked specifically about the margins in China. I mean, given -- they're so dependent upon sales, we're still thinking somewhere along -- we're not coming off our guidance from the beginning of the year, around 16 at this point.
componenttext: And you asked specifically about the margins in China. I mean, given -- they're so dependent upon sales, we're still thinking somewhere along -- we're not coming off our guidance from the beginning of the year, around 16 at this point.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess -- if I'm still on, I guess, if the margin guidance still is around 16 for the year, I guess, I'm a little confused on that, given the overperformance in Q1. Was there something that changed about the outlook for the last 3 quarters? Or is thi
componenttext: And I guess -- if I'm still on, I guess, if the margin guidance still is around 16 for the year, I guess, I'm a little confused on that, given the overperformance in Q1. Was there something that changed about the outlook for the last 3 quarters? Or is this some level of conservatism that you're baking in or perhaps...

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think so. I don't think we're thinking about it necessarily in that level of detail. I think we're saying it's just too early. We're off to a great start. With the Q1 success that we had, we feel very good with the 12%, but I don't think you s
componenttext: No, I don't think so. I don't think we're thinking about it necessarily in that level of detail. I think we're saying it's just too early. We're off to a great start. With the Q1 success that we had, we feel very good with the 12%, but I don't think you should be reading that into the balance of your forecast.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Bernstein with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Bernstein with Barclays.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two things. Just one, I'm hoping to get a little bit more color from Micky on the China side, obviously, with the short-term strength, which seems to be attributed to the New Year's promotion. Just wondering how, in your mind, you perhaps separate that fr
componenttext: Two things. Just one, I'm hoping to get a little bit more color from Micky on the China side, obviously, with the short-term strength, which seems to be attributed to the New Year's promotion. Just wondering how, in your mind, you perhaps separate that from the longer-term recovery efforts? Just, I mean, it seems like you're confident that the brand, I think you said, has really turned, but then it seems like maybe in March and in April things have really eased. Im just wondering how you think of the business over the next 12 months in terms of just short-term spikes because of promotion versus kind of the long-term trajectory improving. And then I had one follow-up on Taco Bell U.S.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, thanks, Jeffrey. Like I said, I think the team and myself are feeling very much more confident. We just, this week, had all of our store managers, who we had a stadium in the City of Dhabia with 8,000 people talking about the theme for the futu
componenttext: Yes, well, thanks, Jeffrey. Like I said, I think the team and myself are feeling very much more confident. We just, this week, had all of our store managers, who we had a stadium in the City of Dhabia with 8,000 people talking about the theme for the future, which is from "strength to strength." And in particular, when the KFC section was discussed, and we put out plans for the rest of the year and the positioning and the proposed marketing, there was just unbounded confidence. So I feel that -- I really feel the brand is making a lot of progress. It is much stronger. I think the positioning is very clear. The calendars are strong. We are doing sensible things around the core of the brand. We've already cleaned up the menu boards. We will do that even more. We're introducing proven international winners. I think you always have to be cautious when it's -- when you come to China because there is economic volatility and there is also unexpected twists and turns. So there's nothing hidden. It's not as though we are worried about some specific event or there's something happening that causes us to worry, but we just want to be cautious. We've had two or three years of a lot of volatility. So the way we're looking at it right now is it's a "show me, don't tell me" sort of story, and we're hoping quarter after quarter to improve and strengthen the business. I think it's been mentioned a number of times, Q2 is going to be a difficult quarter on account of a variety of factors, but we are very focused on seeing whether we can deliver positive same-store sales and take it from there. So on KFC, I feel confident. I feel that the brand is making a lot of progress. And the other thing we didn't talk about today is we that we've spent a lot of energy and are going to be taking very good care of store refurbishment. So we have good designs, we've got good plans for aggressive refurbs in some of our older stores. We are opening a symbolically important 5,000th store in Shanghai, which is I think maybe the best KFC in the world. It's a state-of-the-art green store, which will open next week. Also, I think the brand is making progress on every front. On Pizza Hut, like I said before, I'm very disappointed it's at negative same-store sales, and I don't see any reason why we cannot turn it around. There's no entrance decrees [ph] and all our scores are good, our competitive position is fantastic. There really is no international competitor with the name. And in addition to the 1,500 dine-in stores, we've got about 300 delivery units, which are -- dwarfed the competition. So I feel the brands are really genuinely making progress. It's just that it's been two months. The first quarter was two months. And to make a call on the rest of the year, knowing what we've seen over the last three years, seems to be out of the bounds of what we should be doing. So that hopefully gives you some context on the way we're looking at it.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: For sure. And then just, Greg, I just wanted to follow up. You made a comment about the Taco Bell U.S. It seems like maybe it was a little light of your internal expectation, which I think you attributed to maybe some of the QSR burger competitors taking
componenttext: For sure. And then just, Greg, I just wanted to follow up. You made a comment about the Taco Bell U.S. It seems like maybe it was a little light of your internal expectation, which I think you attributed to maybe some of the QSR burger competitors taking advantage of favorable beef. So I'm just wondering, just to get a better understanding of your response, does it seem like you're now getting more aggressive presumably on value? I know you've obviously been with the brand for a long time and gone through these phases before, but just the idea that you progressively pursue the discounting versus kind of staying the course with your initial plan? Just trying to get your thoughts.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jeffrey. I think the first thing I want to do is just correct that apparently in my prepared remarks, I think I said the breakfast mix was 8%. It's actually 6%. The 8% is actually the transaction growth that we've got in breakfast in Q1, so I just w
componenttext: Sure, Jeffrey. I think the first thing I want to do is just correct that apparently in my prepared remarks, I think I said the breakfast mix was 8%. It's actually 6%. The 8% is actually the transaction growth that we've got in breakfast in Q1, so I just want to clarify that. By the way, I'm very happy with 8% transaction growth in breakfast with one of our competitors doing all-day breakfast. So let me just say that. So to answer your question, yes, we had tied the launch of the Quesalupa to the Super Bowl. I tried to get the Super Bowl moved forward a couple of weeks because that would have really helped us, but unfortunately, the NFL wasn't going to play along. So we were so tied up to the launch with that event that there was a couple of weeks where we were a little naked, I would say. And so obviously, sales and transactions up to there were soft. The good news is that after that event, the Quesalupa had mix of over 10% and has done well for us. But I think even more importantly, Brian, who is doing a great job leading the brand, had -- he and the team have already changed the calendar. And in fact, today, we will launch some new $1 items into the marketplace. There's been a number of revisions to the calendar. So I think we can still be an incredibly innovative brand, a socially conscious brand, led by digital, but we can also just get out value so it's more than competitive in the marketplace. And I think talking to Brian the other day, he and I have -- still have a lot of confidence we'll deliver the at least 3% same-store sales growth for the year at Taco Bell.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Howard Penney with Hedgeye Risk Management.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Howard Penney with Hedgeye Risk Management.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could help me with the Chinese culture and what the zodiac calendar and chicken means next year in terms of what that asset potentially could do for business.
componenttext: I was wondering if you could help me with the Chinese culture and what the zodiac calendar and chicken means next year in terms of what that asset potentially could do for business.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think -- I don't think it is a very serious factor, frankly. I mean, the year of the dragon and the monkey are of particular significance. Every year is important. One interesting feature that Joey and the team put together was they actually introd
componenttext: Yes, I think -- I don't think it is a very serious factor, frankly. I mean, the year of the dragon and the monkey are of particular significance. Every year is important. One interesting feature that Joey and the team put together was they actually introduced a Christmas bucket in 2015 December, which was reasonably successful, so they're dialing that up. So I think the point really is that if we do a good bucket-oriented for the calendar in December for Christmas and then Chinese New Year next year, we can look to a good performance. The success of the monkey -- the year of the monkey promotion has shown to us the importance of choosing the character well, the toys that go with it, the kids meals that accompany it, which will all help us to build for the future. And I think the year of the chicken does help. I mean there's no better authority on chicken than KFC, but I don't think it's going to be culturally that significant. People have to eat chickens in the year of the chicken or something like that. So it's a help, and all I was saying was that to lap this very successful year of the monkey promotion. So that's one little gift on our side.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I could -- sorry. So Greg, 9 months ago, obviously, the quarter wasn't as strong as you would've hoped, and then we go through the process of you spinning out the China business and talking about the change of the structure of the company, and now
componenttext: And if I could -- sorry. So Greg, 9 months ago, obviously, the quarter wasn't as strong as you would've hoped, and then we go through the process of you spinning out the China business and talking about the change of the structure of the company, and now 9 months forward, things look a lot better. I was wondering if you could maybe put tangible evidence around an intangible question, and that is what sort of the changes internally to the employees of Yum! and Yum! China has done to help turn the business around. I don't know if I'm asking that correctly, but I think part of the reason for doing this spin was maybe to focus on the different assets. And I mean, this, obviously, was a fantastic quarter and for all those reasons -- maybe some of those reasons. I don't -- I'm struggling to ask the question properly, but I'm just wondering if some of them -- sorry, go ahead.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Howard, I'll have a go. I think I couldn't be happier to have Micky leading the team. Micky has an enormous amount of just experience, has the confidence of all of us and did an amazing job running our international business for such a long of period of t
componenttext: Howard, I'll have a go. I think I couldn't be happier to have Micky leading the team. Micky has an enormous amount of just experience, has the confidence of all of us and did an amazing job running our international business for such a long of period of time on all 3 brands. So I've got a leader in there who I have the utmost confidence in and who has rallied the team in China. We've got great people leading the brands, Joey and Peter. I mean, they're just -- they're really having -- I was there in March, looking at the plans, looking at what they've learned from the lessons. Our culture is alive and well in China. So the whole recognition culture, and our belief that culture fuels results I think was absolutely evident. And I think at the same time, what's also happening in the whole business is that we're getting much better at brand building and strengthening our brand positioning. And so I think, China, I would say the words aren't exactly Always Original. I think it's be your true self, but they pretty much resonate. We have now got this brand on a global positioning, so we can leverage things. Micky has reached out and taken things like the $5 boxes that had been incredibly successful in a number of markets. As he said, they will go into the market soon in China. The Pizza Hut team is looking at a new positioning for Pizza Hut, and as Micky said, I think focusing on the pizza and less on the more and getting back to the core will help that brand as well. So I would sum it up as new leader, great leader, fresh perspective, great team, more global alignment and a real focus on brand building, all underpinned by our fundamental belief that we leverage culture to fuel results.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of Brian Bittner with Oppenheimer and Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Brian Bittner with Oppenheimer and Company.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to ask a question on Taco Bell. You did roll out your pretty aggressive $1 breakfast menu in March, you said. So it didn't really impact the full first quarter. Can you just talk about how this is impacting the overall business? Is it accretiv
componenttext: I just want to ask a question on Taco Bell. You did roll out your pretty aggressive $1 breakfast menu in March, you said. So it didn't really impact the full first quarter. Can you just talk about how this is impacting the overall business? Is it accretive to your sales trends? Is it doing what you expected it to do? And externally, us looking at the margin, how should we think about how this impacts the food margin going forward, or the COGS margin?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the good news is, as I said, we had 8% transaction growth in the breakfast daypart in the first quarter before we really got the full impact of the $1 menu. So I think we feel really good that that's going to continue to have an impact on ou
componenttext: Well, I think the good news is, as I said, we had 8% transaction growth in the breakfast daypart in the first quarter before we really got the full impact of the $1 menu. So I think we feel really good that that's going to continue to have an impact on our breakfast business. Our food and paper cost for breakfast are in line with the balance of the business. So whether it grows or -- grows faster or slower, doesn't really impact the overall food and paper cost. The good news is, obviously, Taco Bell is benefiting from the price of beef right now, and that's obviously why you're seeing in the marketplace a lot of value by both the burger chains and why Taco Bell can play an aggressive play in beef as well and...

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would just add, Brian, that at 6% mix, the breakfast doesn't change the overall Taco Bell story much.
componenttext: Well, I would just add, Brian, that at 6% mix, the breakfast doesn't change the overall Taco Bell story much.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. I think the good news is it's growing. It's growing in the face of us being focused. We're doing the right thing, which is we've got innovated products. We've got value now in that category, in that daypart, and I feel really good. I was out in
componenttext: Yes, yes. I think the good news is it's growing. It's growing in the face of us being focused. We're doing the right thing, which is we've got innovated products. We've got value now in that category, in that daypart, and I feel really good. I was out in the restaurants in the U.S. just recently. Visited Taco Bells for breakfast, got great food, had a great experience, and I think the general feeling is that this is something we're going to invest in for the long term.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Andy Barish with Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Andy Barish with Jefferies.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just a quick follow-up on that and then one other quick one. On the Taco Bell margin maintenance in terms of your guidance for the year even with a more sharpened value focus, is lower commodity cost really the primary reason you feel confident in th
componenttext: Yes, just a quick follow-up on that and then one other quick one. On the Taco Bell margin maintenance in terms of your guidance for the year even with a more sharpened value focus, is lower commodity cost really the primary reason you feel confident in that still?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think 2 things. I do believe we'll deliver at least 3% same-store sales growth for the full year. So obviously, we got off to a slower-than-expected start. But as we said, we are rolling over big numbers, plus 6%. So -- but the discussions I've ha
componenttext: Well, I think 2 things. I do believe we'll deliver at least 3% same-store sales growth for the full year. So obviously, we got off to a slower-than-expected start. But as we said, we are rolling over big numbers, plus 6%. So -- but the discussions I've had with Brian, he still feels very confident. So I think we're confident we will deliver the same-store sales growth we went into the year at, and, obviously, commodities are favorable. And I think all signs are that certainly beef will stay favorable probably through the balance of 2016.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just quickly on emerging markets at KFC. I know you called out a couple of Pizza Hut markets. That number is only up 1%. Is there any specific country or area that was a little softer this quarter?
componenttext: And then just quickly on emerging markets at KFC. I know you called out a couple of Pizza Hut markets. That number is only up 1%. Is there any specific country or area that was a little softer this quarter?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I think that when you're in 120 -- 130 countries, I always -- I'm never quite sure how many countries we are in on any one day. I think the good news is we had -- in 130 countries, you're going to have some up markets and some downs. India was minus
componenttext: Look, I think that when you're in 120 -- 130 countries, I always -- I'm never quite sure how many countries we are in on any one day. I think the good news is we had -- in 130 countries, you're going to have some up markets and some downs. India was minus 1, but Russia was plus 27 in system sales for KFC. We also had strong developed markets. Australia delivered another really good quarter: they were plus 5, which -- if you think about whats going on there. So we were soft in a number of places, but there's also real signs of real strength both in emerging and developed. And I think that Roger Eaton and the team believe that they also can obviously get sales up into at least the 3% same-store sales growth number for the year.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Karen Holthouse with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Karen Holthouse with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a question on China that's actually not on comp sales but on new store productivity. It looked like there's still a growing gap between comp growth and average weekly sales growth. And just curious if you could comment on that? Is it being driven by on
componenttext: So a question on China that's actually not on comp sales but on new store productivity. It looked like there's still a growing gap between comp growth and average weekly sales growth. And just curious if you could comment on that? Is it being driven by one of the two brands, units in one area or another? And any sort of update on how to be thinking about unit economics for the year? Because I think the last disclosures we have really only go through like 2014.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Karen, what were you quoting as the reason why you had that feeling?
componenttext: Okay. Karen, what were you quoting as the reason why you had that feeling?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That if you look at sort of overall store productivity growth, so just sales per unit versus comp growth, it looks like the gap between those two numbers is still getting wider.
componenttext: That if you look at sort of overall store productivity growth, so just sales per unit versus comp growth, it looks like the gap between those two numbers is still getting wider.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I see. Well, when we look at our performance by peers, it's pretty consistent. So I don't think there's a particular factor there. And I really can't, at the moment, think of a particular reason. That certainly has not struck me that the new units that we
componenttext: I see. Well, when we look at our performance by peers, it's pretty consistent. So I don't think there's a particular factor there. And I really can't, at the moment, think of a particular reason. That certainly has not struck me that the new units that we are building are -- in any way have inferior economics or any such [ph]. It's not as though we're building necessarily smaller units. It is true that we build more stores in smaller cities, but our comp sales growth across tiers has been fairly consistent. We are experimenting with multiple store formats to take into account the fact that there is still a very rapid build-out in infrastructure in China. So we are expecting a very large number of malls that are already under construction, the high-speed rail network is being expanded and then in China, unlike the U.S., there's not a phenomenon at the moment of highways with drive-thrus, or the rest stops, and all of those are being developed. I don't really see the character of our productivity per unit changing in the years to come. I think, worldwide, there is a trend to, what we call, small box, which is because in-lines are becoming more popular in mall stores, et cetera. So there may be in the longer term slightly smaller-format units, but not -- China is not that impacted because we hardly have any drive-thrus. We hardly have any drive-thrus at all. So most of them are in-lines anyway. So maybe we need to think about this question a little more, but we don't intrinsically see any reason why the sort of growth we've enjoyed should not be projected long term into the future.

And then secondly, Dave, could you walk through again the math or reasoning behind the VAT change and sort of how that impacts the business and why you think it would be positive. It would be helpful just to understand that a little bit better.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just your outlook for franchising in China. Do you -- if you'd like to convert more company stores to franchise.
componenttext: Just your outlook for franchising in China. Do you -- if you'd like to convert more company stores to franchise.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Well, at the moment, as you know, the estate of about just over 7,000 stores, about 10% are franchised and 90% are equity. I think, at the moment, as long as we have -- and the way -- we never chase a number of stores that we have to build, but whe
componenttext: Right. Well, at the moment, as you know, the estate of about just over 7,000 stores, about 10% are franchised and 90% are equity. I think, at the moment, as long as we have -- and the way -- we never chase a number of stores that we have to build, but when we get new trade zones opening and opportunities that make commercial sense -- and there's a very disciplined process for capital allocation and measuring new unit returns. We have a lot of surplus capital, as you know, in China. All the stores here have been built with Chinese-generated capital, there's no intrinsic reason why we would want to give that up to franchisees. The 2 reasons why we do expect, however, franchising to up marginally is, firstly, there are regions of the country where it makes sense for franchisees to operate. We recently opened in the Autonomous Region of Tibet, our first store in Lhasa, Tibet. And for a variety of reasons, including difficult operating conditions and local market knowledge, that was given to a franchisee, and it's been successful and I think that will grow. So there are parts of the country where we will do it for reasons that it makes sense to do it that way. And the other is that there will be opportunities to do franchising, for example, with gas station chains, et cetera. And for those technical reasons, the percentage of franchising might go up from 10% to maybe 15% or something in the foreseeable future, but we don't expect a significant change there. Now of course, if we do not find the ability to invest our capital in productive equity investment, sure, we'll look at franchising more actively. We're not at the moment -- we're agnostic to whether it's franchising or equity, frankly. I mean, both have advantages. Franchisees can -- obviously, they're capital-light and also they're very innovative. But at the moment, with the capital that we have, especially as we become independent, I think it will be a good use of the capital to continue to invest. I mean, China is a growth market, the way we see it. And we still have the vision doubling or tripling our store base. So that's the way we're looking at it. So I would say the franchising percentage will edge up, but it will not be a game-changer in our business.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So on the VAT, so currently China is paying 5% of all their sales in the form of a business tax to the government. What's happening now is China is moving to a more traditional VAT regime for -- which is similar to the regime in many other parts of
componenttext: Okay. So on the VAT, so currently China is paying 5% of all their sales in the form of a business tax to the government. What's happening now is China is moving to a more traditional VAT regime for -- which is similar to the regime in many other parts of the world, where we will pay 6% of those top line sales to the government, but we'll get a credit for some of the inputs that we have into our P&L commodities, utilities, rent, against that 6% credit. What's difficult for us to say right now is exactly how that -- those credits are going to accumulate and what exactly is going to be creditable, and we are working through that. As you can imagine, with 6,000 stores this is going to be a monumental effort, and there's also some lack of clarity around the rules at this point still. So we're going to have a lot more for you in July. We'll have 1 month worth of this in our Q2 results, the benefit in our Q2 results, and we'll be able to quantify much more detail at that point in time.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of Andrew Charles with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Andrew Charles with Cowen and Company.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Micky, as you saw success with an operationally simple promotion at KFC in the first quarter, I realize Pizza Hut is not as time-sensitive of an occasion, but are there opportunities to implement better operational practice at that brand, particularly on
componenttext: Micky, as you saw success with an operationally simple promotion at KFC in the first quarter, I realize Pizza Hut is not as time-sensitive of an occasion, but are there opportunities to implement better operational practice at that brand, particularly on the breadth of the menu?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely, Andrew, there are. I think the menu is complicated. I think I've mentioned this in December as well. It's a tabbed menu. You actually have -- it's a very large number of pages. It's a book. It's a little difficult to navigate, so simplify
componenttext: Yes, absolutely, Andrew, there are. I think the menu is complicated. I think I've mentioned this in December as well. It's a tabbed menu. You actually have -- it's a very large number of pages. It's a book. It's a little difficult to navigate, so simplifying that is a priority. Pizza Hut is celebrated and known for the variety of menu here. We do not want to lose that, but at the same time, I think we can make it far more controlled. It also speeds up service, and table turns are an issue at Pizza Hut at peak times. So for those reasons, we are rationalizing the menu. We're also, like I said earlier, pointing out the great value that we have through lunch combos and other offers, so we'll -- we're redesigning that part of the menu as well. And lastly, does it -- this -- I mean, I'm constantly amazed at how advanced China is digitally. It's got twice the number of cell phones, smartphones as the U.S. population. And even in our offices, people go up and down the elevator to go to lunch. They're looking up where the offers are available and where they can book a table, et cetera. So the action is shifting very rapidly to mobile devices, and both the menu as well as digital marketing is becoming very significant. So we are working on that. The good news is that both -- for both our brands, we are in a leadership position when it comes to that whole digital interface, cashless payment, et cetera. But to your question, yes, I think the sort of operational simplicity at KFC, making it easier for consumers to choose our bestselling products, and the general philosophy that the menu should not be a -- should be used more as guiding customers to our best-selling products than to give open choices, which they get confused about, is something that is applicable at Pizza Hut as well.

componenttext: Sure. So the plan is still to be 96% franchised by the end of 2017, which that will include the China units, post-spin. This year what's going to get -- what's -- more of what's going to get done are the U.S. re-franchising, which is going to be KFCs and -- I'm sorry, Taco Bells and, to a lesser degree, Pizza Hut. We would expect significant gains in those regards. Quite frankly, selling some of the international markets is a little bit more difficult, so that will take a little bit more time. We expect that to be more 2017 loaded.
