componenttext: Good morning. My name is Heidi, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome, everyone to the Yum! Brands Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Donny Lau, Senior Director of Investor Relations and Corporate Strategy, you may begin your conference.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Heidi. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. On our call today are Greg Creed, our CEO; and David Gibbs, our CFO. Also on today's call is Larry Gathof, Yum!'s Treasurer. And we're very pleased to have Micky Pant, Yum! China's CEO a
componenttext:
Thanks, Heidi. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. On our call today are Greg Creed, our CEO; and David Gibbs, our CFO. Also on today's call is Larry Gathof, Yum!'s Treasurer. And we're very pleased to have Micky Pant, Yum! China's CEO as well. Following remarks from Greg and David, we'll open the call to questions for the entire team. Please keep in mind Micky is dialing in from Shanghai, so there could be a slight delay in some of his responses. 
Before we get started, I would like to remind you that this conference call includes forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements are subject to future events and uncertainties and could cause our actual results to differ materially from these statements. All forward-looking statements should be considered in conjunction with the cautionary statements in our earnings release and the risk factors included in our filings with the SEC. 
In addition, please refer to the Investors section of the Yum! Brands website, www.yum.com, to find disclosures and reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures that may be used on today's call. We are broadcasting this conference call via our website. This call is also being recorded and will be available for playback. Please be advised that if you ask a question, it will be included in both our live conference and in any future use of the recording. 
We would like to make you aware of the following upcoming Yum!'s investor events. Third quarter 2016 earnings will be released on Wednesday, October 5. Our 2016 Investor and Analyst Conference will be on Tuesday, October 11 in Midtown Manhattan. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Mr. Greg Creed.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you Donny, and good morning, everyone. Yum! Brands delivered second quarter core operating profit growth of 7% and EPS growth, excluding Special Items, of 9%. Given our strong first half results and current trends in China, I'm pleased to raise our
componenttext:
Thank you Donny, and good morning, everyone. Yum! Brands delivered second quarter core operating profit growth of 7% and EPS growth, excluding Special Items, of 9%. Given our strong first half results and current trends in China, I'm pleased to raise our full year core operating profit growth forecast to at least 14% from 12% previously. I'm particularly pleased with the continued sales momentum at KFC China, which delivered better-than-expected same-store sales growth of 3%. This represents our fourth consecutive quarter of positive same-store sales growth in KFC China, despite the second quarter being our most difficult of the year from a historical sales overlap standpoint. Importantly, our China division is off to a good start in the third quarter for both KFC and Pizza Hut Casual Dining, including a return to positives same-store sales at Pizza Hut Casual Dining in recent weeks. 
Outside of China, challenging industry conditions in the U.S. contributed to soft sales results. However, our 3 brand divisions, in the aggregate, delivered core operating profit growth largely in line with our expectations and remain on track to deliver against their full year core operating profit growth targets. We are confident in our plans to drive second half sales improvement, led by continuous focus on innovation, value and our core products. 
This as a transformational year for our company as we remain on track to finalize the separation of our China business with a targeted completion date around October 31, 2016, ultimately creating 2 powerful independent focused growth companies. Our capital structure is fully in place, and we plan to return a significant amount of capital to shareholders but prior to, and after the spin. And I look forward to sharing more details on the transformative initiatives we are undertaking as we become a more heavily franchised company at our New York investor conference on Tuesday, October 11. 
Today, I'll give you an overview of each of our operating divisions and then David Gibbs, our CFO, will walk you through the financials. After that, the team and I will be happy to take any questions you might have. 
So first, China. As I mentioned, I'm particularly pleased, KFC, which represents about 75% of our operating profit in China, reported its fourth consecutive quarter of positive same-store sales growth with [indiscernible] comps in the second quarter. This was driven by stronger results in the second half of the quarter as bucket-related promotions resonated with consumers. It's great to see the teams focused on the core and value, translating into tangible results. 
Furthermore, we've simplified menus, improved efficiency and conveyed our value proposition to customers, all the while maintaining our consumer perceptions goals. In fact, we've done all these while simultaneously improving restaurant margins in each of the last 4 quarters versus prior year. 
I'm also encouraged by China's -- sorry, by KFC China's plans for their balance of the year, and then pleased to report our third quarter, which began June 1, and is historically our highest from a profitability standpoint, is off to a great start with same-store sales results quarter-to-date at low double digits. We rolled out boxed meals in June and are currently promoting our historically successful wing bucket, which we pulled forward a week earlier this year. As you will note, boxed meals have proven effectively globally for KFC and we expect success in China given test results. It's great to see now sharing across our global knowledge base, and we look forward to leveraging this on an ongoing basis across all of Yum!. 
At Pizza Hut Casual Dining, system sales declined 2% and same-store sales declined 11% in the quarter. The good news is, based on our third quarter results today, it appears that China team strategic initiatives are beginning to bear fruit. As evidence, quarter-to-date same-store sales are slightly negative, and I'm pleased to report they have turned positive in recs week. Our renewed focus on pizza and ensuring customers understand our value proposition are critical to brand's success. It's too early to declare victory, but we know the potential of this brand and are further enhancing our core
simplifying the menu and leveraging ideas of Indonesia and Hong Kong, where we have other successful casual dining concepts to execute on our strategy. 
Overall, we are clearly pleased with the progress we're making in China and our third quarter results to date. We caution overlaps do get tougher though through the balance of the quarter. 
So now, under our 3 branded divisions. In our KFC Division, same-store sales grew 2% in the second quarter or 4% on a 2-year stack. Operating profit grew 6% in the quarter, and the division opened 132 new international restaurants in 42 countries. 88% of these units were opened by franchisees, and 68% of our new international openings were in emerging markets. 
I'm encouraged by our ability to generate growth in both emerging and developed markets, as I think this really speak to the global strength of our brand. In the U.S., for example, we reported our eighth consecutive quarter of same-store sales growth. As further evidence, we are gaining traction with our strategy in the U.S, Our 2-year same-store sales growth lapped 3% growth in the prior year, so on a 2-year basis, comps were plus 5. System sales in international developed markets grew 4% and in international emerging markets grew 10%. We remain on track to [indiscernible] 475 net new international restaurants this year, and the U.S. is committed to delivering about 1,000 remodels in 2016. 
After the spinoff of our China division, KFC will be the largest contributor to new Yum! from multiple perspectives, including absolute profit growth, restaurant count and profit growth, to name a few. What really excites me are all the opportunities for growth that exist in this brand. Today, we opened approximately 3 new KFCs a day globally or 1 every 8 hours. We are on a path over time to open 1 every 5 hours, which will nearly double our annual new unit openings. 
Pizza Hut had flat same-store sales in the quarter with 1% same-store sales growth in the U.S. which makes up approximately 60% of total sales. While second quarter results in the U.S. were softer than expected, as competitors respond to our first quarter success with more aggressive promotions, we are pleased to see transaction growth in the U.S. and a continuation of the positive sales trend in our U.S. business. We believe our focus on making it easier to get a better pizza, whether it be by providing consistent value to the $5 Flavor menu and $6.99 Any medium pairs deal or by improvements in technology as we upgrade our web experience and migrate our system to 1 POS, will continue to enhance our business model. As a testament to our strategy, our company-owned stores, which are executing against a comprehensive suite of easy and better initiatives, including a locally competitive value message, driven by data science that is complementary to the national message and new operations programs geared to accelerate improvements in customer satisfaction delivered second quarter same-store sales growth higher than the system with transaction growth more than 5 percentage points higher. This company outperformance is obviously encouraging, as it is a clear indication that we are on the right track, and we are excited about the impact these initiatives will ultimately have on the entire Pizza Hut system. 
Our international business at Pizza Hut saw system sales growth of 3% in constant currency and a 1% decline in same-store sales in the quarter. Sales were strong in Thailand, Canada and the U.K. but offset by weaknesses in Korea. 
Last quarter, I mentioned that we were planning on rolling out proven successful tactics from the U.S. in international markets. I'm pleased to say that we have started this and are seeing success with the $5 Flavor menu in Australia and other markets and have plans to roll this construct out to additional market later this year. This gives us confidence that the international Pizza Hut business is not far behind the U.S. in its turnaround. 
And finally, Taco Bell. Operating profit grew 1% when adjusting for the impact of refranchising. And this was after lapping a plus 29% from the prior year. However, U.S. same-store sales declined 1% as we lap a plus 6% from the prior year. While a plus 5 on a 2-year stack is ahead of the category, we expect more out of Taco Bell given the strength of this brand. 
In the current environment, we need to pay innovation with value that clearly resonates with our consumers. For example, our $5 cravings bundle, deal bundle, improved results toward the end of the second quarter, and through the first 5 weeks of the third quarter, same-store sales are positive. We believe that the Taco Bell is extremely well positioned to succeed in a challenging environment. In market research, Taco Bell always remains as one of the top brands [indiscernible] value and innovation to consumers. We plan to [indiscernible] this division [indiscernible] balance of 2016 and going forward. 
Furthermore, we remain all plan with new-unit development for the year. We are accelerating international new unit openings and are excited to see momentum behind this strategic objective. While it is early days, we believe this could be a meaningful driver of long-term growth and look forward to continued progress. 
Now before I turn it over to David Gibbs, I just wanted to share with you some highlights from our recent biannual franchise convention that was held this year in Las Vegas. I think it's fair to say our franchisees are extremely bullish about the transformation we are undergoing at Yum! as evidenced by a record 1,100 attendees, representing over 100 countries, including numerous participants from our China division. This showcased the power of Yum! at its finest as we brought all 3 brands together to build and share know-how on development advertising, innovation, value and digital. We are on a clear path to become a world-class franchisor and an even sharper brand builder. 
So as I've said, 2016 is truly a transformational year for Yum!. We are confident we'll deliver at least 14% core operating profit growth, and I am pleased with the momentum in our China business as we near completion of the China separation. 
The Yum! China team is excited to reap the benefits of a continued growth in the consuming class. And as an independent company, Yum! China will continue to unlock massive growth opportunities while further capitalizing on what remains the#1 retail opportunity in the world. 
At new Yum!, I couldn't be more excited about the plans we have to become an even more unique and more powerful world-class franchisor. We will not undergo an evolution from Yum!, as you know, it, but instead another transformation as we increase our franchise mix to at least 96% by the end of 2017 and sharpen our focus on 4 key areas: Brand building, franchisee capability, market and asset development and our unique culture. We will make all decisions based on this construct. We will transform our mindset from equity-led to franchise-led and commit to our cost structure that enables us to build on these pillars. And I look forward to sharing additional details of this transformed vision for new Yum! at our Investor Conference in October. 
And with that, I'll hand it over to David Gibbs.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Greg, and good morning, everyone. In my remarks today, I'll cover 3 areas. Our second quarter operating results, our outlook for 2016 and an update on the recapitalization and separation of our China business. Let's start with the high-level ov
componenttext:
Thank you, Greg, and good morning, everyone. In my remarks today, I'll cover 3 areas. Our second quarter operating results, our outlook for 2016 and an update on the recapitalization and separation of our China business. Let's start with the high-level overview of our second quarter performance. 
Yum! Brands delivered core operating profit growth of 7% in the quarter. Our China division reported flat same-store sales growth despite it being our toughest compare of the year. As Greg said, we are pleased with the progress we are making in China and with sales results to date in the third quarter, which is historically the biggest quarter of the year from a profitability standpoint. 
Second quarter core operating profit in our China Division grew 6% and was impacted, as expected, by an additional $14 million in closures and impairment expense versus prior year as well as a $4 million expense related to our RGM convention. These expenses were partially offset by a benefit from recent value-added tax reform in China, which went into effect on May 1 and positively impacted restaurant margins in the second quarter. 
In aggregate, our 3 brand divisions delivered 3% core operating profit growth in the quarter. This was led by 7% growth at Pizza Hut and 6% growth at KFC, partially offset by soft result at Taco Bell. 
Overall, EPS before Special Items grew 9% including a 4 point negative impact from foreign currency changes. EPS benefited from a 6% reduction in our diluted share count compared to our second quarter last year due to our significant share buybacks over the past 12 months. 
Now I'd like to discuss our 2016 outlook. Given our strong first-half performance and current trends in China, we are raising our core operating profit growth forecast for Yum! from 12% to at least 14%, including 53rd week. We started the year by saying that we expected Yum! core operating profit growth of at least 10%. Outside of China, our 3 brand divisions remain on track to deliver results consistent with our initial targets. Therefore, the increase in Yum!'s 2016 guidance is essentially due to upside in China, including strong year-to-date KFC sales, margin and profit growth, and a balance of the year that will be aided by a vast change, partially offset by return to commodity inflation and higher labor costs. 
As you might recall, last quarter we walked through the pending changes to China's retail tax structure, which became effective May 1. As a reminder, under this reform, a 6% output VAT replaces a 5% business tax currently applied to certain restaurant sales. Input VAT is creditable to the aforementioned 6% output VAT. We believe this change will have a material benefit to Yum! China restaurant margins for the balance of the year. However, the scale and nature of the policy, along with implementation and transition challenges, make it very difficult to pinpoint the exact magnitude of the impact. While we won't provide any further detail on VAT today, we expect to be able to provide more clarity on our third quarter call after we have a full quarter of results behind us. I want to point out that for the balance of the year, we do expect labor and commodity inflation to partially offset this benefit. With this and our first test outperformance in mind, our current guidance for full year China restaurant margins is now at least 17% versus 16% previously. 
Outside of China, our 3 brand divisions remain on track to deliver results consistent with our initial 2016 targets. We expect any potential softness in topline performance to be offset by a favorable commodities environment. That being said, we are confident in our plans to drive sales improvement balance of the year and are encouraged with our positive results third quarter to date at Taco Bell. 
On the development front, we added over 370 new units globally in the second quarter, taking our year-to-date global new restaurant openings to over 650 units. Consistent with prior years, development will be weighted more towards the second half as we expect to accelerate our pace of development balance of year, further laying the groundwork for future growth. 
In China, we have increased our focus on refurbishing and remodeling stores this year, and we believe that momentum that we are seeing in the business today can be partially attributed to this investment in improving the guest experience. In fact, we are reallocating our capital to increase our pace of remodels to nearly 800 in 2016, up from our previous target of 550. At the same time, we're reducing both our growth and net new unit numbers for the year by around 50 to 100 openings versus our original expectations. This is primarily due to fewer new Pizza Hut Casual Dining units this year. But to be clear, our confidence level on the long-term growth prospects of our brands in China remains undiminished. Also, keep in mind, as a division, we expect about 100 fewer closures in 2016 than we had last year, and we continue to get cash paybacks from new KFC and Pizza Hut units in the 3- to 4-year range, both great signs of the underlying strength of the business model and the potential for future expansion. 
And finally, outside of China, for the full year we expect another strong year of development with total gross openings of nearly 1,800 units. 
Turning now to foreign exchange. Given the recent vote by the U.K. to exit the EU, I want to remind investors that one of the many great benefits of Yum! is our global and, therefore, diversified presence. In 2015, approximately 6% of our operating profit was generated from the U.K. and approximately 2% from the remaining euro zone. That being said, with the strengthening of the U.S. dollar against most of the world's other major foreign currencies, at current forward rate, currency translation is now estimate to negatively effect balance of the year operating profit by about $50 million, which represents an increase of $10 million versus our initial expectations. As always, please take this as directional guidance only as rates will inevitably change as we move throughout the year. In addition, keep in mind this does not impact our core operating profit growth forecast of at least 14%, which excludes the impact of foreign currency translation. 
Now I'd like to provide you with an update on our refranchising targets. As you know, in connection with the China separation, we've committed to become at least 96% franchised by the end of 2017. In the past 4 quarters, we've refranchised over 300 restaurants outside of China, including 82 units in the second quarter. Refranchising will, simply put, improve our business model. Proceeds from refranchising enable us to return significant amount of cash to our shareholders while creating an even larger and more stable stream of franchise fees. It also produces immediate SG&A savings as field level employees are typically absorbed into our franchise system. That being said, we realize there are additional opportunities to operate more efficiently and look forward to sharing more detailed plans around our ongoing refranchising strategy and G&A roadmap at our Investor Conference on October 11. 
Now I'd like to quickly update you on our spinoff plans. We remain on track to complete the spinoff with a targeted completion date around October 31. We filed our initial Form 10 on May 3 and filed an amendment earlier this week. Our comprehensive global roadshows will follow our investor conference. 
In conjunction with our spinoff, we are also optimizing the capital structure of Yum!. To this end, I am very pleased to report the successful completion of our planned recapitalization in June. In aggregate, we closed on $6.9 billion of new debt, consisting of a $2.3 billion financing capacity, securitizing our Taco Bell royalties; a $2.5 billion senior secured credit facility; and a $2.1 billion of high-yield notes. With the completion of our recapitalization, today we have approximately $9 billion in debt outstanding at an attractive bended interest rate of less than 5%. This marked yet another milestone in our previously communicated commitment to return $6.2 billion of capital, excluding ongoing dividend payments, to shareholders. 
In fact, since we announced in October 2015 our intention to separate the China business, we have repurchased 3.3 billion of shares, which equates to 42.9 million -- $3.3 billion of shares which equate to 42.9 million shares at an average price of $76. We continue to believe that our stock represents a good value at current prices. But make no mistake, this is just the beginning as we target an additional $3.5 billion in capital return across 2017 and 2018. This will take our total capital returned program, including dividends, to $10 billion over about a 3-year period and further demonstrates our commitment to delivering meaningful cash returns to our shareholders. 
So let me wrap things up. We're confident we'll deliver at least 14% core operating profit growth for the full year, and we're proceeding as expected with the separation of our China business. Our brand businesses are performing, in the aggregate, in line with our initial expectations, and I'm pleased with the progress we're making in China as it approaches its first day as an independent company. As Greg said, 2016 is truly a transformational year for Yum!. We look forward to sharing additional details with you at our New York Investor Conference in October. 
And with that, the team and I are happy to take your questions.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Joseph Buckley from Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Joseph Buckley from Bank of America.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Couple of questions. Could you elaborate a little bit further on the Pizza Hut Casual Dining opening plans that I think you mentioned you scaled back. And then on the remodels, the increased number of remodels in China concentrated on Pizza Hut? Is it tha
componenttext: Couple of questions. Could you elaborate a little bit further on the Pizza Hut Casual Dining opening plans that I think you mentioned you scaled back. And then on the remodels, the increased number of remodels in China concentrated on Pizza Hut? Is it that kind of the capital trade-off you're making?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Joe, this is Micky. Pizza Hut Casual Dining, as you probably remember in 2015, we opened 280 units. And over the last 4 years, we virtually doubled the estate. And we saw the trend over the last year of same-store sales, and our judgment was that we shoul
componenttext: Joe, this is Micky. Pizza Hut Casual Dining, as you probably remember in 2015, we opened 280 units. And over the last 4 years, we virtually doubled the estate. And we saw the trend over the last year of same-store sales, and our judgment was that we should pause for a break, so we would still be the leading developer of casual dining restaurant by far in China, but we paused for a bit. And I think we are encouraged by the trend that we are seeing currently. When same-store sales come back to positive territory and we will re-step up the build rate to Pizza Hut Casual Dining. As far as refurbishment is concerned, that is applicable to both our brands. And it was our judgment that it was very important to improve the customer experience and also to be able to bring our estate in line with retail in China, which has been modernizing in general very rapidly. So as David Gibbs mentioned in his comments, we increased the remodel rates across both brands and, in aggregate, that should be about 800 this year. So we've effectively, in the last 18 months, doubled our rate of refurbishment to bring new estate to acceptable levels. So it's not as though we're reinvesting only in Pizza Hut, we are reinvesting in both the brands. I hope that answers your question.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from in the line of John Ivankoe from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from in the line of John Ivankoe from JPMorgan.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just going to try and sneak in just a 2-parter on China, if I may. Firstly, and thank you for the color on the quarter-to-date basis regarding trends. But in the third quarter last year was really kind of a tale of I think 2 very different quarters wh
componenttext: I'm just going to try and sneak in just a 2-parter on China, if I may. Firstly, and thank you for the color on the quarter-to-date basis regarding trends. But in the third quarter last year was really kind of a tale of I think 2 very different quarters where, I think the first 7 weeks was down 11 and that the next 4 weeks was up 31. So you guys kind of get to see the trends and normally I wouldn't ask you to forecast results for the rest of the quarter, but how might that significant change in trend between the first quarter and the second quarter perhaps influence the quarter-to-date numbers that you're talking about? And then I have a follow-up as well.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're not going to forecast obviously the balance of the quarter. And I think as we said, we are pleased with the way the quarter opened whether that be, obviously, in China, on both KFC and Pizza Hut, whether it in the U.S., where we have a
componenttext: Well, I think we're not going to forecast obviously the balance of the quarter. And I think as we said, we are pleased with the way the quarter opened whether that be, obviously, in China, on both KFC and Pizza Hut, whether it in the U.S., where we have actually seen Taco Bell sales turned positive. So I think we are excited by the positive momentum we've got. We do know, we spoke about the fact that obviously, as you said, the lap gets harder, but I do see some encouraging signs in the progress we're making in the number of businesses around the world.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks for the color. And then secondly, our calculation is never perfect for this, but we do look at new unit volumes in China the best that we can based on what you all report. It does look like first half new unit volumes in China are well off av
componenttext: Okay. Thanks for the color. And then secondly, our calculation is never perfect for this, but we do look at new unit volumes in China the best that we can based on what you all report. It does look like first half new unit volumes in China are well off average and well off what the trend has been. So I guess I wanted you to you kind of confirm or deny that, make some comments about the overall trend of new unit volumes in China as you continue to develop both brands.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I can give you a couple of technical points on that and Micky can give you some color. But you're right, the average unit volumes are opening are slightly down and I can give you some of the reasons. In the pool right now, we got 100 small box units
componenttext: John, I can give you a couple of technical points on that and Micky can give you some color. But you're right, the average unit volumes are opening are slightly down and I can give you some of the reasons. In the pool right now, we got 100 small box units that were test units that are obviously of slightly lower volume. We've got little heavier weighing on Pizza Hut home service and our new unit development is a little bit heavier weighted towards Tier 3 through 6. In fact, the majority of the development occurs there. While some of the stores that we're closing are a little heavier weighted towards Tiers 1 and 2. When you add up all of those smaller points, you get to a little bit of a drag on new unit volumes. But most importantly, critical to us, is we are very happy with our development programs, we're getting positive cash paybacks, 3 to 4 years, margins are improving, sales trends are improving. So we feel good about our development programs. I don't know, Micky, if you have anything else to add.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you covered it well, David. I just want to reassure you, I think this question came up in the last earnings call as well, is there anything fundamentally changing about our strategy or the delivery of sales and profits from new units as we go forw
componenttext: I think you covered it well, David. I just want to reassure you, I think this question came up in the last earnings call as well, is there anything fundamentally changing about our strategy or the delivery of sales and profits from new units as we go forward as compared to the past? I think in general term, the answer is no. We continue to build aggressively. The band mix changed a bit. As David mentioned, we did build Pizza Hut Home Service restaurants which tend to be lower volume. And KFC slowed a little bit because of the 2 years of difficulty in sales. We fully expect KFC development this year to be ahead of our original plans. And in general terms, we see the efficiency and delivery from new units as being just as good as it has been in the past. In general terms, our focus at the moment is to raise traffic and sales in all of stores, and that's one of the reasons we moderated new unit build this year. We're encouraged by the trend we are seeing, and we hope we can continue to deliver growth in sales.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Palmer from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Palmer from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] on for Dave Palmer. I'm just wondering if you could talk about Pizza Hut Casual Dining in terms of what's happening there in the price contracts and media message. And also KFC [indiscernible] from Yum! footing, maybe you can comment on so
componenttext: [indiscernible] on for Dave Palmer. I'm just wondering if you could talk about Pizza Hut Casual Dining in terms of what's happening there in the price contracts and media message. And also KFC [indiscernible] from Yum! footing, maybe you can comment on some of the changes that are happening there. And then for both brands, we are wondering how is the innovation pipeline different today in terms of test innovation? How does that compare to a year ago?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, well, if I take the Pizza Hut Casual Dining, I think is in a much better position with regards to the consumer proposition than it was even I would say 3 months ago. The positioning of the brand is quite clear. It's been explained and our current fo
componenttext: Okay, well, if I take the Pizza Hut Casual Dining, I think is in a much better position with regards to the consumer proposition than it was even I would say 3 months ago. The positioning of the brand is quite clear. It's been explained and our current forward through the organization. Integrated position which covers new product development as well as service, down to uniforms, et cetera. And I think it's resonating well. It is called love to share, and it's appropriate because, unlike KFC, where most people come in singles, they order their meals individually, and Pizza Hut is a group, they tend to order their meals together. There's a big phenomenon now of sharing the food experience through social media. And all that is working in our favor. On both brands, the emphasis has been to continue our rate of innovation and to continue to give consumers good great meals. The differences that we are doing it in a way that is operationally friendly, so it does not slow speed of service or cause problems with value. In the case of KFC, for example, as Greg mentioned, that includes boxed meals which is a tried and tested formula globally, that offers consumers not 3 but 5 items with slightly higher price and offers great value. The innovation across all platforms is strong, but the big difference, I think, is that it is now practical innovation that gives choice without complicating operations a great deal. Across all dayparts, also we have made significant investments in high-quality coffee machines in both brands and high-quality ice cream machines in the case of KFC, to be able to improve our delivery and our quality of products.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just add, I think what you are seeing in China's what you're starting to see in the rest of the world, which is on the KFC brand, we are very focused on buckets, boxes, [indiscernible].  And on Pizza Hut, [indiscernible] Pizza Hut Pan Pizza in part
componenttext: Let me just add, I think what you are seeing in China's what you're starting to see in the rest of the world, which is on the KFC brand, we are very focused on buckets, boxes, [indiscernible].  And on Pizza Hut, [indiscernible] Pizza Hut Pan Pizza in particular. So I think our return to the core and belief in the core that it can drive same-store sales is what you're seeing in China. I think it is resonating there. That is also what you're seeing in the balance of our business around the world.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Glass from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Glass from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to go back to this inflection in China because I think it is important. But if I recall correctly, you were down like 11% in the first half -- first 7 weeks of the quarter last year and then you are up like over 30. So first of all, is that
componenttext: I just wanted to go back to this inflection in China because I think it is important. But if I recall correctly, you were down like 11% in the first half -- first 7 weeks of the quarter last year and then you are up like over 30. So first of all, is that correct? What drove that inflection last year, just so we understand what the hill we have to climb this year, what we're up against. And you didn't update your total comp trends for the year for China. Last quarter you said didn't want either. Do you have any updated thoughts just here holistically so we can think about this beyond the next few weeks.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I guess, what I would say it's really quite hard to look at 1, 2, 3 year comps in China and with any certainty be able to forecast sales. We're encouraged by the trends that we're seeing right now. We're not changing our annual guidance of 2% to 3%
componenttext: John, I guess, what I would say it's really quite hard to look at 1, 2, 3 year comps in China and with any certainty be able to forecast sales. We're encouraged by the trends that we're seeing right now. We're not changing our annual guidance of 2% to 3% same-store sales growth in China. We're in that range today year-to-date. But certainly, if the current trends continue, we would be able to beat that number. We do caution that the second half lap gets more difficult. But again, depends on how you look at them. The initial food event that we're lapping occurred towards back half of July, and that makes the comps really hard to look at.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Bittner from Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Bittner from Oppenheimer.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I couldn't help but notice the at least language that's in the new profit guidance. That at least language wasn't in the old guidance. Was that deliberate? Are you starting to see some nice potential upside to profits on the back half given the potential
componenttext: I couldn't help but notice the at least language that's in the new profit guidance. That at least language wasn't in the old guidance. Was that deliberate? Are you starting to see some nice potential upside to profits on the back half given the potential operating leverage that you get out of China and maybe some easier profit laps from some of the non-China segments? And kind of also, on the G&A side, Greg, you talked about an optimized cost structure when you had the franchise model in place. Is that something we're going to hear more about at the Analyst Day? Or is there any initial thoughts you could maybe give us on how you're thinking about that today.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first -- I'll take the second one first, which was G&A. I think as we've said and continue to say, we'll have a comprehensive review of our G&A structure in October when we meet. Obviously, we're going through the whole strategy structure, t
componenttext: I'll take the first -- I'll take the second one first, which was G&A. I think as we've said and continue to say, we'll have a comprehensive review of our G&A structure in October when we meet. Obviously, we're going through the whole strategy structure, the culture process. And I am very confident that we will be able to share, in great detail, those numbers when we meet in October. So I think we're only a couple of months away. We're finalizing all of those plans, and we'll be able to provide a great amount of detail about the efficiency we can bring to the business. Without try first part of the question back to.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of our forecasting for the year, the use of the word at least obviously indicates that we see some upside to the numbers that we are communicating. But as we we've all learned, these are difficult business to forecast with any precision. I feel m
componenttext: In terms of our forecasting for the year, the use of the word at least obviously indicates that we see some upside to the numbers that we are communicating. But as we we've all learned, these are difficult business to forecast with any precision. I feel more comfortable conveying where we are at with the terms [ph].

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Sara Senatore from Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Sara Senatore from Bernstein.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll also ask, I can get 2-part question here on China, if I may. First, I was interested to hear you say that you're still going after a lower tiered cities in the sense that all the macroeconomic indicators seem to be weaker in those -- in many of those
componenttext: I'll also ask, I can get 2-part question here on China, if I may. First, I was interested to hear you say that you're still going after a lower tiered cities in the sense that all the macroeconomic indicators seem to be weaker in those -- in many of those cities than they're in the higher tiered side. Just wanted to ask about new unit economics confirmation that you are still very good in those lower tiered cities given what we are hearing about just the macro backdrop. And I guess, the second point was about the China margins. I know you gave some color on that. Also surprised to see the commodity. It looks like the food margins were good in the context of it seems like an emphasis on value. So maybe you could just help me think through what the complexion of those margins should look like going forward. Will we continue to get that kind of tailwind? And will it be headwind on the sort of labor and expense side? So the unit economics and margins, if you will.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the margin question and then I'll turn it over to Micky for some color on development is what I think you're looking for. On the margin, you can see we have 1 point of margin improvement in China in the second quarter. That was really fundamenta
componenttext: I'll take the margin question and then I'll turn it over to Micky for some color on development is what I think you're looking for. On the margin, you can see we have 1 point of margin improvement in China in the second quarter. That was really fundamentally, the food and paper outperformed the inflation that we saw in labor, to give us that 1 point benefit. What went into that food and paper upside is really sort of 4 components. It was a price benefit, a mix benefit. We did have deflation. And then, of course, the VAT shows up there and then a couple of other line items. And then I'll turn it over to Micky for some color on development.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think one of the strengths of Yum! in China is that we are so widely present across the country. You know, over 1,000 cities with KFC. As mentioned earlier, our Pizza Hut development rate this year has been moderated a bit, but KFC will be on or ah
componenttext: Yes, I think one of the strengths of Yum! in China is that we are so widely present across the country. You know, over 1,000 cities with KFC. As mentioned earlier, our Pizza Hut development rate this year has been moderated a bit, but KFC will be on or ahead of plan. I can confirm that our new unit return are very high. They are at the highest they've been for 4 years in terms of percentage of units beating [ph] hurdle rate as said on the CapEx. So we are very confident that we are not over expanding at all in the smaller tier cities. We developed at least under challenging economic conditions, you get the best long-term deals and be able to secure long leases for these stores. We are very confident these stores made good do well in the future. So I don't think there is a concern at the moment with the rate of return on our new store builds.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Tarantino from Baird.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is about the divisions outside of China which you said on a combined basis are tracking to reach their profit plan. But it does look like they might necessarily small comp spend. So the question is, what is supporting the profit outlook? And d
componenttext: My question is about the divisions outside of China which you said on a combined basis are tracking to reach their profit plan. But it does look like they might necessarily small comp spend. So the question is, what is supporting the profit outlook? And does that comment apply to each of the divisions individually? Or is that a comment on the combined basis?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think on a combined basis, we did talk about that the second half of the year will be better for us from a profit standpoint and that Q2 was a difficult quarter for us. So as I've reiterated in my prepared remarks, we do feel like the divisions from pro
componenttext: I think on a combined basis, we did talk about that the second half of the year will be better for us from a profit standpoint and that Q2 was a difficult quarter for us. So as I've reiterated in my prepared remarks, we do feel like the divisions from profit standpoint are on track.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think the other thing is we -- as we said, we are seeing some improvement as we start the third quarter. Taco Bell, which obviously was negative in Q2 has turned positive in Q3 through the first 5 or 6 weeks of the quarter. The KFC U.S. numbers is a
componenttext: And I think the other thing is we -- as we said, we are seeing some improvement as we start the third quarter. Taco Bell, which obviously was negative in Q2 has turned positive in Q3 through the first 5 or 6 weeks of the quarter. The KFC U.S. numbers is also stronger than the plus 2 we had. So I think we're seeling that there are some momentum. Obviously, I think, as we all know in the U.S., the market is a little soft, but I think that we see some momentum in sales. I think that we believe the commodities will be under control. And I think as I even may have said in the last call, we are confident we can deliver the outside of China profit numbers even if the sales number's just a little tough to get to.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from Joseph Buckley from Bank of America.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016

componenttext: I wanted to just check on the check and the traffic components of the same-store sales. I'd love to get it for both China, KFC and Pizza Hut individually. And then for the U.S. comps for KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so for China, we can provide you at a division level that price contributed 2 points, mix contributed 3, and that covered a 5 point decline in transactions. Of course, as we talked about in the last call, that the transaction decline is not necessari
componenttext: Yes, so for China, we can provide you at a division level that price contributed 2 points, mix contributed 3, and that covered a 5 point decline in transactions. Of course, as we talked about in the last call, that the transaction decline is not necessarily per person as we think our party has increased given the promotion that we are running.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] U.S., I think that was also part of the question. I think the Taco Bell mix was a transaction mix pretty much. I think that is probably the best way to describe it. Our outlook at the category also probably for the last -- for the trailing
componenttext: [indiscernible] U.S., I think that was also part of the question. I think the Taco Bell mix was a transaction mix pretty much. I think that is probably the best way to describe it. Our outlook at the category also probably for the last -- for the trailing 13 weeks, the U.S. is probably running about minus 1 same-store transactions and probably around plus 1 same-store sales, so that's sort of the number that we see. But the Taco Bell mix was essentially driven by transactions. But as I said, I'm happy in the first [indiscernible] part or 6 weeks of the third quarter we are back on positive territory on Taco Bell. So that is a nice change in momentum.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Karen Holthouse from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Karen Holthouse from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just actually a follow-up to the pricing piece in China. It seems like it is a little bit more pricey than we've seen since some of the [indiscernible] since happened. As we're getting further away from that new sound pretty positive underlying momentum o
componenttext: Just actually a follow-up to the pricing piece in China. It seems like it is a little bit more pricey than we've seen since some of the [indiscernible] since happened. As we're getting further away from that new sound pretty positive underlying momentum on the brands and the positioning. Do you think that's giving you permission to potentially get a little bit more aggressive on the pricing front if you want to?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me clarify something, Karen, then I'll turn it over to Micky. On the pricing, that was all rollover pricing, there was raise, no pricing raise in the quarter. But I'll turn it over to Micky for more color.
componenttext: Let me clarify something, Karen, then I'll turn it over to Micky. On the pricing, that was all rollover pricing, there was raise, no pricing raise in the quarter. But I'll turn it over to Micky for more color.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Karen, in general, we had, as you know, commodities were very favorable in the first half, so we didn't see any reason to take pricing. We continue to offer a bigger meal bundles, especially buckets, and they offer great value anyway. The net i
componenttext: Thank you. Karen, in general, we had, as you know, commodities were very favorable in the first half, so we didn't see any reason to take pricing. We continue to offer a bigger meal bundles, especially buckets, and they offer great value anyway. The net impact of pricing is actually 2, which are all rollover. The rest of it, one shape, way or form is in of more customers or more food per customer which are both good news. We have to watch commodity inflation on the back half. At the moment, we feel pretty confident that we can deliver through other productivity initiatives, profit dollar goods without having to taking recourse in pricing. But obviously, we remain sensitive to commodity. And we will not be stupid about it. But we do want to contain pricing for as long as possible to maintain price stability in the market as well as to continue to offer great value. We are very focused on transaction growth, but we will not do it at the expense of profits come to that. The way things are at the moment, we feel pretty comfortable that through the year we do not have to take any further pricing, but we are watching commodity, especially poultry, very carefully in the back half.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jeffrey Bernstein from Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jeffrey Bernstein from Barclays.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just related questions on the China separation, the cash flow it's generating. One is on the separation, I'm just wondering whether there's any consideration at all for options rather than the current spin plan as always talked about, the sale of part or
componenttext: Just related questions on the China separation, the cash flow it's generating. One is on the separation, I'm just wondering whether there's any consideration at all for options rather than the current spin plan as always talked about, the sale of part or all to third parties or other opportunities. I'm just wondering whether you'll offer any insight to that. And then the second question was just on the cash return. I think, Greg, in your prepared remarks you say we're going to return significant amount before and after the spin. I'm just wondering whether we should assume that's traditional open market share repurchase, which I guess gives you the flexibility? Or Are you considering maybe ASRs or special dividends or other forms of that?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think with regard to the spin, I think what we have said multiple times, we look at the number of options to maximize shareholder value. And we have believed and continued to believe that a separation o r spin is the best way to maximize shareholder val
componenttext: I think with regard to the spin, I think what we have said multiple times, we look at the number of options to maximize shareholder value. And we have believed and continued to believe that a separation o r spin is the best way to maximize shareholder value. We are 100% focused on that, as we said, the Form 10 filings, everything else is going ahead in China. Starting things like Board selection. So we are really doing all the things you expect, we are on a timeline in order to hit the separation on October 31, plus or minus a couple of days. And we continue to believe that is the very best way to maximize shareholder value. I'll hand it over to David, he can just give you an update on cash return.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as cash return goes, obviously, we feel good about the share repurchases we have made to date at attractive prices, that our stock is priced attractively for continued share buyback. But that's something that we will continue to evaluate, there's o
componenttext: As far as cash return goes, obviously, we feel good about the share repurchases we have made to date at attractive prices, that our stock is priced attractively for continued share buyback. But that's something that we will continue to evaluate, there's other options, special dividends, tender offers and we will continue to revisit that decision as time goes on. But the intent obviously is to return that cash this year.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Andrew Charles from Cowen.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Andrew Charles from Cowen.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: All of my questions have been answered, but Micky, this is of the fourth conservative quarter of positive gross margin in China. So I just wanted to ask specifically about your willingness to sacrifice some of that margin in order to drive traffic by focu
componenttext: All of my questions have been answered, but Micky, this is of the fourth conservative quarter of positive gross margin in China. So I just wanted to ask specifically about your willingness to sacrifice some of that margin in order to drive traffic by focusing more aggressive on value. I know obviously you have some pricing that rolls off, inflation is likely to re accelerate. Just thinking how that ties the margin profile, boxed meals? And separately, David, just a follow-up on that last question. Was just hoping you guys could talk about how you're evaluating the remaining $3.3 billion of cash return to shareholders through October. Your current trading prices, what kind of [indiscernible] this is going to be 20% of your daily trading volume if you repurchase that all over the course every day over the next 3.5 months. So it just seems like an ambitious endeavor. Just want to hear what kind of factors at least you guys reallocate some of that cash for special dividend?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, this is Micky, I'll just take the pricing question and then hand it over to David. We do not really see a need at the moment to sacrifice margin. We believe we have a good flash point now, we have key velocity flashpoints around the RMB 29 mark fo
componenttext: Andrew, this is Micky, I'll just take the pricing question and then hand it over to David. We do not really see a need at the moment to sacrifice margin. We believe we have a good flash point now, we have key velocity flashpoints around the RMB 29 mark for individual meals for slightly bigger meals for individuals at 35 RMB mark and I believe our buckets are competitively priced. We are very keen to hold that for a period, but we don't see any reason to lift up the transaction any further. I don't think get help particularly by pricing. We are, however, doing more and more effective marketing activity through digital media, et cetera, which is a complicated topic, but we are getting higher and higher efficiencies that's allowing us to target specific consumers that will allow us to drive traffic to our stores and develop sales satisfactorily. So short answer is we are not looking to dilute our margins.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and then on the share buyback question, just a little bit more detail on that. Our plan is to get the vast majority of the buybacks done by the separation. But obviously, we're going to be smart about it and recognize that we have to comply with the
componenttext: Yes, and then on the share buyback question, just a little bit more detail on that. Our plan is to get the vast majority of the buybacks done by the separation. But obviously, we're going to be smart about it and recognize that we have to comply with the regulations on that. So some of that may spill over, but we still think we'll get it all done by the end of the year.

componenttext: Greg, can you talk a little bit more about the brands in the U.S. and how you feel you're positioned on value currently, particularly in Taco Bell? Any surprises over the last few much that you've seen from competitors or the changes in consumer sentiment that has made you change your approach and get even more aggressive than your plans in the back half of the year?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's good question. I think, as we've said earlier, there is [indiscernible] in the U.S. is probably the best way to describe it. I think industry reported yesterday that I think 75% of people age 18 to 30 that the U.S. is either falling behind or faili
componenttext:
That's good question. I think, as we've said earlier, there is [indiscernible] in the U.S. is probably the best way to describe it. I think industry reported yesterday that I think 75% of people age 18 to 30 that the U.S. is either falling behind or failing as a nation according to a [indiscernible] . So that is not particularly good news from just -- what are people thinking. As I said earlier, we believe that in the U.S., the market on a trailing 13 is about minus 1 in transaction is probably plus 1 in sales. So I think the good news is we have started the third quarter stronger than we finished than we had in the second quarter. I think what it means is, for brands like Taco Bell, we got to make sure that we get communication really tight and focused. I'm not necessarily believe it means we have to drop our prices anymore. I think what we're going to do is do a better job of communicating our value. We also have to remember that the Taco Bell brand always responds to incredible breakthrough innovations. So I think you will see more of that coming from Taco Bell. I have to give the KFC U.S. team credit. I think the George Hamilton as the new colonel behind extra crispy is brilliant, and that is having a positive impact on our sales momentum at KFC in the U.S. right now. So we have gone back to our core product. We haven't had a discount, we obviously wrapped it around $20 buckets and $5 boxes but we done a much better job of breaking through with the communication. And then I think on Pizza Hut, we have announced that we're moving to a new agency. We will get to a new campaign some time before the end of the year. And I think the Pizza Hut team would agree we can do better job of communicating both better and easy. So I'm positive about what's happening now, and I'm positive with regards we're working on. As I said, kudos to the KFC team, I think they have taken a core product and demonstrated you can deliver above category growth by making sure you have breakthrough medication. So better communication, making sure we've got the right product points, making sure we've got breakthrough innovation. I think that's -- I know, that's what the 3 U.S. brands are focused on. I am encouraged but what I'm seeing and I'm encouraged by the momentum we have going into the third quarter. 
So what I'd like to do, I think just to quickly wrap up. So first of all, I want to thank you all for being on the call. Really appreciate it. Pretty much [indiscernible] which was we're encouraged by the progress we're making particularly in those businesses that we have been focused on, which is both Pizza Hut and KFC in China as well as KFC and Pizza Hut in the U.S. As I said, we're off to good start in the third quarter in both China and the U.S. And all of us, and particularly I am looking forward to catching up with everyone at the Investor Conference in New York at October 11. Thanks for being with us today. We really appreciate it.
