And I guess this is seemingly happen without the industry acceleration underneath you. So what was it that changed so quickly in the third quarter for both of these brands to really divert from the industry so dramatically? And how much a fall-through does this have going forward the strategy that drove that?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brian. I think I wouldn't [indiscernible] say it's an abrupt change. I think, certainly, take the U.S., I mean KFC U.S. just delivered its ninth consecutive quarter of same-store sales growth. No doubt the plus 6 rolling [indiscernible] plus 2 , p
componenttext: Thanks, Brian. I think I wouldn't [indiscernible] say it's an abrupt change. I think, certainly, take the U.S., I mean KFC U.S. just delivered its ninth consecutive quarter of same-store sales growth. No doubt the plus 6 rolling [indiscernible] plus 2 , plus 8, it means we growing share in the category which is great. I put it down to if you think what we are in the quarter, we have Extra Crispy chicken which we have for 40 years and the $5 box and the $20 bucket. I think what demonstrates is when you have distinctive and disruptive positioning and breakthrough advertising with great product quality and very good operations, I think what you'll see is you can get the customer to actually come in more often. So I think that was the KFC story. I'm particularly proud of what the Taco Bell team did, how quickly they reacted to the Q2 minus 1 number to change the calendar for Q3. It's not easy to do. So a huge call out to the Taco Bell team for basically getting it back and 1.49 [ph] flat bread, the crunch wrap which is doing it well and obviously putting it in the $5 box. So I think the answer is we're back to the core, selling core products. They've got distinctive and disruptive advertising and positioning, and I think that's the cornerstones of success.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the $1 all-day menu that you talked about the Taco Bell, is the same as the $1 cravings menu that you've had? Or is it there something incremental coming on the all-day $1?
componenttext: And the $1 all-day menu that you talked about the Taco Bell, is the same as the $1 cravings menu that you've had? Or is it there something incremental coming on the all-day $1?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes -- no, so they run a $1 menu for the quarter as you said delivered a really impressive 14% transaction growth in that daypart. What they've done is they've now taken all-day value menu play, which is only just started in the marketplace. I think as I
componenttext: Yes -- no, so they run a $1 menu for the quarter as you said delivered a really impressive 14% transaction growth in that daypart. What they've done is they've now taken all-day value menu play, which is only just started in the marketplace. I think as I said, what was impressive is not only do we have now a market-leading position for low prices. We now have the category-leading position for everyday great value. And so I think that you're seeing these brands particularly both these brands strengthen in the marketplace.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Glass with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Glass with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Micky, maybe I just want to go back and talk a bit more broadly about how your strategy in China is evolving. I think when you came in, you focused more on the core of the buckets and the value boxes. So what's working now in China? Do you need more? And
componenttext: Micky, maybe I just want to go back and talk a bit more broadly about how your strategy in China is evolving. I think when you came in, you focused more on the core of the buckets and the value boxes. So what's working now in China? Do you need more? And how do use this crisis -- or how do you responsive a bit differently then you've done in prior periods if there's been any response? You talk about product evolution and percent commission. I think in the past you've given sort of the breakdown in China between traffic, ticket and pricing. Can you provide that this quarter?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. What's working is our strong -- Greg talked about the KFC U.S. business. It's similar things. As you probably know, we did divert capital to store refurbishment in the very large rate, so we'll good detail in the 11th, but we improved the look
componenttext: Yes, sure. What's working is our strong -- Greg talked about the KFC U.S. business. It's similar things. As you probably know, we did divert capital to store refurbishment in the very large rate, so we'll good detail in the 11th, but we improved the look and feel of our stores quite considerably especially in the large cities. We did focus on our core bestsellers, so we did simplify the menu just a little bit, but the quarter bestsellers, including fried chicken, which dialed and that's having a beneficial effect. Key price points, especially the crucial 29 39 [indiscernible] price points in this market. And lastly, digital. I think digital has been probably the most significant growth area for us in our cashless payments have grown from 10% to 20% in a very short period of the time. We expect that to continue as we partner up with people like Alipay to expand it. And our loyalty programs are significant now, so that percentage of transactions that [indiscernible] for loyalty points is very significant. And overall, spend on digital has become a very large part of our total marketing spend. All this put together is having good results, and we've accordingly geared our calendar for the balance of this year as well as the next year. So both KFC and Pizza Hut considerable attention to core product, key price points and continued in-store execution. And that really is what's working.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Michael on for John. Just on G&A in the context of being a 96% franchise business post spin. How is the company going to think about G&A? When you look at G&A on a per-store basis or a percent of systems sales? We're just trying to get a sense of
componenttext: This is Michael on for John. Just on G&A in the context of being a 96% franchise business post spin. How is the company going to think about G&A? When you look at G&A on a per-store basis or a percent of systems sales? We're just trying to get a sense of what the right metric is and if there's a target or benchmark.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's something that we plan on addressing in great detail at the investor conference next Tuesday, and we'll probably give you a couple different ways to think about it and some frameworks. But we'll mostly be focused on G&A as a percentage of syst
componenttext: Yes, that's something that we plan on addressing in great detail at the investor conference next Tuesday, and we'll probably give you a couple different ways to think about it and some frameworks. But we'll mostly be focused on G&A as a percentage of systems sales.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then this is David. Just a question about the guidance for the quarter, as you know, we don't particularly provide guidance on sales in the quarter, but we did obviously say that we feel better about the balance of the quarter. We've got great promoti
componenttext: And then this is David. Just a question about the guidance for the quarter, as you know, we don't particularly provide guidance on sales in the quarter, but we did obviously say that we feel better about the balance of the quarter. We've got great promotions on the calendar in November and December that we're really excited about, and that's why we feel bullish on the balance of the quarter. But I'd like Micky to talk about the promotions and the impact we're expecting on the business.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So there is a 4-month [ph] quarter, and we be passed September, which is a tough for us. We're in the middle of a golden week, which is the second-most significant holiday after the Chinese New Year. And that's going well at this time. It's a peak se
componenttext: Yes. So there is a 4-month [ph] quarter, and we be passed September, which is a tough for us. We're in the middle of a golden week, which is the second-most significant holiday after the Chinese New Year. And that's going well at this time. It's a peak selling period and comps are good. But after what we've got in the month of November is a winning item that's been tested very well and done with in the past and extended through November, which is the snack platter, which is a good example of how KFC in China is unique in the sense that the snack platter have got 4 parts to it. 3 of them are familiar for people anywhere in the religious french fries, popcorn, chicken and hot wings. The fourth part is squid, fried squid, which is unique to hear. It's done well in the past and [indiscernible] price point of 29, so we feel very good about our November calendar. And then in December, for the first time last year, we started Christmas promotion. Christmas is not a traditional holiday in China. And the response is pretty good. So we've taken that on another level this year covering the entire gamut from low end meals at RMB 35 to buckets for families at RMB 98. And with a lot of innovation taken from winning items from around the world. So December, I think, for the December promotions, looks particularly strong. And that gives us confidence in the balance of the quarter. So obviously, we can -- we report Q4 when Q4 is done. But at this time, firstly, the incident is behind us and the golden week is going quite well and the calendar looks really strong.

componenttext: A couple questions. The third quarter China restaurant margins were very close to peak levels, even with both -- well below peak AUVs. And add to that the $4 billion left to get your $10 billion target, looks like you might have $5 billion over the next 2-plus years? Is that right? And likely be share repurchase?

componenttext: Just taking the second part of that question. It's correct. I think we have about $900 million to return to shareholders for the balance of the year, intensive cash buybacks.

componenttext: I think our original guidance was we get this all done by spin, but the spin has actually moved up a couple of months from where we thought it would be done at the end of the year. And the second question on the margin -- future margin guidance for China, obviously, we're getting that benefit, as Ted mention that we have to be at least 2 points. Of course, that's going to help our margins, but at this point in time, we're not going to provide margin guidance for next year, but I think as the China team becomes a separate public entity, there's certainly providing more detail on that kinds of issues.

componenttextpreview: To add to that, David, on the profitability overall for the quarter, even though the sales were not where we wanted them, operating profit grew very well, and our cumulative operating profit in 3 quarters is about equal to what all of last year. So in som
componenttext: To add to that, David, on the profitability overall for the quarter, even though the sales were not where we wanted them, operating profit grew very well, and our cumulative operating profit in 3 quarters is about equal to what all of last year. So in some ways, the fourth quarter profit is going to be growth, and that's a big credit to our teams we own our entire supply chain and control it very carefully, so we have very good control on input, taxes, et cetera. And that's all helped us to get strong margin profit performance.

componenttext: Well, we've done 2 rounds of research where we actually measured sentiment, and we have [indiscernible] less inclination to go to one of our restaurants on account of the protest specifically. That number came down quite sharply. Now remember, the quarter-to-date includes all of September. And with that month gone behind us, I think it's safe to say that the protest impact is now -- is very small, is now negligible. So I think that we can put behind us now. It always takes a little while to regain momentum once you get going in operations and everything else, so this October holiday is going to be quite crucial in determining that, and my intention for them is to keep our [indiscernible]

componenttext: Great. And maybe just a quick follow-up. You mentioned, I think David mentioned in his script that there was some investments in driving sales plan in the fourth quarter? I know you mentioned some of these promotions. But can you maybe elaborate on what the investment side of that equation looks like?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, what we expect our overall E&P not to be at the same level that we have always budgeted. We have made -- because the margin benefit, we did invest some of it back. Some of it has gone to increasing -- to increase advertising spend on Pizza Hut. With
componenttext: Yes, what we expect our overall E&P not to be at the same level that we have always budgeted. We have made -- because the margin benefit, we did invest some of it back. Some of it has gone to increasing -- to increase advertising spend on Pizza Hut. With the Pizza Hut has a very good chance to recover momentum. We have a soft laps in the fourth quarter. We've very good promotions in November and at Christmas, and we are putting additional money in advertising promotion behind both. We've also got some unique China-only deals with international IP on films movies. And also, we've got maybe 3 of the best celebrities available in China across the 2 brands. So that's where we made investments. But it's all within what we originally budgeted. Your question implies that there's going to be any deterioration on profitability, that's not the matter That's the [indiscernible] in sales and that's what we're focused on.

componenttext: To be able to give you more detail, I don't have the number off the top of my head. But maybe Ted can give you [indiscernible] quite dramatically. And we'll give you numbers on the 11th. And I think what happens with [indiscernible] is it's very difficult to quantify exactly the impact until you get this fixed. We're very keen to keep the estate current because China architectural spend, especially in the biggest cities have gone up dramatically over the last several years with a lot of international entries. And they have been left behind a little bit. So that has been corrected quite substantially.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the remodels, we're planning to do about 780 remodels this year. And this is going to be about a 50% increase versus what we did in 2015. And year-to-date, we've completed a little over half. I think we'd say we're getting great feedback from our
componenttext: Sure. On the remodels, we're planning to do about 780 remodels this year. And this is going to be about a 50% increase versus what we did in 2015. And year-to-date, we've completed a little over half. I think we'd say we're getting great feedback from our consumers. We've contemporarized the experience. We've made the restaurants more youthful, more energetic. And overall, I think it's a very positive effect on the image of the brands. And we'll give you more updates on our conference next week.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions. One, maybe David on the new Yum!, I mean, looking at the operating margins this past quarter for proxy, I know that expanded a couple hundred basis points at each brands despite the mixed results and you're running from a low to the high
componenttext: Just 2 questions. One, maybe David on the new Yum!, I mean, looking at the operating margins this past quarter for proxy, I know that expanded a couple hundred basis points at each brands despite the mixed results and you're running from a low to the high 20% range at each of those brands. I'm just wondering directionally perhaps, how you think about the opportunity there with the refranchising, I mean modest further refranchising from here, but where do you think those margins are -- what gating margins are on the margin? And another question, Greg, just on Taco Bell, a very strong result in something you attribute most of that to product news and more so on the value front. So with that as a backdrop, I'm just wondering whether Taco Bell still [indiscernible] for more of that premium push. And why do you think the QSR category has been sluggish recently. I think you mentioned the category softness. I'm just wondering what you attribute that to.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the first question on operating margin. Obviously, as we move to an asset-light model, we're excited about significant expansion in our operating margins. We'll give you a lot more color on the exact refranchising plans and how that would play out in
componenttext: Yes, the first question on operating margin. Obviously, as we move to an asset-light model, we're excited about significant expansion in our operating margins. We'll give you a lot more color on the exact refranchising plans and how that would play out in terms of operating margin next week. And I'll turn it over to Greg for the second question.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think Taco Bell is doing a lot of things right. It's not just the core product. It's not just the great value. Assets are in great shape. Best customer experience delivering really as good as your fun in the marketplace. There obviously trying to m
componenttext: Yes, I think Taco Bell is doing a lot of things right. It's not just the core product. It's not just the great value. Assets are in great shape. Best customer experience delivering really as good as your fun in the marketplace. There obviously trying to make -- this is becoming an incredibly culturally relevant brand. I think being part of a millennial culture is really what's driving this performance. So I'm very excited that all of the things they're doing I think sets us up for a continued long-term growth just across the broad of all the things the brands to be doing.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Terms of the sluggish category, any thoughts of where you can attribute that to?
componenttext: Terms of the sluggish category, any thoughts of where you can attribute that to?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, it's hard to say. We've been doing a bunch of work just talking to different -- to millennial, gen x, gen y generally, boomers. Where, what, 5 weeks away from a general election. I think there is great uncertainty to what's going to happen in the U.
componenttext: Look, it's hard to say. We've been doing a bunch of work just talking to different -- to millennial, gen x, gen y generally, boomers. Where, what, 5 weeks away from a general election. I think there is great uncertainty to what's going to happen in the U.S. in particular as a result of the outcome of the election. It goes without saying people are sort of trying to [indiscernible] and the impact will be to the economy and I think people are hampering down a little bit. But that said, that's why I think I'm even more pleased with the performance of KFC and Taco Bell in the quarter because despite that uncertainty, those 2 brands, I think, the incredibly distinctive and disruptive and going back to the core of delivering great experience making sure the value is right. That's how you win, even in a sluggish market. And I think there are lessons that we're also applying around the restaurant. KFC outside the U.S. have just a game-buster quarter, probably with the exception of Japan, developed markets, developing markets, you can ask me any country, and I'll show you incredible sales growth. So I think the global growth of the KFC brand and the momentum we have in the strength that we've now got in the U.S. sets that up for particular strength. Taco Bell, as I said, across all the factors that you want a brand to be strong at is just tearing ahead. And once we get through the election and that uncertainty is removed, hopefully, the market will find some momentum, but I'm really confident that our brands can grow in strong markets or markets that don't have the momentum we loved to have.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016

componenttext: I have a question the full year guidance of 15% for operating profit growth. I know that includes the 53rd week, which I think in the beginning of the year you said was around 1.5, China for the full year, I think, you said will be 20. And you always have that fourth quarter step down just based on seasonality, you said the full year will be 17. So my question is on the new Yum! business, which been running 9 4 and 4, respectively, for the 3 brands, you don't have a step-up part of that for the 53rd week, but there's also something else in there that in place you going to have to big set up. My question is what [indiscernible] within the new Yum! outside of the 53rd week to get to that full year 15% operating profit guidance?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess we always anticipated the fourth quarter to be the best quarter of the year in terms of core operating profit growth and that gets to a lot of features of our business performance last year, expenses that were lapping and things like that. S
componenttext: Well, I guess we always anticipated the fourth quarter to be the best quarter of the year in terms of core operating profit growth and that gets to a lot of features of our business performance last year, expenses that were lapping and things like that. So I can't give you precise answer other than to say the guidance was raised because we do feel confident that the fourth quarter with the momentum that the brands have and the plans that we have in the fourth quarter and how they are tracking against those plans gives us lots of confidence in our ability to generate more profit than we thought this time last quarter.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Andrew Charles with Cowen and Company.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to clarify. Was Taco Bell traffic ex breakfast positive? And my question the Taco Bell performance in an industry backdrop? Obviously, the competitive environment continue to be fierce. I'm just wondering on your dollar all-day on the menu. We seem t
componenttext: Just to clarify. Was Taco Bell traffic ex breakfast positive? And my question the Taco Bell performance in an industry backdrop? Obviously, the competitive environment continue to be fierce. I'm just wondering on your dollar all-day on the menu. We seem to be seen from the $5 box strategy. And Greg outlined strategy earlier. Possibly, dollars menus and dollars offerings -- the core offerings have a better margins than the dollar offers that you'd be launching from the context of an inflationary labor environment.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess my answer is transactions are a bit slightly positive. The answer is we have the [indiscernible] breakfast, but I think breakfast transactions would have been slightly positive. I think the key to Taco Bell success is not just the 1-show pony.
componenttext: So I guess my answer is transactions are a bit slightly positive. The answer is we have the [indiscernible] breakfast, but I think breakfast transactions would have been slightly positive. I think the key to Taco Bell success is not just the 1-show pony. We didn't just do $1 menus, we also did triple [indiscernible] $5 boxes. So it's our ability to have great value and value is in just what you pay, it's what you get. I think if you look at what's in the box or if you look at now the Sony promotion we're doing right now, which from our millennial point of view is an incredibly attractive promotional offer. And I know the Sony box the team is very happy with the performance of the Sony boxes we get into the fourth quarter, which is why we said we have momentum. So I think transactions were probably slightly up ex breakfast. Margins in the quarter, I think we're well over 21% close to 22%. I've been talking to some Taco Bell franchisees, I can assure you they love this sort of margins. And I think, as I see it with the work that Brian and the team are doing, we're set up for continued success at Taco Bell going forward.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brett Levy with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brett Levy with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you guys dive a little bit deeper into the U.S. competitive landscape? Obviously, we've talked about value in premium, but what are your thoughts with respect to traditional and nontraditional competition, especially with all of the top that's going o
componenttext: Can you guys dive a little bit deeper into the U.S. competitive landscape? Obviously, we've talked about value in premium, but what are your thoughts with respect to traditional and nontraditional competition, especially with all of the top that's going on about food at home and away from home deflation?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, look, I think we're all reading the same reports, whether the industry reports or the newspaper or what's online. There's no doubt that food from grocery stores has declined. That's not to say some people aren't choosing to cook more at home. I think
componenttext: Yes, look, I think we're all reading the same reports, whether the industry reports or the newspaper or what's online. There's no doubt that food from grocery stores has declined. That's not to say some people aren't choosing to cook more at home. I think the fundamentals of what QSR offers, which is always convenience and value, will always be there. And as I said, in any markets, strong markets or sluggish market, always going to be winners and losers, and I think having the right tactics in order to ensure that you win is what's critical. And obviously in the quarter, 2 of the brands delivered. And we've got lessons from that, and I'm very confident that we can continue to apply those lessons to KFC at the Taco Bell and that we can apply those lessons to Pizza Hut. And there'll be a lot more of the Pizza Hut story that we'll talk about next Tuesday. And I know the Pizza Hut team is looking forward to tell you about their plans to reignite growth in that brand as well.

componenttext: Greg, the back what you just said about Pizza Hut and more detail next week, is there anything that you can share on your strategy with the U.S., specifically if you can provide the U.S. company-owned number relative to the system, which I think you provided last quarter, as a way to kind of see some of the traction from the initiatives? And anything you can share on the easy and better initiative and the local value initiatives will be helpful.

componenttext: Yes, sure. I think so the good news is next Tuesday, Micky will take you through the easy and better strategy [indiscernible] and will talk about that happening internationally. What I can tell you is in the quarter, the company same-store sales were 3 points ahead of the system and transactions were 6 points ahead of the system. So again, the company outperformed the system, and obviously, we working with the franchisee to bring them a long to sort of deliver that improve performance across the entire brand.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, I think the space is still growing. We tracked -- we repeatedly track this industry monitor and looking at it very closely just internally to make sure we don't miss an opportunity. The gross merchandise volume is still growing. For us, the tot
componenttext: Yes, well, I think the space is still growing. We tracked -- we repeatedly track this industry monitor and looking at it very closely just internally to make sure we don't miss an opportunity. The gross merchandise volume is still growing. For us, the total delivery volume is approximately 10% of our sales. So $600 million [ph] a year is through delivery. The percentage the ghost aggregators, I don't have -- it's not a very large percentage of what we have. dine in is significant growth or aggregated. But for the rest of it, it's mainly our own delivery systems. We are listed with the major aggregators, so we are present in all of them. It is true that there's been a lot of fall out because of the profitability of the aggregators are very negative. So the big 3 companies to continue to support their delivery engines. And rate of discounting, et cetera, I think moderated over time, but it still a growth area.

componenttext: Good morning. My name is Amy, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to Yum! Brands Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Keith Siegner, Vice President, Investor Relations and Corporate Strategies, you may begin your conference.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Amy. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. On our call today are Greg Creed, our CEO; David Gibbs, our President and CFO. Also on today's call is Micky Pant, Yum! China CEO; and Ted Stedem, Yum! China CFO. Following remarks from Gre
componenttext:
Thanks, Amy. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. On our call today are Greg Creed, our CEO; David Gibbs, our President and CFO. Also on today's call is Micky Pant, Yum! China CEO; and Ted Stedem, Yum! China CFO. 
Following remarks from Greg and David, we'll open the call to questions for the entire team. Please keep in mind, Micky is dialing in from Shanghai, so there could be a slight delay in some of his responses. 
Before we get started, I would like to remind you that this conference call includes forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements are subject to future events and uncertainties that could cause our actual results to differ materially from these statements. All forward-looking statements should be considered in conjunction with the cautionary statements in our earnings release and the risk factors included in our filings with the SEC. 
In addition, please refer to the Investors section of the Yum! Brands website, www.yum.com, to find disclosures and reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures that may be used on today's call. 
We're broadcasting this conference call via our website. This call is also being recorded and will be available for playback. Please be advised that if you ask a question, it will be included in both our live conference and in any future use of this recording.
We would like to make you aware of the following upcoming Yum! investor events. Our 2016 Investor and Analyst Conference will be next Tuesday, October 11 in Midtown Manhattan. Live webcast will be available at www.yum.com/investors and will be available for playback within 24 hours after the call.
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Mr. Greg Creed.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Keith, and good morning, everyone. Yum! Brands delivered third quarter core operating profit growth of 11% and EPS growth, excluding special items, of 9%. For 2016, we are raising our core operating profit growth guidance from at least 14% to at l
componenttext:
Thanks, Keith, and good morning, everyone. Yum! Brands delivered third quarter core operating profit growth of 11% and EPS growth, excluding special items, of 9%. For 2016, we are raising our core operating profit growth guidance from at least 14% to at least 15%, owing to continued strength in our business outside of China and solid profitability in China despite sales headwinds, which I'll discuss shortly.
Today, I'll give you an overview of each of our operating divisions; and then David Gibbs, our President and CFO, will walk you through the financials. After that, the team and I, including Micky Pant, CEO of Yum! China; and Ted Stedem, CFO of Yum! China, will be happy to take any questions you might have. 
For those of you who don't know Ted, he joined the Yum! China team in August. He's been with Yum! for the last 7 years and served as CFO of KFC Australia and New Zealand and most recently, as the General Manager of our KFC Asia business outside of China. Ted brings significant financial and operational expertise to Micky's leadership team as they prepare for the separation.
Now let's begin today with China. As we mentioned in our second quarter call, we were pleased with the results we saw through the first 6 weeks of Q3 as sales were ahead of our plan. However, tougher laps in the second half of the third quarter, which we built into the forecast, were compounded by an international court ruling regarding claims to sovereignty over the South China Sea. The ruling triggered a series of protests and boycotts intensified by social media against a few international companies with well-known Western brands. At its peak, the demonstration significantly impacted store traffic in certain trade zones, and this was during our busiest season.
The impact to our sales was sudden, and while difficult to pinpoint the exact magnitude of the impact on the quarter, our best estimate is there was a 400 to 500 basis point impact to the division's same-store sales in the quarter.
Most importantly, as we got further away from the incident in July, sales improved. Fourth quarter, which began in September, has seen improvement continue with quarter-to-date sales down modestly. We're encouraged by recent trends through the important Golden Week holiday, which is currently ongoing, and optimistic about a strong product and promotional calendar for the balance of the quarter, which Micky will discuss. Given these trends in the business, we expect same-store sales to be positive for the balance of the quarter.
In spite of the external headwind, the team was able to execute well and manage costs, resulting in solid profitability, with core operating profit up 14%. It is unfortunate that something outside of our control impacted our sales, but thanks to solid execution, it appear to be mostly behind us at this point, and we are moving forward with excitement about the balance of the year with confidence in the long-term potential of this business.
As we prepare to separate the China business, there is a lot to be excited about. First, the strategic partnership we previously announced with Primavera and Ant Financial is a tremendous asset and competitive advantage. Both are well respected Chinese institutions that are ideal partners for Yum! China as a stand-alone public company operating in China.
Second, we are the undisputed category leader in digital engagement. We're building the world's greatest loyalty program with a large and growing database to help us drive future sales.
Our mobile payment has doubled from 10% to 20% of sales over the last year, and with Ant Financial's Alipay, will continue to grow.
Third, delivery. We currently offer delivery from more than 4,000 units across China. This is an unmatched and growing platform that affords further growth opportunities. 
And finally, idea sharing. As we get closer to separation, what is ironic is Yum! and the China Division have never been closer from a knowhow and idea-sharing perspective, and this will continue post separation. You'll hear a lot more about all of this next week.
Now on to our 3 brand divisions, where I'm excited to say we're on track to deliver another year of strong operating profit growth, which is a testament to the talents and capabilities within the global team. For the third quarter, we are very pleased that in aggregate, our business outside of China produced 11% core operating profit growth ahead of our expectations. In what has been an overall sluggish environment for the QSR category, particularly in the United States, 2 of our 3 brands have been delivering solid results and has continued to do so into the fourth quarter thus far.
Our KFC Division excelled. Same-store sales grew 4% in the third quarter or 7% on a 2-year stack. Core operating profit grew 19% in the quarter, and the division opened 138 new international restaurants in 42 countries. 70% of our new international openings were in emerging markets.
System sales in international developed markets grew 4% and international emerging markets grew 12%. This brand continued to perform in nearly every market globally, with particular strength in Russia, Continental Europe and Africa this quarter. And we remain on track to open at least 475 net new international units this year, and the U.S. is full steam ahead on its remodel program.
In particular, I'm pleased with the third quarter results out of the U.S., which were driven by the Extra Crispy campaign. We continue to gain traction with our strategy here, and our 6% same-store sales growth lapped 2% growth in the prior year. 2-year comps of plus 8 in the quarter are category leading, and this is our ninth consecutive quarter of same-store sales growth in the U.S. and speaks to the importance of an aligned franchise system and strong marketing adhering to core innovation and value.
The KFC U.S. team, in partnership with the franchisees, have really turned this brand around in the last 2 years, and the brands' continued strengthening in a sluggish QSR market is commendable. This achievement in the U.S. gives me confidence in continued global success as we share best practices across the system.
Pizza Hut system sales in constant currency were flat, and same-store sales declined 1% in the third quarter. The U.S. market was influenced by an unsuccessful promotion and the competitive environment. As we saw earlier this year, we know the brand can perform when the right product is combined with compelling value and the messaging is distinctive and disruptive, and I am confident in our ability to turn around the Pizza Hut U.S. business. We believe the fundamentals are being put in place and now execution is the focus.
Our international business of Pizza Hut saw system sales growth of 3% in constant currency and flat same-store sales growth in the quarter. Across our international markets, we are leveraging a wealth of proven, ownable value bits [ph] to address specific consumer needs and rolling them out rapidly from one market to another.
In Thailand, for example, we took a bold approach to value, leveraging in any construct in tandem with significant product and operations improvements and have seen double-digit sales and transaction growth since launch.
Other markets now taking learnings from this significant turnaround. This traction gives us confidence that the international Pizza Hut turnaround is underway.
Finally, I'm very pleased with Taco Bell's strong performance in the third quarter. Core operating profit grew 9%. U.S. same-store sales grew 3%, even as we lapped a plus 4% from the prior year. This included 1 percentage point of growth in transactions or over 2 percentage points better than the industry. Our strategy of bracketing value with the $1.49 steak flatbread sandwiches and $5 boxes, which provided abundant value, allow us to grow transactions and boost check.
Furthermore, we saw impressive results with our breakfast offering in the quarter as transactions grew 14%, driven by our $1 breakfast menu. We're now taking the learnings from this success in promoting our all-day dollar menu. It all goes to show that when you remain committed to the core and value, the results follow. 
In addition to being a clear leader in offering low prices, we are now the -- leading the category in good value for money.
As for Taco Bell development, we remain on plan with at least 300 new restaurant openings for the year. Taco Bell international is an area of enviable growth potential, and we are excited to see the momentum behind the strategic objective. While it's early days, we believe that it's to be a meaningful driver of long-term growth and look forward to continued progress.
So 2016 marks the beginning of a massive transformation for Yum!, a transformation that has been years in the making. The first step is the October 31 separation of the China business. This business began with the first KFC in Beijing nearly 30 years ago and has grown to over 7,000 restaurants in over 1,100 cities. Today, it is one of China's largest employers with over 400,000 employees serving over 2 billion customers every year. In short, this business is a powerhouse with unrivaled growth opportunities in the world's fastest-growing major economy.
As we announced on September 2, investments with Primavera Capital Group and Ant Financial bring strategic value and additional local and digital knowhow immediately and over the long term.
In addition, on September 15, we announced a world-class Board of Directors for Yum! China, with Dr. Fred Hu, Chairman and Founder of Primavera Capital Group, to serve as Nonexecutive Chairman. I have the utmost confidence that this board will offer the market insights and strategic vision required to enable Yum! China to reach its full potential.
Including the Primavera investment, Yum! China will have a very strong financial foundation, over $900 million of cash and no external debt on the balance sheet at spin. I couldn't be more optimistic about the future of this business or the great foundation that is now in place for them to begin their journey as an independent company, and I look forward to watching them succeed for many years to come.
So in conclusion. At new Yum!, the massive transformation will continue as we become a unique and focused world-class franchisor. Following the separation, we'll be roughly 93% franchised, with a clear path to reach our stated goal of becoming at least 96% franchised by the end of 2017.
We've given a great deal of thought towards creating a high-growth, asset-light efficient company best positioned for accelerating growth in global system sales, operating profits and cash flow. And we're excited to share more details behind our thinking here next Tuesday, so stay tuned.
And with that, gives me pleasure to hand over to David Gibbs.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Greg, and good morning, everyone. In my remarks today, I'll cover 3 areas: our third quarter operating results, our outlook for 2016 and an update on our recapitalization and the separation of our China business.Let's start with a high-level
componenttext:
Thank you, Greg, and good morning, everyone. In my remarks today, I'll cover 3 areas: our third quarter operating results, our outlook for 2016 and an update on our recapitalization and the separation of our China business.
Let's start with a high-level overview of our third quarter performance. We're pleased Yum! Brands delivered year-over-year core operating profit growth of 11% in the quarter. In aggregate, our 3 brand divisions, excluding China, delivered 11% core operating profit growth in the quarter, led by 19% growth at KFC, partially offset by soft results at Pizza Hut. This growth is especially impressive given how competitive and sluggish the QSR category has been recently, particularly in the U.S.
Combined, our brands are outperforming the category, and we're pleased to see relative outperformance continuing thus far in the fourth quarter.
In our China Division, core operating profit grew 14% despite a 1% decline in same-store sales. The implementation of a value-added tax and continued tight cost controls materially benefited unit economics and enabled us to offset inflation and sales deleverage primarily resulting from the South China Sea ruling. As Greg mentioned, tougher back-of-quarter laps were compounded by the incident. While it is very difficult to be precise given all the moving pieces in our China business right now, our best estimate is this had a 400 to 500 basis points impact to our same-store sales in the quarter. 
It was most severe in July, primarily affecting our stores in lower-tier cities where the protests were more intense. The impact continued to dissipate and sales have recovered off their lows.
Overall, for the quarter, EPS before special items grew 9%, including a 6-point negative impact from foreign currency changes.
Now I'd like to discuss our 2016 outlook. As Greg mentioned, we're raising our 2016 full year core operating profit growth guidance to at least 15% from at least 14%, including the 53rd week. This increase is supported by strength in our overall business outside China and healthy profitability in China despite temporary sales headwinds as we discussed.
As expected, third quarter margins in the China Division benefited due in part to the diligent effort across our entire China team in implementing the new VAT. In each of the last 2 quarters, we highlighted the change into China's retail tax structure, which became effective on May 1. The benefit to our business continues to fluctuate from month to month as we refine our ability to get input credits and as the interpretation of the new tax code becomes clearer.
As a result, we will not provide precise guidance for the future benefit of this tax change other than to say that we expect it to be worth at least 2 points of margin upside on a go-forward basis.
We still expect full year China restaurant margins of at least 17%.  This reflects the ongoing benefit of the VAT, offset by labor and commodity inflation as well as our investment back into generating sales.
Now let's talk about development. Yum! remains one of the leading global retail developers. In the third quarter, we added over 475 total new units, taking our year-to-date global new restaurant openings to nearly 1,150 units. Consistent with prior years, development will be weighted more towards the fourth quarter as we expect to accelerate our pace of development balance of year, further laying the groundwork for future growth. For the full year, we expect China to add about 525 gross new units, and for new Yum! Brands, to add over 2,175 units, which will continue to include China.
With regards to refranchising, we've committed to becoming at least 96% franchised by the end of 2017. Once we finalize the separation of our China business, we will be 93% franchised. Over the last 4 quarters, we refranchised nearly 470 restaurants. In the third quarter specifically, we refranchised 94 stores, 48 of which were Pizza Hut restaurants. Refranchising allows us to return significant amounts of cash to shareholders while reducing G&A expenditure as field-level employees are typically absorbed into our franchise system. We look forward to sharing our strategy for improving overall efficiency at Yum! with you next week.
One housekeeping item. Unallocated corporate G&A in the quarter, excluding special items, was $44 million, with the increase versus last year largely due to timing. For the full year, we expect this to come in closer to $205 million, excluding special items.
Now I'd like to talk about our capital structure. In connection with the pending separation of our China business, we are optimizing the capital structure of Yum!. We closed the previously announced $2.5 billion new senior secured credit facilities and $2.1 billion senior unsecured notes offering on June 16, which was 5 days into our third quarter.
As a result, we have total debt outstanding of $9.2 billion. Our intention is to maintain leverage equal to about 5x EBITDA at new Yum, while Yum! China should have over $900 million in cash and no external debt at separation.
In the quarter, we also swapped a portion of our floating rate debt to fixed, resulting in about 90% of our debt fixed for a total current blended rate of 4.75%.
With this in mind, we expect interest expense of about $300 million in 2016.
We're fully committed to returning cash to shareholders. Last December at our Analyst and Investor Day, we committed to returning approximately $6.2 billion of capital, excluding our ongoing dividend payments, between separation announcement and completion, which assumed a year-end 2016 separation of our China Division.
In connection with this, we have repurchased approximately 5.3 billion shares at an average price of $81, reducing our share count by approximately 15% as of October 4. We plan to return the remainder of our previously committed $6.2 billion of capital before year-end. Including our recently increased quarterly dividend, we have returned $5.2 billion to shareholders year-to-date.
Now I'd like to quickly update you on our China separation plans. We are on track to complete the separation after the close of business on October 31. On September 23, the board approved the separation of our China business via a dividend distribution of 1 share of Yum! China common stock per each share of Yum! Brands common stock held at the close of business on October 19, the record date for the distribution.
We expect to complete the distribution of Yum! China common stock to shareholders on October 31.
When-issued trading for both Yum! Brands and Yum! China will begin on the NYSE on October 17, and Yum! China will begin trading regular way as an independent company on November 1.
As Greg mentioned, we were pleased with the announced investment in Yum! China by Primavera Capital and Ant Financial. They will make a $460 million strategic investment, reflecting an 8% discount to the volume weighted average trading price in days 31 through 60, following the separation of Yum! China. Additionally, they will receive 2 warrant tranches, representing approximately 2% of equity value in each tranche, with strike prices equating to Yum! China equity values of $12 billion and $15 billion.
This is an attractive structure for shareholders as it minimizes upfront dilution and highlights the long-term value in Yum! China as an investment.
More importantly, we are thrilled with the strategic partnership and the benefits this offers Yum! China. Both Primavera and Ant Financial are well-respected Chinese institutions that are ideal partners. Dr. Fred Hu, who leads Primavera, will become the Nonexecutive Chairman of Yum! China, and Ant Financial will have an observer seat. Given the value these ideal partners will bring to the table, we believe Yum! China is set up for success immediately and over the long term.
So to wrap things up, we have an exogenous and temporary event at China sales mid-quarter, but we're able to hold the line on operating profit in China. And with the strong performance of our brands outside of China in aggregate, we have line of sight to at least 15% core operating profit growth for the full year.
As Greg said, 2016 is a truly transformational year for Yum!. We're nearing completion of the separation of our China business and have secured strong strategic partners. We've enhanced our capital structure, and we've made progress on refranchising. We look forward to sharing additional details on these matters and more with you at our New York Investor Conference next Tuesday.
And with that, the team and I are happy to take your questions. Operator?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Sara Senatore with Bernstein.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Sara Senatore with Bernstein.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would like to ask just quickly about China and this -- the protests, in the context of I think you've laid out sort of comps that over the long term you'd target in the mid-single digits, but it feels like you've had a hard time getting there with perio
componenttext: I would like to ask just quickly about China and this -- the protests, in the context of I think you've laid out sort of comps that over the long term you'd target in the mid-single digits, but it feels like you've had a hard time getting there with periodic things that are outside of your control. So I guess the question I have is sort of twofold. One is, is there just a higher country risk now? And does that mean that the long-term targets of kind of 4% to 5% maybe are going to be harder to reach? And the second point is, is there an opportunity to make up some of that top line gap with faster unit growth? Because it looks like unit growth -- gross units is -- has continued to come down a little bit.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Micky, we'll let you take that.
componenttext: Micky, we'll let you take that.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, thank you, Sara. I think the first point, nobody likes giving weather and politics and reasons like that for sluggish sales. So trust me, we are very disappointed with the negative comps number. But this was very unusual. The first half of the
componenttext: Yes. Well, thank you, Sara. I think the first point, nobody likes giving weather and politics and reasons like that for sluggish sales. So trust me, we are very disappointed with the negative comps number. But this was very unusual. The first half of the year, we were trending very nicely. In fact, third quarter -- second quarter of this year was the fourth straight quarter of same-store sales growth. And in Q3, we were trending through the middle of the quarter very strongly. And then right around the 13th of July, this matter started, and we saw very sharp and sudden decline in sales. The good news was that thereafter, the recovery started almost immediately within 10 days or so, but it did have this impact. Two things. Firstly is that unlike the food safety incidents, research that we've conducted have shown that there's been no damage whatsoever to the brand. Our trends have continued to improve. And I think the other point, which was mentioned in by both Greg and David, the spin-off, coupled with the 2 very strong strategic partners, who are very deep respected in China, I think will help us in the longer term in issues and matters like this. I think if you're at the 11 October, Tuesday, Investor Meeting in New York, we'll give you more comfort as to why we feel that we can grow comps into the future. But had it not been for this incident, we would almost certainly have had comp growth in Q3. And we're expecting from this point onwards to the rest of the year to get back to growth. As far as new unit development is concerned, I think for the quarter, the impact was -- yes, it's --  it -- I don't see any particular reason why we will not have strong new unit growth. Again, we will share more details on the 11th. This year, as you know, we did take our Pizza Hut Dine-In build rate down from last year's 280 to about 150. And that was done -- 150 is still, on a base of 1,500, is about 10%. We felt that was a responsible thing to do, and it kept Pizza Hut comps back, which are trending upwards. And once that is done, I think we'll get back onto a strong growth path. So we don't see really a sort of ongoing decline in our union of build rate [ph] in China at all.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Bittner with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Bittner with Oppenheimer.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on the non-China business. The Taco Bell and KFC businesses are going to be, I think, a little over 80% of new Yum!'s profits after the separation, so it is really nice to see the comp acceleration in the sales of both of those brands, and I gu
componenttext: A question on the non-China business. The Taco Bell and KFC businesses are going to be, I think, a little over 80% of new Yum!'s profits after the separation, so it is really nice to see the comp acceleration in the sales of both of those brands, and I guess this is seemingly happened without industry acceleration underneath you. So what was it that changed so quickly in the third quarter for both of these brands to really divert from the industry so dramatically? And how much follow-through does this have going forward, the strategy that drove that?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brian. Yes, I think that I wouldn't necessarily say it was an abrupt change. I think certainly if you take the U.S., I mean KFC U.S. has just delivered its ninth consecutive quarter of same-store sales growth. There's no doubt the plus 6 rolling o
componenttext: Thanks, Brian. Yes, I think that I wouldn't necessarily say it was an abrupt change. I think certainly if you take the U.S., I mean KFC U.S. has just delivered its ninth consecutive quarter of same-store sales growth. There's no doubt the plus 6 rolling or the plus 2 and the plus 8. It definitely means we're growing share in the category, which is great. I put it down to -- and if you think what we're in in the quarter, we essentially ran Extra Crispy chicken, which we've had for over 40 years [ph] in the $5 box and $20 bucket. I think what it demonstrates is when you have distinctive and disruptive positioning and breakthrough advertising with great product quality and very good operations, I think what you'll see is you can get the customer to actually come in more often. And so I think that was certainly the KFC story. I was particularly proud of what the Taco Bell team did, how quickly they reacted to the Q2 minus 1 number to change the calendar for Q3. It's not easy to do. So a huge call out to the Taco Bell team for basically getting us back into $1.49 flatbread, the Triple Double Crunchwrap, which did incredibly well and obviously then putting it into $5 box. So I think the answer is we're back to the core, selling great core products. We've got distinctive and disruptive advertising and positioning, and I think that's the cornerstone to success.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the $1 all-day menu at Taco Bell that you talked about, is that the same as the $1 cravings menu that you've had? Or is there something incremental coming on the all-day $1?
componenttext: And the $1 all-day menu at Taco Bell that you talked about, is that the same as the $1 cravings menu that you've had? Or is there something incremental coming on the all-day $1?

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes -- no. So they run a $1 breakfast menu through the quarter, and that, as you saw, delivered a really impressive 14% transaction growth in that daypart. What they've done is they've now taken that to an all-day value menu play, which has only just star
componenttext: Yes -- no. So they run a $1 breakfast menu through the quarter, and that, as you saw, delivered a really impressive 14% transaction growth in that daypart. What they've done is they've now taken that to an all-day value menu play, which has only just started in the marketplace. I think as I said, what was impressive is not only do we have now the market-leading position for low prices, we now have the category-leading position for everyday great value. And so I think that you're seeing these brands, particularly both these brands, strengthen in the marketplace.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Glass with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Glass with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Micky, I want to maybe just go back to you and talk a little bit more broadly about how your strategy in China is evolving. I think when you came in, you focused more on the core, the buckets and the value boxes. So what's working now in China? Do you nee
componenttext: Micky, I want to maybe just go back to you and talk a little bit more broadly about how your strategy in China is evolving. I think when you came in, you focused more on the core, the buckets and the value boxes. So what's working now in China? Do you need more value? And how have you used this crisis? And how you responded to it maybe differently than you've done in prior periods, if there's been any response? You talked a little bit about product evolution and price evolution. I think in the past, you've given some sort of the breakdown in China between traffic, ticket and pricing. If you could provide that for this quarter.

headline: Yum! Brands, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. Well, firstly, what's working is our strong -- by what Greg was talking about, the KFC U.S. business, is very similar things. As you probably know, we did divert capital to store refurbishment in a very large way, so we'll give more details in
componenttext: Yes, sure. Well, firstly, what's working is our strong -- by what Greg was talking about, the KFC U.S. business, is very similar things. As you probably know, we did divert capital to store refurbishment in a very large way, so we'll give more details in the 11th, but we've improved the look and feel of our stores quite considerably, especially in the larger cities. We did focus on our core bestsellers, so we did simplify the menu just a little bit, but the core bestsellers, including fried chicken, the Zinger sandwich were dialed up, and that is having a beneficial effect. Our key price points, especially the crucial RMB 29, RMB 39 price points, which are the last 2 price points in this market. And lastly, digital. I think digital has been probably the most significant growth area for us, and our cashless payments have grown from 10% to 20% in a very short period of the time. We expect that to continue as we partner up with people like Alipay to expand it. And our loyalty programs are significant now, so the percentage of transactions that are being scanned at the till for loyalty points is very significant. And overall, spend on digital has become a very large part of our total marketing spend. All this put together is having good results, and we've accordingly geared our calendar for the balance of this year as well as for next year. So both on KFC and Pizza Hut, a considerable attention to core product, key price points and continued in-store execution, and that really is what's working.

componenttext: This is Michael on for John. Just on G&A in the context of being a 96% franchised business, in post spin. How is the company going to think about G&A? Will you look at G&A on a per store basis or a percent of system sales? We're just trying to get a sense of what the right metric is and if there's a target or benchmark.

componenttext: Yes, that's something that we plan on addressing in great detail at the Investor Conference next Tuesday, and we'll probably give you a couple different ways to think about it and some frameworks. But we'll mostly be focused on G&A as a percentage of system sales.

componenttext: Questions on China as well. I know you said that the sales impact is dissipating and you expect to be positive in China for the balance of the quarter. Does that mean that for the full quarter, you're expecting China comps to be positive? And then also on China, you mentioned the VAT tax having at least a 200 basis point benefit on a go-forward basis. Was that the benefit in the third quarter? Can you share that with us as well please?
